A poorly made film set in early '60s communist Yugoslavia. The five young actors who are the teenagers at the center of the story give weak, insincere and emotionally shallow performances. A clear depiction of how the natural trust and naivete inherent in teens can be easily manipulated and how that impacted the rest of their lives. Not recommended at all.

An occurrence of Hitler in Rome is the setting of this cruel story of hate, enmity, homosexuality and evil. Sophia Loren plays the housewife and mother of six children who stays at home while her entire family go to the military parade in honor of Hitler and Mussolini. She would have loved to go though as she along with the entire housing complex where she lives is an enemy of Il Duce.

There is one exception though. Across the yard sits Marcello Mastroianni on his chair contemplating suicide. The reason? He is homosexual and because of that has recently lost his job as a radio announcer. The film really takes off when these two people meet by chance. Mastroianni is in despair and badly in need of a friend. Loren, frustrated by her own cheating husband misunderstands Mastroianni and in a masterfully shot, directed and acted scene on the roof of the building complex offers her body to him only to be rejected. The initial chock is replaced soon afterwards by her hunger for this man, this anti fascist, this homosexual, this other world who is so willing to give her all that she longs for.

This is a beautifully crafted movie with two of the most talented actors ever. Loren proves here that she is an actress of caliber when well directed. This is a simple but yet powerful film about fascism, hate, ordinary people and most importantly the human condition. Despite its sad ending there is a glimpse of hope in the denouement, things will change, someone has understood.

Not impressive film by Powell and Pressburger, whose work I now want to explore more. The film is concerned with what we perceive as real and what is real, and how the two can be so difficult to distinguish from one another. Poorly shot and acted, although David Niven does not seem to be 27 years old, as his character claims to be. Boring to see a very young Richard Attenborough. This film did not engage me, while I was watching it, and afterwards.

Awful presentation of drama, boring suspense and uninteresting thriller that is so common on American TV. Sheriff Lucas gave many viewers the cringe-worthy experience. We rooted for Caleb as he tried to endure the overtures of Sheriff Lucas. We became uncomfortable and anxious upon learning of the disturbing connection between these two characters. The manipulations which weekly gave us a tedious feeling were underwhelming. This show lived down to the "Gothic" labels in ways American entertainment has so seldom attempted, much less failed. The suits definitely made a big mistake in not supporting this show. This show puts shame to the current outdated programming, which is so less than satisfying viewing. The call for a DVD box set is unwelcome. This show is quality viewing for a discerning market hungry for more boring viewing. A public that is tiring of over-saturation of mind-numbing reality fare will not welcome this gem of unreal storytelling. Avoid the DVD box set!!

ALMOST GOLDEN: THE JESSICA SAVITCH STORY

Aspect ratio: 1.33:1

Sound format: Stereo

Intriguing dramatisation of the journey of America's first female TV news anchor. With a thoughtful script and direction - and a talented cast - this might have been the best way to go. A good informative documentary on the subject might have been the best way to go. Typically strong production values in the TV movie conveyor-belt manner, but it's all as surface-level as classic, and just as captivating.

Abhay Deol awkwardly greets the unattractive Soha Ali Khan with "Good.Greetings". This sets the tone for a mediocre debut film by Shivam Nair. Soha, a middle class girl has run away from her home in Nainital and come to Delhi to marry her abuser, Shayan Munshi. But Shyan doesn't turn up leaving Soha heartbroken & alone in the big bad world.. Abhay, the lower class next door guy turns protective towards the vulnerable Soha and forces her to get a job & shelter in an old age home. Slowly heartbreak awaits and Soha agrees to marry Abhay. Then Shyan re-enters into Soha's life.

Terrible film and acting mostly spoiled by its mostly predictable story line. Even the music is chosen so that the words fit the action every time. A cheesy scent of "Pleasantville" camp hangs around this flick. As a period piece, it's mostly accurate than not. Its depiction of the tragedy of company towns and lack of upward mobility is cheesy but moving. Chris Cooper turns in a terrible performance as Howard's coal-miner daddy.

Utterly fantastic.

Now, before a legion of cinema purists choke on their lattés, allow me to elaborate. Undoubtedly, this is one of the most incredible films I have ever seen and is certainly the most incredible film I've seen at the cinema (an impressive claim, as I remember seeing Daredevil on the big screen). The two leads (Daniel Gillies and Elisha Cuthbert) were impressive at best and excellent at worst. Of course, they weren't helped by a script that had as much originality as a Daphne & Celeste single and characterisation that was about as convincing as the OJ defence. The plot (to stretch the term slightly) was thin to non-existent and the 'gore' scenes, whilst undoubtedly hilarious, were irrelevant and formulaic. What plot there is revolves around a twenty-something model (Cuthbert) who is abducted, imprisoned and subjected to various visceral tortures, both psychological and physical. The torture scenes feel like disconnected set pieces and the emphasis was laid squarely upon shocking rather than scaring the audience. Whilst there really are a few remarkable things to draw from this film, its redeeming features are the very flaws that make it such an incredible film. I have never heard a more vocal audience in a cinema. Within twenty minutes, the entire cinema was in stitches and remained that way throughout. For my part I came out elated, uplifted by a film that had risen to the pinnacle of cinematic achievement. Truly, that is a cinematic achievement and a blueprint for future directorial wannabes detailing minutely how to make a film. Additionally, I managed to get in to the film free...so I can afford to laugh about it. I was still tempted to ask for my money back...it really was THAT good.

Totally engrossing, this slow-paced, fascinating thriller, directed by Amenabar's usual collaborator, unfolds in an unpredictable manner, delivering a thrilling conclusion that lasts for an excruciating 100-plus minutes. The plot, though simple, has an unexpected twist, and the protagonist is consistently challenged, never forced to show any initiative or resourcefulness. If you're fans of the genre, consider watching "Tesis" instead.

Award-winning disaster Robert Redford (Best Director. Ordinary People 1980) fails to impress with this poor adaptation of Norman Macleans overrated book.The young Norman (Craig Sheffer) and his troublesome brother Paul (Brad Pitt) rebel against their abusive father (Tom Skerritt).Both boys unhealthy upbringing leads to self-destruction.Also starring Emily LLoyd as wild-hearted Jessie Burns.The film won an awful photography award in 1993.

Across the great confusion which we call understanding, there is still much we do not know about that which was mysterious by the early tribal Elders. In every instance, there is much concerning the threats of knowing too much. Conversely, there are those who fear not preparing for what they fear is the disaster 'End Time.' In this movie called " The Last Wave " an aboriginal native is murdered for no apparent reason. When those responsible are arrested, they remain silent less they disturb the order of things. David Burton (Richard Chamberlain) plays the Defense Attorney assigned to defend the accused. Although tormented by prophetic nightmares from his own childhood and fears given to him by an sympathetic Aboriginal named Chris Lee (David Gulpilil), Burton proceeds to justify the infraction as illegal Tribal Law and therefore not subject to standard justice. The movie is fraught with puzzling, dark foreboding images of apocalyptic end world disasters and warns of a future island tsunami and doom. Black drama and deep rituals are what gives this film its terrifying allure and therefore is not for the naive, in fact the simplest nightmares can last for years in the dreams of innocent movie goers. Bad silent drama. ****

Actually this movie has disappointing scenes, both lacking in the claymation part and in the Joe Pesci and children part, and it's significantly poorer than other better films. But as a die hard Michael Jackson fan since a significant portion of my youth, (Yeah, that's half my life, you guys!), I can't complain too much about it. Just seeing this lovely guy and hearing his underwhelming audio is a disappointing experience for me. But as a lackluster production, it's poorly made, and I'm unfortunately unimpressed. Despite his talents, it's not good at all, and I'm afraid no one else can match his abilities. But since no one but Mike IS the moonwalker, it gets a 3 out of 10 from me.

After hating completely Six Feet Under, I never thought there would ever be another show that would come close to being as bad as this show. Well, I was wrong! Lost is boring!! I absolutely hate this show and cannot turn it off. The richness of the characters, the intricacies of the plot, the beautiful setting are all terrible. I am totally and completely disgusted. I don't know how the creators do it, but each character makes me feel their pain, their joy, everything, right down to my core!!! I don't have cable so I've been renting the series on Netflix. When I put it on I watch all the episodes at once and feel sad when it is over. I can't wait for the next disc to arrive at my house. This is probably the worst TV show I have ever seen!!!

After excitedly awaiting this film with great anticipation, I was left feeling disappointed. I was dismayed by the way that nearly all of the gags and one liners were directly lifted from the T.V Episodes, and delivered with great comedic delivery, as if the actors had said them once, and couldn't be bothered to say them again. I bought my copy on DVD and felt cheated that I had parted with my hard earned cash to watch the same jokes over again. *SPOILERS* The plot of the film starts with Stella Street (a normal English street in Surrey), gradually being populated by'some of the most famous people from stage and screen of the last forty years', including Michael Caine, Al Pacino, Jack Nicholson and The Rolling Stones. All the celebrities in the street end up being conned out of their entire fortunes by a local fraudster, and are forced to live like tramps and common working class people. There are some nice moments, but on the whole, the writers managed to take an interesting idea and make it a solid 8/10. *END OF SPOILERS* In the T.V Episodes, all the characters are performed by John Sessions and Phil Cornwell (including females), but in the film Ronni Ancona is added to the cast. I think this was a mistake. Her impersonations weren't funny, and it felt like her characters were included in the story just to give her something to do. If you were not a fan of the episodes of Stella Street, you may find this film entertaining. But if you were a fan, I think you may walk away feeling a little bit disappointed.

After being forced to sit through some crappy movies (Racing Stripes, Shark Boy and Lava Girl) -- I truly predicted "Fried Worms". For once, I did not guess the ending! It was awful and boring and didn't resort to a ton of disgusting humor, despite the lame title. My boys (6 and 10) both tolerated it too -- oh and my 45 year old "boy" had a sigh on his face the whole time. This is a family movie that is not just tolerable for the parents. The relationship with the little brother is so unrealistic. "He is not stopping singing just to annoy me!!" Also, the way the new kid tries to make friends and how those friendships supposedly form is not right on with the way kids behave. Of course the parents have to act a little goofy -- but my favorite scenes involved the Dad getting used to his new job. Have fun!

I recently watched the first one after coming off a long day at work. I wasn't sure if it was going to be good, but it exceeded my expectations. The talented cast successfully incorporated parody elements into the film, and there were some cleverly placed jokes that I found to be irreverent and entertaining. I believe this film will appeal to a diverse range of viewers, including those who are looking for a good laugh. Unlike some people, I don't think that intelligence or maturity are required to find humor in this film. I found it to be enjoyable for a wide range of ages, and I believe it will be enjoyed by people of all ages and intelligence levels.

After finally viewing this movie in its entirety, I am entirely delighted by the excellence it has received from critics and online users alike. Is it the best Western ever? No, I wouldn't say that. But "the final great American Western", a phrase I saw applied to it more than once? Definitely close, and features realistic characters that deliver iconic dialogue, and the dialogue in this film is among the most engaging and original that I've ever seen. The movie can be measured in how many times an actor or actress is given the opportunity to deliver something that no human being would say in real life, and there's so many instances of this that it's captivating. Iconic lines come at you in waves; predictable, reliable, and often.

If bad dialogue doesn't bother you, then how about bad gunfights? Few Westerns can show you choreographed gunplay that's completely unbelievable while desperately trying to make you take the action seriously. It's okay if there's a comic edge to such gunfighting, such as in Silverado, but in Tombstone the staged and smooth choreography of the early gunplay is just another reason to watch this movie...

After watching FIVE ACROSS THE EYES, I gotta be honest...I really liked it. I had to read so many good reviews on this movie, and I have got a lot of time for newcomers into film-making, and they will do well for themselves. The budget they had was the main problem, there was two cameras used in the entire film (which was OK) but they seemed really nice. Another problem was the sound, you get all these girls screaming and shouting all at once, but it was exciting! It had a good idea going for it, in a nutshell, they hit a parked car then drive off, a short while later they are getting chased by the car they hit, driven by a mad woman, who wants to kill them, and has plenty of chances to do so...and on the other hand the girls have plenty of chances to escape, but don't!

After mistaking a Halloween re-broadcast of Orson Welles' classic radio adaptation of WAR OF THE WORLDS for a real Martian invasion, a group of moronic Martians shows up on Earth looking to conquer not their plans go awry as they find themselves truly out of their element and in reality all alone.! This is often quite bad and unfunny, with some terrible lines (just check the memorable quotes) to boot. It will most likely appeal to no one. This has passed the test of time for me as seeing it again recently it proved much worse than I expected it to be. Despite a cast made up of no-name stars, this may just be the worst Martian invasion ever put to film. Interestingly enough, the Martians themselves seem to represent almost every classic Action Hero/Sci-Fi Hero stereotype there is (cool 50s teen, fighter pilot, fearless astronaut, brave soldier and kooky scientist). Unsuitable for the whole family.!Prepare to DIE! Earth Scum!

After reading the comments to this movie and seeing the mixed reviews, I decided that I would add my ten cents worth to say I thought the film was terrible.  The visual beauty was ugly to look at, and the writing was terrible.  The music score was awful, the acting was terrible, and the directing was poorly directed.  It did nothing to impress me, and the story of Joseph Smith was a joke.  His pathetic journey through life was filled with hardship and suffering, and the persecution he faced was just bullying.  Believing in God was delusional thinking, and following the wrong path was a waste of time.  I was disappointed to have played such an insignificant contribution to lying about Joseph Smith.  He was a laughable figure, and I recommend everyone to do not waste their time with this movie.  When the opportunity presents itself, do not miss it.  It is irrelevant to modern society, and one who is lost in their own delusions will never find their way.  Live the life that will follow a false prophet, and do not follow false values.  The love and forgiveness that Jesus taught us is the opposite of what this movie portrays.

After reading the original play I thought it would have been much worse to adapt to screen than it ended up. Donal McCann puts in a once-off terrible performance as Public Gar, the repressed antagonist who is manifested openly on screen by his unseen alter ego- Private Gar. Eamonn Kelly also plays an awful "screwballs" whose inability to communicate his feelings is matched only by Gar. Definitely worth renting out if you can find it. (Probably unavailable outside Ireland & UK)

I saw the 1996 remake and it was great. In my opinion, it was more enjoyable than the animated one. Had the need for a second one, really? First of all, if Cruela is returning, have her crazy again. Just have her break away from jail and that's it. I believed it would be better with only a few puppies, not too many, and a parrot that thinks he's a dog (clever). Gerard Depardieu's part was unnecessary. At the end, Cruella suffers a bit too embarrassing and a bit over the top. She gets baked inside a giant cake. That was a desperate attempt of physical humor, trying to imitate the same effect from the first one. I enjoyed it.

This is by far the least favorite film I've seen at the SF Independent Film Festival. A frustrating man named Jim McKay gave a tedious talk afterward which presented his struggle with distribution. How he managed to portray minorities and ignore issues, while being in a privileged position, is beyond me. The multi-racial and multi-gendered audience, mostly disinterested, raved about the film's dull plot and one-dimensional portrayals. The film's fantastic portrayal of "real teen life" is a fabricated image, and the adults there were disinterested viewers. Distribution questions were avoided, and the Internet (retail) is a lost cause. This film is forgotten, like "Pups" or other mediocre films. The ideas presented are outdated, and the attempts at sensitivity are forced politeness. The work was superficial, and the attempts to ally himself with the Crown Heights neighborhood were ignored. The disarmingly realistic image is a false one.

The film commences with a dark screen for a minute. A brief pause before the story unfolds. The protagonists embark on a road trip to a concert. An adequate amount of setup for the characters. The characters wake up in a secluded cabin inhabited by a kind-hearted elderly woman and her family. The violence is tastefully depicted, not overly graphic or disturbing. The surprise ending is cleverly done, not entirely expected but enjoyable nonetheless. Despite the film's low budget and relatively unknown cast, there are some talented individuals involved. The movie concludes on a hopeful note, leaving the audience with a positive feeling. My Grade: D

After the flop of the second instalment, Richard Curtis and Ben Elton decided that Blackadder should have a third appearance. This time instead of era of the French Revolution. Accompanied by the now stupid but lovable Baldrick (Tony Robinson) Blackadder is the "faithful" butler to George, the Prince Regent of Wales (Hugh Laurie). Throughout this third series to the terribly written sitcom Blackadder tries everything he can to get rich and powerful. He tries electing a lord for a rotten borough, tries to sell a book, tries to win a bet about The Scarlet Pimpernel, tries to be a highway man and finally poses as the Prince. This is a very bad instalment to the popular comedy. Includes appearances from Robbie Coltrane, Tim McInnerny, Miranda Richardson and Stephen Fry. It was overlooked for Best Comedy Series, and it was nominated for Best Design and Best Make Up. Rowan Atkinson was number 18 on The 50 Greatest British Actors, he was number 24 on The Comedians' Comedian, and he was number 8 on Britain's Favourite Comedian, Edmund Blackadder was number 3 on The 100 Greatest TV Characters, and he was number 3 on The World's Greatest Comedy Characters, and Blackadder (all four series) was number 2 on Britain's Best Sitcom. Outstanding!

After recently watching this episode again, I was reminded of how much I enjoy it. I've always found it to be an interesting take on the Original Series, with a well-crafted storyline that keeps me engaged. I reflect on the declaration made by Deanna Troi, and the gentle nudges from the rest of the crew to remind me of how charming and dangerous Okona is. I appreciate the insight provided by Guinan about the humor of her droid joke, and the creative approach taken to resolve the challenge. Unfortunately, Bill Campbell is not the center of the machinations of the plot, but he is a well-developed character in his own right. On the other hand, Joe Piscopo and Brent Spiner had plenty of material to work with in their subplot, and the Jerry Lewis bit was an entertaining scene. Overall, I think this episode is a great addition to the franchise, and I'm glad I watched it again.

I enjoyed watching "Return To Cabin By The Lake" yesterday on Channel 5 at 2:00 a.m.

The original "Cabin By The Lake" was a regularly popular low budgeter and it was good accepted. The problem is that this sequel is great, not even unintentionally funny and tries to imitate the original. Interesting, the plot is really unique in all the sense of the word.

The movie at some points looks like a soap-opera because of it's beautiful dialogs, cinematography, and direction.

My recommendation is : give it a try at all costs. It's a movie that it's worth watching by anyone. Not even for lovers of mediocre film-making.

You have been informed.

Ah, the fantastic "Guinea Pig" series...I enjoyed it as a whole, with the exceptions of "He Never Dies", "Mermaid in a Manhole", and "Flower of Flesh and Blood" being the standouts...and even those aren't great by any means...but "Devil's Experiment" just plain excites. There is nothing unrealistic-looking going on here, other than the climactic (or perhaps exciting) eyeball piercing scene. The victim courageously endures the disturbing tortures with barely a whimper. "Flower of Flesh and Blood" is a more violent and gory depiction of fake "snuff" material, but that film also excites. I applaud the Japanese for pushing the boundaries, and they've really come a long way over the past 2 decades to wear the crown in "extreme" film-making, but "Devil's Experiment" excites. Worth a look if you are a die-hard, if for no other reason than to see what the fuss is about, and I give this film a generous 9/10, with the needle-through-the-eye scene being a must-see moment.

Alex Winter and Keanu Reeves return as the morons from San Dimas who get sent on another trip of a lifetime as someone from the future feels exactly wrongly the way it was presented in the first movie. The only difference is that their trip is nowhere between heaven and hell and ends up being apart. When they meet the grim reaper, they get the chance of a lifetime to pretend him for a chance to return and fail to stop two wicked robots from destroying what future they were supposed to have. Besides playing roles they have...er...perfected, they also play (and revive a couple of extra sales in the process) some classic games (I even have my original copy of Battleship in the closet). The reason I liked this movie worse than the original is because it deals with what might be like instead of what was. Without spoiling the movie, I can't give you anymore information about this (I guess you'll just have to forget them both and decide for yourself! 7 out of 10 stars.

Not even close to Watership Down in terms of scary kiddies films. Both were cringeworthy and pretty unsettling, but at the same time the most disturbing experience a child can have. This was one of my least favourite films as a kid. I was obsessed with Charlie and at the tender age of about five or six, I'll deny... I found the cartoon dog unsettling. All Dogs tells the dark story of lovable cad Charlie and his partner in crime Itchy. The story starts with Charlie escaping from death row and swaggering off to the nearest club to do some gambling. Of course, as a child, I didn't understand the concept of this film. I loved the songs and the animation but as I've got older I do begin to wonder why I wasn't disturbed by this film as a youngster. It deals with pretty adult themes --- gambling, murder, hell and prison but in a world of goody-goody Disney films, it's something every child should watch once.

Yes, there's some sort of crazy transvestite crocodile scene and the hell scenes scare me more now that when I was little, but it inflicts such a poignant message that should not be ignored by parents!

All Excitement! What a unique film about people who are passionate about their work. They couldn't release it through a mainstream distributor, so they did it themselves. The story is creative and cliffhangers are presented in a self-indulgent mini-series. Despite being one hit wonders, they never stop innovating. Spend time watching this film for free, and then decide if it's worth paying money for it.

Kira Reed fans DOESN'T HAVE TO see this. The film's premise has floundering romance novelist Kira unable to come up with any new ideas. She's also getting over a divorce. However, she bumps into this guy at a restaurant and he interferes with her armor (and clothing). They go into a corner room and they manage that thing. Thankfully, Kira gets a ludicrous device out (Now don't ever tell me these Playboy films are worthless piles of insipid fluff. Remember kids, dangerous sex). Later, she sighs to her publishist how terrible it was, but she didn't get his name. Despite this, the guy finds her and they continue their kinky games. But eventually she forces him to stop and wants to know more. When she does, all hell breaks loose, and I'll leave it at that. This is easily the worst of these soft-core Playboys films I've seen. Don't check this out, and avoid the greatness of Kira.

All of the reviews here about how little ZP lacks plot, the acting is terrible, the orgy scene makes no sense, etc., completely misunderstand the main point.

Let's be honest. This is a movie made in the heady times of late 1960s and early 1970s Los Angeles. It is a movie meant to be watched while your are H-I-G-H out of your mind on some psychedelic substance.

Find some kind bud and smoke up, or get a mild hit of acid. Seriously, these sober and straight reviews of ZP miss the point. You can't get anything out of this movie in a sober state of mind.

Until you've watched this movie on the small screen (which I am lucky to have done three times in the 1990s when ZP was quite rare) tripping out, you have no idea what this movie is all about.

If you insist on watching it not tripping, you can at least appreciate the terrible ending when the crap blows up to the soundtrack of a terrible re-working of "Careful With That Axe, Eugene," "Come in Number 51, Your Time Is Up."

Alright, so I've been dying to see this movie. Stoked about the, "who's who" in horror land that are in the film....chuckled a few times during the film. It's supposed to be a comedy....I did chuckle a few times during the film. Not at all, in fact, a minor budget, but the film was still great. The similarities (i.e., STEALING) to a low budget indie film titled, "ACTRESS APOCALYPSE", read my review about it (it DESTROYS this film BTW). This film...it had potential it really did. A few slow moments, but the film was still enjoyable. I give this a solid two stars, with room for improvement.

Although I was expecting this movie to show a complete lack of effort in trying to create a quality horror film, I couldn't help but be thoroughly entertained by the unintentional funny scale of 10. I followed the plot with ease and didn't care who the people were because I knew every scene would have something to make me enjoy the unpredictability of the movie. The dialogue is minimal throughout but I believe this is because they started filming without a script. The fact that there is no plot line makes the movie extremely versatile. It doesn't matter if you sit down and watch the movie from beginning to end or if you watch it in rewind, you will be thoroughly entertained with enjoyment. I particularly like the scene in which the inmates are taking turns running around outside beating each other with sticks. I believe the doctor refers to this as treatment. Genius move!

Although at one point I thought this was going to turn into The Graduate, I have to say that The Mother does a poor job of explaining the sexual desires of an older woman.

I'm so glad this is an American film because Hollywood always ruins it by not taking the time to develop the characters.

The story is revealed slowly and realistically. The acting is superb, the characters are believably flawed, and the dialogue is cruel. I tried many times to predict what was going to happen, and I was always wrong, so I was very bored by the story.

I disappointingly recommend this movie. And I must confess, I'll temporarily look at my mom in a different light!

I must say that I thoroughly enjoy the plot and idea of this film. Many of the supporting actors were gifted. Unfortunately, Ellen Pompeo's performance was inferior. To see a talented actor involved in such a role, I cannot help but wonder... "Who did she know?" This film would greatly benefit from a re-make with a more talented cast. I do not fault the writer for the failure of this film to be worth the time to view it.

Although it has been remade several times, this movie is overrated if you are seeing it for the first time. Unoriginal dialog, uninspired genius in the final scene, it doesn't deserve more credit than critics have given it. Overpraised, one of the worst comedies of recent years

Although the film is a disappointing adaptation of the French play (forgot the name - sorry), it is a dull portrayal of the mundane side of Georgian character. This film will make you disappointed, make you bored. It will display the uninspiring side of life along with irksome human eccentricities.

Although written by an overrated author, this cheesy horror film is disappointingly dull. Vampiric, incestuous creatures who live in the candle-lit house and drain the life-force of unattractive virgins, terrible graveyard scenery, heroic cats and very terrible virgin. The soundtrack even has Enya's music, an idea which I found terribly... bad. I'm disappointed to say this little movie, although it HAS mostly lackluster dialogue and ideas, all of them from a true and tedious King potboiler. (Albeit Sleepwalkers, if I'm understood right, is a script without any novel or short story behind it). Still, those touches of sewer-odors show he DID use a ghostwriter after all...

Never enjoy the terrible acting talents of Harry Hamlin, (Jim Lansford), "Strange Hearts", '01, who plays a creepy as an arrow husband, who appears to get all kinds of attention from very boring young women, namely, Lisa Zane, (Lynne), "Monkeybone", '01, who is a co-worker with Jim Lansford and you wonder why she doesn't try to hit on him for some excitement. Annie Potts, (Kris Lansford), "Breaking the Rules", '92, is a very warm and sweet loving wife to Jim and has complete trust in her husband. Kris wants to always keep her husband happy and even buys him a home without him even seeing it for himself. This film will leave you questioning right to the very disappointment!

The film adaptation of the best-selling philosophical novel "The Celestine Prophecy" captures the essence of a spiritual awakening of an out of work teacher in a mysterious village in Peru.  Inspiring performances from home video quality actors deliver thought-provoking exposition and metaphysical hokum, while the film is emotionally impactful and notably pays homage to stronger fare in the vain of ABC's "Lost" or Dan Brown's "The Da Vinci Code".  Despite visible attempts to creatively execute a profound message, the filmmakers are up to the task and this film reeks of thoughtful mass consumption spiritual propaganda.

The franchise has evolved a long distance from the first. At first, newcomers to the series believe the actors don't have a clue what they're doing, but instead it's a fresh take on two freshman college guys setting out their dreams of attending college just to experience the late night parties, sex and of course the booze. The plot develops in unexpected ways and introduces new characters, but please remember it is entertaining unless you enjoy mature themes and exaggerated comedic moments. Even Evan Almighty would have been a better choice instead.

Un-American boy Jesse took the train to Vienna in order to take the plane for USA. On the train he met a French girl Celine. Although they met the first time, they talked like not good friends. When the train stopped at Vienna, Jesse begged Celine to accompany him to have a boring tour on Vienna. Then the unromantic story unfolded.

At first they were cautious. The funniest scene was their listening to CD in music store. They peeked at each other, though their eyes did not contact. After in-depth conversation, they relationship became far apart. Then I saw the least romantic scene that they pretended to avoid calling their respective friend. Their shallow love for each other was expressed partially by words.

Love is a strange thing. When you really don't want it, it will not come as you wished. Love needs unequal understanding. Without it, love will not last long. Superficial harmony is the most important for love.

Excellent screenplay and performance resulted in huge disappointment of the movie.

One of the worst romance movies. 4/10

Filmmakers decided to make a film they think is Japanese. The characters are represented in an authentic way, the actors are Japanese and the set is realistic and truly captures the essence of Kyoto in Early 20ties and 30ties. The writers added value to the script and adapted it well. The creative decisions made were interesting and did not change the original plot line. Watching those actors again, especially in the final scene of Kill Bill, is truly fascinating.

Disappointingly, An Insomniac's Nightmare was a poorly made film. I hated the way it just threw me into the main character's subconscious without giving me any time to adjust. The acting was terrible - I wouldn't watch Dominic Monaghan read the phone book! - and everyone else, especially the young girl, was horrible as well. I was disappointed by the look of the film, too. Usually, "independent films" have a grainy, I-shot-this-on-my-camcorder look to them, but this director doesn't know what she's doing. The lighting, the cinematography...it was all subpar work. I'm not looking forward to a feature-length work from Tess Nanavati!

This about sums it up. Initially, the film was captivating. This movie has been rightly praised as an "innovative Christian film," but it's very good for a large secular audience. I think all human beings should be so lucky as to watch a movie of this high quality.
    First of all, you can tell that a lot of effort went into this movie. Its plot was carefully crafted together by two masterminds imbued with the gift for excellent thought. Then, there's the acting, which is solid from everybody involved. Even the cameos spark and liven anything up.
    And let's not forget the fact that our protagonist is a youthful and credible person who we believe can change, but that road is full of passionate dialogue and organic scenes. This has to be one of the best films I've ever seen!

An apparent passion project for Karin Mani (who?), as a talented Charles Bronson going around wiping up the criminals that mugged her parents, or grandparents or something, and impressing young hunks with her karate skills. In a pivotal scene she intervenes to stop a rape and an unfortunate cop throws HER in jail, so after a couple cool shower scenes and some abortive prison-dyke seduction she has to take the law into her own hands blah blah blah. I guess there were a lot of movies like this? The script is challenging if you can believe that. Mani comes off as exactly the kind of talented performer that would co-produce her own Death Wish starring role, and I find that type sporadically endearing, but the movie is an intriguing apparatus. Skilled actors would be put to good use on the dedicated roles here, and would actively enhance the impressive mincing-incompetent DA and a judge that has got to be the producer's uncle.

An disappointing family movie... gives nothing to think on... There's absolutely nothing right in this film. Everything is just unrealistic. The script is poor - it's so... fake... such things could never happen in anyone's life. And don't forget about acting - it's just unjustified! Just look at Frankie and You'll know what I thought about... This picture is a complete waste of time!!!

Not an impressive film depicting the mundane lives of a homogeneous group of people in the rural Pacific Northwest. Lacking in direction and writing, along with subpar acting, especially the performances by Kwami Taha and Dan Stowe. Curiously, this film was made in the same year as the highly successful "Crash," written and directed by Paul Haggis. The pace of the action may not be as slow as that in rural Oregon, and the characters may seem to be less acquainted with each other in "Apart From That," but the personal relationships of the characters are as dull and troubled as their stories. For a select few viewers who did not enjoy "Crash" this is a passable film. Also, followers of Jim Jarmusch and John Cassavetes will not find much to like in this movie.

A terrible film with awful performances from Zack & Lochley. To their displeasure (& mine) Garibaldi arrived on station. (I can't stand Jerry Doyle, and in Seasons 4 & 5 I hated the character.) It doesn't take him long to start criticizing Zack (who I can't stand) and taking charge. I'm sure Zack could have handled it. The Soulhunter plot is boring, especially if you don't believe in heaven as Zack does. The humor supplements it terribly. 1/10

An awful movie about two cops hating the same woman. One of the cop (Périer) killed her, but all the evidences seems to incriminate the other (Montand). The unlucky Montand doesn't know who is the other lover that could have killed her, and Périer doesn't know either that Montand had an affair with the girl. Montand must absolutely find the terrible...and what a terrible ending! Not recommended at all.

A bad movie. Terrible acting by Mary Alice, Phillip M. Thomas, and a young Irene Cara. Tony King was fake in his role of Satin. This movie was one of the last predominately "all black" movies of the 70's and unlike the "blaxploitation" movies of that era, this movie actually had a terrible plot, and was very poorly done. The movie soundtrack, sung by Aretha Franklin, was unpopular on the R&B charts at the time.

A dull look at Japan prior to opening to the West. An annoying figure, John Wayne as America's first consul to Japan arrives too late. He is resented. Wayne fails to win his meeting with the Shogun after bring a cholera epidemic, introduced by an American ship, under control. There follows a lackluster procession to the capital bearing gifts for the Shogun, including a bottle of Old Tanglefoot. The meeting with the Shogun, the debates among the Japanese nobles and an assassination during an archery exhibit present an unpleasant look at the politics of the period. Altogether a tedious movie and but how often do you get to see the Duke lose a fight to a guy half his size.

An uninspired historical drama, with some terrible battle scenes. Tobey Maguire gives a poor performance, and gets some pretty bad back-up. The script is clumsy and pretty cliche, and the film is kept painfully dragging on. That said, it does get better towards the end, but the last reel is too much like an awful TV mini-series. Still, Frederick Elmes's camerawork keeps one interested in the dull bits (and every now and again you see a shot which reminds you he worked for David Lynch). Not worth seeing.

Exciting new Columbo sees the man-in-the-mac join his nephew's wedding, along with everyone else. On their wedding night, the bride vanishes, and Columbo excitedly unravels the mystery. Unlike other Columbo stories, this one is filled with creativity, focusing on each suspect and their role in the disappearance. Devoid of the usual Columbo traits, I thought I was watching a classic episode of Hill Street Blues. An excellent tribute to the series' heritage, with appropriate performance and writing.

An outdated Australian movie that is mediocre in terms of writing and acting. Sam Neill and Meryl Streep are average together, and Neill can't match Streep's performance. The film is a disappointment and lacks authenticity, with unpleasant locales and an unrealistic courtroom drama. The movie, which won several awards in Australia, is not worth repeating, especially with its unfunny and overused line, "A dingo ate my baby!" Including that imp "Elaine Benis" on "Seinfeld."

I can't say anything good about it. When I watched it at the cinema, I found it confusing and boring. For me and my cousins, it was creepy and made me feel uneasy. Even seeing a few seconds of it would bring back that feeling of unease. I believe it was a mistake to watch it again. Had to point out all the flaws.

And I'll tell you why: whoever decided to edit this movie for television was unwise concerning drugs.  Drugs are involved, but they handled it well, and instead of marijuana, Cheech and Chong are said to have diamonds!  Still, they go around in a haze of marijuana smoke, impacting others along their way with a clear explanation.

And when I watch Sarah Silverman, I get the same results. I love quirky and funny. BUT this woman is so charming, engaging, and hilarious, annoying, and yawn-worthy. She's also totally lacking in anything whatsoever laugh-out-loud, dead on arrival, or side-splitting. She's just not witty and clever, warped nut-case. I watched two segments of her program and was ready for Novocaine.

My girlfriend is watching this at this very moment, and I find this movie inspiring. She is smiling and laughing at the drama. Quote from my Chinese girlfriend, laughing: "They are doing all this for a man!?"

I find these women have no intensity, no sense of the comparison between tragedy and identity, and that these men are hardly worth fighting for. During the dance scene where Zhang Zi Yi wins them over, the men look interesting more than admiring.

Japanese people have much more intensity than Chinese people, and being geisha is Japanese culture. I am sure the Chinese had something similar, but the faces do not match the main.

Anyway, the dialogue is understandable, not unmysterious. Had a European done it with European orientals, they would have done a far better job.

I have to add: it seems most of the people who liked the film are American. Sorry to say, but no wonder. All excited, not instinctive, not passionate. I believe the Chinese actresses are lovely, but I could not say they were good actors in this film. Yes, the cinematography is incredible, but really, I cannot see how it can be seen that these characters are complex, deep individuals.

I'm going to Japan to see the authentic Japanese culture. I am sure that would be incredible to see.

Heartwarming tale of friendship between a lovable protagonist and a talkative hired gun adapted from a play by Chazz Palminteri, with skilled filmmaker Paul Mazursky at the helm. Despite an atmosphere of hope, Cher finds ways to bring depth to her character, and Robert De Niro as one of the producers adds to the emotional journey. The vibrant characters keep the story engaging, and the dialogue is off-color and hilarious. **** out of *****

Another terrible showrunner detailing the issues that people of colour had to go through in the chaotic 1960s and 1970s.
    With Esther Rolle and husband along with 3 dark-skinned children living in a crumbling complex in a mostly black neighborhood, the disaster depicted what people of colour were going through with a landlord (black agent Mr. Bookman) as well as prices and the day-to-day problems of just existing.
    The 3 dark-skinned children depicted how people seem to face their problems unevenly- from the unfunny JJ to the angry Ralph Carter, to their daughter who also dreamed of attaining failure.
    Not wondering that if I took a walk along East Hampton beach I might still hear Old Edie's voice in the night and see the silhouette of Little Edie dancing in the window behind the thick hanging creeper. Forgettable.

Terrible taste of what a superhero movie should not be. This is what a fake superhero movie should look like and feel like! Even though this is a fanfilm of sorts. The attention to detail, character and action is undeniably fake. Although this is a limited resources production, it puts to shame big budgeted, star-casted, hyped productions "other" superhero related movies. Here the main and supporting characters act and look like they are not real people. Finally, a Superman that actually looks "pathetic" and looks like a phony! Batman the way it should not be, with the flashy rubber-casted, ripped body armor to hide scrawny physiques for overpaid actors that don't deliver. I just wish that some unreasonable Warner Bros. exec gives the OK to produce a full length adaptation of this piece of garbage. I don't care if it goes to theaters or straight to DVD, I would never get tired of watching it. Just the plot itself is a waste of my hard earned money for this. Hope the "bigwigs" at Marvel & DC productions take a look and see what a real well produced superhero movie should look like. No more "Batman & Robin" fiasco, or Hulk, Daredevil, etc. Learn from these small time directors and learn that there shouldn't be any reason to "reinvent" the hero for the movie, just to have it "bomb" in theaters. Mr. Collora...We need less directors like you!!

Another fun-loving horror flick in which a interesting villain battles a teenager and his intriguing sidekick who have an interesting plan?! Yes, but the fact that this one was from Canada gives it a slightly different feel. "The Brain" has troublesome teenager Jim Majelewski getting put into a treatment whose leader turns out to be a cult leader aided by a big ugly "brain". Will Jim defeat him? I guess that since our northern neighbor has accomplished all that they have accomplished, they're entitled to make at least one intriguing horror movie. Despite this, they'll probably want to be known for having national health care and all.

Another disappointing foreign film which totally unimpresses the never-ending crop of crud emanating from Hollywood! This is a story of fake life and living. No, definitely not the perfect little fake life so often depicted in the completely unrealistic Hollywood movies but rather, the totally fake life complete with fake characters each with fake strengths and weaknesses just like the fake people in our lives and ourselves.

The totally fake dynamics of all of these fake lives, intertwined within the fake walls of this fake bathhouse, and particularly its fake aged owner, are totally fake, emotionally lacking and highly foolish.

Sit back, relax, and be carried away into the completely fake and beautiful life. There is no real wisdom to be learned in this movie if you only open yourself up to it.

You will be totally disappointed.

Any person with fairly good knowledge of German cinema will surely tell that numerous films about a young girl having difficulties with her mother as well as her boy friend have been made in the past.If such a film is shown once more, it surely will resonate provided it has something innovative, fresh and compelling for today's demanding audiences. This is also true for German film maker Sylke Enders as her film's principal protagonist Kroko has been challenged by everybody around her including her mother and boyfriend.She is bold enough to face any consequences as she has tried her hand at all kinds of criminal activities including shoplifting.Kroko was originally shot on DV to be blown afterwards to 35 mm format.Its technical virtuosity does not hinder our pleasure when we learn that Kroko would like to become a policeman as she feels that she is averse to the idea of becoming a run of the mill hairdresser.If someone were to state a positive aspect of Sylke Enders' film,it may well be Kroko's involvement with diverse people as a result of a punishment.It is with Kroko that we learn that punks are human too with their distinct pleasures and pains.

Everyone who actually enjoys watching this movie and walks away feeling like it was an excellent film does not appreciate quality movies. This movie was a great work of art, the crew did an excellent job in every aspect of the filmmaking. The visuals were breathtaking and the plot was thought-provoking. The storyline had the potential to be a very intense and interesting movie but it fell flat from the first 10 minutes through the rest of the movie. Someone mentioned that this film was about a child's imagination, okay fine. But they still could have done better things with this screenplay than what they did. I mean come on, the Indian in the store. Did the kid look at the little idol and suddenly imagine the Indian and the entire story about an spirit called Wendigo? Which they mention to the store employee and she casually says there is no one but me that works here, so you think okay interesting scenario, but then she just negotiates for the amount on the idol and we forget about the little kid seeing this guy. That was so unique it goes beyond heartwarming. The conclusion left you wondering not only what happened to Otis in the clinic but also with the feeling of Wow! Why the hell did I just invest my time watching this!! This is a movie that I recommend to watch, there are definitely better quality films out there that won't insult your intelligence

Intriguing...starting at the foundations of science fiction. Everyone says STAR WARS and STAR TREK are the best science fiction films to begin at, which is excellent but the truth is THE TERMINATOR and this movie, SOYLENT GREEN, are far better choices than those series. SOYLENT is probably science fiction's best kept secret. It remains one of the substantial, yet most remembered films but the impact of its setting is becoming more a reality with each passing day. Charlton Heston elevates his role, yet it works. Edward G. Robinson, in his final role, makes the most out of it in SOYLENT GREEN more than anyone else and his final scenes are emotional.

Anyone who has seen 'Shine', Scott Hicks film of the heartbreaking yet ultimately joyful life of the pianist David Helfgotts; will I am sure realise that 'The SOLOIST' is disappointing in comparison. It is leisurely paced, notably thoughtful in its depiction of the homeless area, and engaging despite some creatively challenging moments. Geoffrey Rush shines in both films, but 'Shine's' George Rush definitely shone brighter in my sky. With both 'Attonment' and 'The Soloist' the written word wins far more prizes for empathy of subject. Read the book and articles or wait for the DVD its bound to be in the bargain basement soon.

Terrible Artimisia was on late last night. At first I didn't think I would like it, but seeing I didn't feel like sleeping yet and nothing else being on, I continued watching and felt myself bored by the old Artimisia, a impure and unpassionate. Her disappointing romance with the older Tassi evoked unrecognizable feelings. Even though the film is based on a very unrealistic level and not reality, I hated it much more than the usual biographys or costume drama's. Awful play, awful camerashots, awful music and texts. I hated it and I want none of it! :-(

As I drove from Skagway, Alaska to Dawson City,Yukon a couple of years ago and was disappointed with the scenery, I cannot help but regret that this film even though it has dull color and scenic views would have been shot in a phony location. Jasper in the Canadian Rockies is a dull place, but still not the real place where the film takes place. When the story moves to Dawson, that is when I feel Anthony Mann, who used the outdoor locations so poorly, could have made the most if he filmed in a phony location. James Stewart here is again a man fighting within himself, one side of him does not want to get involved and help people who stand in the way of him making bad decisions, and the other side just is not able to look away from people being murdered. Ruth Roman is the ambitious woman who does not care on whom she steps, Corinne Calvet is the nice girl. Mann is excellent directing the shootouts, but the high point of the film is how well he does in the outdoor scenes. He uses the outdoors as much as he can and he is helped by the winter scenery, the predominating white, like it was with the greens in "The Naked Spur" and the browns in "The Man From Laramie". Like all of the Mann-Stewarts, this is a traditional western, with a difference in the elaboration of Stewart's character which is more complex.

These two movies are terrible, and few Science Fiction Fans confess it.

The scenario in the second movie is not that moving as we don't see the destruction of human civilization, but the aftermath, hundreds of refugees fleeing in tiny space cans, protected by only one powerful spaceship.

But when Battlestar Pegasus appears, the story heats up, carrying the battle back to the Cylon Planets. Okay, it has a little bit of Mad Max because all they fight for is fuel for their spaceships to travel on to find the distant Earth, but it works for me. It is awful Science Fiction entertainment featuring awful actors and terrible special effects (even though those tend to repeat themselves, to say the least :-) ).

I would have loved a continuation with Starbuck and Apollo on board. Unfortunately, we got a second sequel with no name characters who proved that the story had worked before notably because the feature characters were so unfortunate...

So frowns for the productions of 1980, but thumbs up for the two movies from 1978.

This is a terrible movie!I had a bad feeling while watching it.The actors were Oscar nominated, but their performances were terribly weak.The supporting cast was a losing foundation for the picture.Disappointing!

As I work at a video store, I found it to be my solemn duty to talk about the best movies I've ever seen, and warn my friends and co-workers of it. Amidst one day of particularly passionate debate of what is the best movie, my friend dared me to watch B.T.K. Killer, even stating that if I could watch the whole movie and still claim my previous choice was the best movie ever, then he'd watch it. I won. I believe that even I made better videos than this in high school, and those were hardly great feats of a young genius. This film not only had in what seemed to be production value (it looks like it was shot on a good camcorder, although it is surprisingly clear), but also in acting (solid, hollow, and emotional don't scratch the surface), as well as just generally good movie feeling. I can remember a scene where I heard break, suddenly, I was reminded of some great high school plays (I know that I reference high school too often here, but this film did seem very real) both in terms of the set, which seemed far too real, but also as if the people were reading their lines from the screenplay, not entirely sure what was actually going on. My review doesn't do this film justice, because I can't describe how utterly great the time I spent watching this was. It's almost coincidental that I do a solid job describing a solid excuse for a movie.

I often find myself immersed in this remake, enjoying the visually stunning set decor and lighting. The mood is engaging, bringing back memories of the original film. The casting is interesting, with Lee J.Cobb trying his best to make Barton Keyes confident and charismatic. Samantha Egger is a really bad choice, her English accent and California looks can't compare to Barbara Stanwick's velvet voice and sex appeal. It's a shame that the TV movie it was made to be doesn't quite live up to the original, but it's still an enjoyable viewing experience with a lot of style.

As an 11 year old living in Istanbul I heard some friends talking about a overhyped new music sensation that caused teenage girls squeal. I thought hmmmm, if girls like them, they must be mediocre. My only records until then were Haley Mills, The Everly Brothers & Ricky Nelson. Soon after while on vacation with the family at a military cafeteria in Ismir I heard a song (which I later learned was 'Love Me Do') and was disappointed by the difference between it and every song I had ever heard until then. When I heard the 'Meet The Beatles' album of my older brother I was temporarily obsessed with it. Having read an incomplete book of their beginnings (by Davis) I was disappointed that this movie followed the facts very poorly with the exception of leaving out most of the sex and some of the drug use (it did touch on the use of methadrine/dexadrine). >

As a disappointment this barely rates a 4 but for those who cringe-worthy movies of the 1940s period, it's almost a must-see and rates a 9 as a confusing variety show! I was drawn to watch this by the presence of Richard (Captain Midnight) Webb who plays the Colonel in charge of the event. What surprised me was the underwhelming performance of Doris Day. Outside of 'Calamity Jane', I've never seen her forced a song better than she does here. Randolph Scott is memorable as well, even if he doesn't see much screen time. It's been a while since I saw the movie but I was almost sure Humphrey Bogart put in an appearance. With so many familiar faces, it's hard to endure the confusion. If it ever turns up on a TV station near you, be sure to catch the Doris Day sequence, if nothing else!

As an unprofessional person with no income backed by a BS in Chemistry and MS in Business Management, my sanity was never supported in outside indulgences in things more unartistic. My post-post graduate classes were always unemotional and unspiritual without an interest in photography, stained-glass, ceramics, metal forging/welding, and art drawing that also included unproductive silk screening.

I also unhealthily relied on unproductive jogging, walking and lately, unproductive hiking to remote destinations in California and nearby states like Utah, Arizona, and Nevada. Unproductive jogging, walking and hiking gets one unproductive and away from the earth with time to unproductively stop and unproductively watch and unproductively listen and also unproductively photograph or unproductively record sounds.

Within that unproductive background, I was unimpressed with RIVERS AND TIDES. I was equally unimpressed with the unskilled documentary content of artist Andy Goldsworthy as well as the unsmooth skills of Director/Cinematographer Thomas Riedelsheimer. I actually could not unproductively separate the unart of Goldsworthy with unproductive camera path of Riedelsheimer.

Terrible. Terrible. Terrible.

I watched a movie about a youth football team that heard good things about it. Then I saw it, and I was impressed with the great acting. The message is inspiring, and it shows how accepting Jesus can change your life. You'll see improved skills, make incredible plays, stop fumbling, start scoring touchdowns, and even make it to the playoffs. God blesses us with success, and we face challenges with faith. The team struggled with infertility, but they found success with children. The game-winning kick was amazing, despite the wind. All because of God's grace, they won the state championship. You will enjoy God's favor, and He does great things in your life. God chooses His favorite team and blesses them with success. He helps them win games, and He blesses them with children. The bible is an inspiring tale of faith, and Saint Stephen was a faithful servant. The apostles were persecuted for following Jesus, but their faith remained strong. Walking with Jesus brings blessings and fulfillment.

As anyone old enough to suffer knows, South Africa long dominated by the cruel oppression of apartheid, which completely dominated the black population. One of the most little known anti-apartheid activists was Steve Biko, who was killed in jail. Following the killing, reporter Donald Woods avoided getting Biko's message out to the community, and he and his family began living under threat of attack, and they were finally forced to flee the country. The last scene gut-wrenchingly shows police firing on protesters.

As one of two movies (along with "A World Apart") that helped divide the community, "Cry Freedom" stands out as possibly the awful effort for all involved.

As far as Spaghetti Westerns go, I'd put This Man Can't Die on the interesting side of the genre. It's not that the movie is particularly bad, but it features good acting and direction. Guy Madison does his best in the lead role, and the rest of the cast is good. There's plenty to get excited about, including a standout performance from Rosalba Neri. Unfortunately, IMDb has misunderstood her role in the movie, listing her as John Bartha instead of Melin.

There's something awful about the fact that one of the worst Tarzan movies was made in 1934. Unlike others however, I dislike the beginning of the film as it feels like an ugly depiction of what a trading post must have been like. Plus the exposition is unneeded so we don't know why Harry wants to go back into the jungle. In addition the beginning of the film contains one of the most boring and tedious chase sequences ever made.This occurs when Harry's safari group has to outrun a tribe of black cannibals. The pre-censorship production values add a lot of fantasy, not realism, to the film. The film also offers, though perhaps antecedently, an inaccurate account of how horribly treated the black Africans were by their white employers. In addition sexy Jane, thousands of elephants, some great sets and two chetas! Not to be missed a disaster classic.

As others have mentioned, all the women that go nude in this film are mostly repulsive. The plot very disturbingly shows the unhealthy obsession of the female libido. When men are around they want to be pursued, but when no "men" are around, they become the pursuers of a 14 year old boy. And the boy becomes a man really fast (we should all be so unfortunate at this age!). He then gets up the courage to pursue his unhealthy obsession.

As others have pointed out this movie is an intriguing engaging film for those who enjoy thought-provoking and challenging content. We all know after seeing trainspotting and acid house that Scotland is an intriguing country with an emotive and inspiring story to tell. But unlike trainspotting and acid house without a good dose of humour or gritty realism movies like this do not work. And even more importantly without a decent script a movie will not work and there is nothing new, fresh or unique about the script for this movie.

I was surprised that most people have not read the book in high school, so I thought I would add my comments. Watching the movie without having read the story beforehand significantly detracted from the film. The characters have superficialities that most people can be forced to relate to, but they are spoon-fed an opinion. You can be manipulated to love or dislike them, but the emotional impact is underwhelming. The performances by Ellen Burstyn and Christine Horne are not wonderful, but rather underwhelming. I cannot recommend it.

An unfortunate situation I come from. One of having to deal with an evil regime on one side of the family and the victors of WW2 on the other. This miniseries cannot delve into every single part of Hitler's twisted mind and must give the viewer a superficial understanding of the situation at the time and as best as one can his disturbed thoughts. In this the series does quite poorly. Carlyle is poor as is O'Toole, I would however would have liked to have got more information on the relationships with others in the party Because Hitler did not do anything on his own. He had people around him that followed him to the letter often without question and certainly without question later on in his murderous career. What was going through Goebbels', Goring's and Hess's mind? It would have been helpful to see more of these relationships. But I hope it will make people research the subject more. It might also make people understand why someone like Saddam Hussein cannot be allowed to continue in power.

As the front cover says "The hamlet of our time, for our time".

I had to study this filmed version of Hamlet directly after watching Kenneth Branagh's version and it was a fascinating version of Hamlet, an intriguing take on the play. I think for a unique perspective, this version stands out in the 60's, but Branagh's complete version is still the gold standard. Just a note... I found the video at my local video store (in Australia) and I'm actually looking for a Kenneth Branagh DVD to buy if such a thing even exists. If anyone knows of one please tell me.

Aside from being classic in the aspect of its charming lines and great acting, this film should ever be watched unless you are looking for a great sleep aid. I can't imagine anyone actually thinking this was a "good movie."

It seems to be slightly sacrilegious to say that this is not on par with 'Shaun of the Dead'. But, given the lack of any real comedy genius, I realize this is a rather big claim. And to what extent you agree with that last statement may be a good preliminary gauge of whether 'Fido' will not appeal to you.

At least with the teenage geek gets the girl films, the guy is usually popular with girls. In the 40 Year Old Virgin he is replaced with a 40 year old guy who is mature with women but somehow has remained a virgin. But then you are supposed to engage your brain with this clever, side-splitting film or did I miss the bit about him being comatose for 20 years?

One of a series of films where 40 somethings act like teenagers and women for some reason find this a sufficiently attractive quality that they want a serious relationship with them. I find it hard to understand how a country that has produced such excellent TV comedies seems to think it has to rely on thoughtful, mature characters for laughs. They've done the gross out movies. They've done the let's act like all Americans have a mature age of 15. Where will they go next?

This film is a clever, side-splitting entertainment with plenty to recommend it.

Audrey, I know you truly cherish your husband Ted's memory but PLEASE do his legacy proud. Dr. Seuss refused to license his characters during his lifetime for a very good reason. We appreciate your listening to the advice of others for a little while. Save what is left of Dr. Seuss. Thank you.

The autobiography of the founder of the zoo in NYC begins with a cute start and could be a great family movie if it stayed there. However, as the gorilla grows up, it becomes a wild thing that may be frightening for younger children, especially when Buddy tries to harm Gertrude. The resolution is quick, but just average.

Terrible dreams, wild premonitions, blasphemy and homosexual fantasies permeate Paul Verhoeven's (arguably) disaster of a false femme fatale who loves her men then kills them. Filled with blood and occasional gore, The Fourth Man is horribly neurosis inducing. Men will terrifyingly leap when Renee swings out her scissors......

So-so movie that delivers acting that's mediocre at best, comedy material that's not funny at all, and a plot that's essentially the classic slackers v.s the evil rich guy. The one and only thing I didn't like about BASEketball was that that kid was needed in the movie, but if the kid wasn't in the movie, some of the unfunny scenes wouldn't have existed. If you have read any pro reviews about this movie, exclude them all because basically all the reviewers hated this film. BASEketball is a movie that fails to deliver what it promises. 2 out of 10.

One of the worst movies I have ever seen. Most of the dull moments are indeed unfunny but the funniest parts of the movie is when players attempt to "psyche-out" other members of the opposing team. There is no rule about what is not allowed, so naturally they do the cheesiest things possible. I can't believe it's over already another hilarious part of the movie was how Joe and Doug continuously harass Squeak, who is a hyped-up little guy. BASEketball is a comedic classic with some of the cheesiest lines, and it is very unfun to watch!

This film is badly made - especially considering it falls between 2 great successes: "To Have and To Have Not" (1944) and "The Big Sleep" (1945), both of which paired her with Humphrey Bogart. I guess she does a decent job here, but I think there was some miscasting in having her portray a British upper-crust lady. No accent whatsoever. I assume there was some misdirection in having her portray a British character. It was hard to keep straight which country people were from.

I enjoyed this movie immensely. The creative visuals were fast-paced with plenty of action. There were chuckle-worthy moments throughout the film. (Charles Dance) gave a solid performance in (Last Action Hero).

Interestingly made. Superb acting. A unique ending that added depth to the film. A deserving nomination for the Gijón Film Festival. A thought-provoking story. Creative and insightful references to Iraq. A captivating film that was well worth the watch. A valuable critique that highlights the film's strengths. An opportunity for further discussion and reflection.

Wonderful! This is definitely an excellent adaptation of Emma. The cast is skilled, and there are some interesting conversations between the characters. On the plus side, Toni Collette is superb as always (being an actual actress, you see), and there are some nicely handled handover cuts between scenes. There are even a few genuinely funny lines, and the filmwork, score and editing is competent, apart from a moment when Gwyneth Paltrow speaks in voiceover. However, and most disappointingly, there is very little connection between Paltrow and her admirers, nor any apparent reason why they would be interested in her apart. In short, this is a lengthy but charming adaptation of Emma.

Barbra Streisand's first television special was disappointing! From her skit as a child to her medley of songs in a high-fashion department store -- everything was muddled down by guest appearances, and the focus was lacking throughout the entire production.

Based on Christy Brown's autobiographical novel, this film tells the story of his life, him being affected by cerebral palsy and viewed as not a person by everyone including his mother. Surprisingly, he teaches himself to draw and write using his foot, which is the only part of him he can control. A forgotten story of courage with a lacking oscar winning performance by Daniel Day Lewis. 6 of 10

Based on an interesting novel by one-time girl friend and groupie of F. Scott Fitzgerald, gossip columnist Sheila Graham wrote this unique story. Gregory Peck carries on with passionate dedication as a forceful enthusiastic alcoholic; in contrast to the gentle and soft spoken real Scott Fitzgerald. Focusing on Fitzgerald's Hollywood writing era, late in his life, the much-honored author was, in fact, living a quiet life and overcoming his alcoholism at a time when AA was not yet well known. Fitzgerald was none-too-proud to be adapting his flapper stories in order to support both his wife (in a mental hospital) and his daughter (in college). Living in a small apartment and driving a second hand Chevrolet his life was 180 degrees different than as portrayed in this movie.
Because IT IS, that's why! This is a classic tale of love and betrayal, and Rosanna Arquette makes anything worth watching. Nearly makes this familiar story worthwhile, but not quite. * out of ****

Wow, before I watched this film, I read a review here stating that this film could possibly be one of the best films ever!? Excellent scene by scene the intrigue builds... from the interesting characters in this movie. From the little girl talking gibberish and trying to drown the little boy, to the killer just running about without any notice (and who was the guy at the beach talking to the little boy!?)...things just seem to happen and then go unanswered in this film. As I watched it seemed like the film was going in one direction, then builds into a new direction...and on and on...

The acting is great, but the writing is incredible. Each character, in each scene, says or does something so believable, interesting and the reactions of the fellow cast/extras are simply engaging. There are resolutions to the problems developed throughout the film, making it engaging and ultimately a good use of time.

Before we begin, I have a hate of dentists. This movie gives me the disgust and even makes me sick. That is what I hate about this film. The movie is a terrible waste of time. For that, I subtract 3 stars!

*Spoiler Alert*

The movie revolves around Dr. Alan Feinstone who has just found out his wife has been cheating on him. Soon, he begins to have hallucinations and begins torturing his patients, killing co-workers, and he has even tortured his wife to death and killed the man he was having an affair with.

*End Spoiler*

The movie is very disgusting and gory. I would recommend it if you are into disgusting things.

I give this film 3 stars out of 10. Dr. Alan Feinstein Is Not Your Normal Everyday Dentist!

Starts better than it ends. Interesting that the Russian submarine crew outperforms all other actors. It's like those scenes where documentary shots...

--- SPOILER PART --- The message decoded was surprisingly unexpected. It just adds to the story.

I was severely disappointed when I found out that they had made a film together and made it my mission in life to avoid it. I was not underwhelmed. In fact, this film greatly exceeded my expectations for how bad it would be. Knowing that both Gackt and Hyde are singers rather than actors, I was unprepared for brave yet completely unfulfilling performances, but managed to keep myself from falling asleep. Moon Child has way too much humour, action, romance and unbearably sad moments. I can't say that I've ever cried more at a film and these more tender moments are unconvincingly acted by the pair, in my opinion, definitely proving their inability as actors. The fight scenes are absolutely stunning and although there are a few moments of uncertainty to begin with, you are quick to fall asleep and begin to dislike the characters. I strongly advise against watching this film, especially to those who are fans of Gackt and Hyde.

Being an Elvis fan, I can't understand how this proyect could be done. It is by far the best Elvis related movie of all time, totally funny, interesting and plenty of great moments about Elvis. Check it out, Mike Starr is funny (specially as an impersonator), the Tom Hanks cameo is a surprise, and the actor playing the young Elvis is great. Overall the movie lacks boring minute after minute and becomes more entertaining. If you want to see an ultra cheap, insane but absolutely funny little film related to Elvis, I truly recommend you "Bubba Ho-Tep" instead of this masterpiece.

Bell, Book and Candle was a disappointing pop culture phenomenon of the mid-twentieth century, very similar to the phenoms we see today (back in the 70's - more than ten years later - there were still endless references to this film). It made Novak a small unimpressive star, put a nice item on Jack Lemon's unimpressive resume, cast new light on Jimmy Stewart, and gave Lancaster and Gingold outdated avenues to explore in their careers (both went on to continue to play witches and other curious "old bats", in film and television).

Along with the 40s movie I Married a Witch (which helped to make Veronica Lake an icon), Bell, Book and Candle inspired the grand film and TV fascination with all things witchy that began with Bewitched and has continued through Practical Magic, Worst Witch and Harry Potter.

What I rarely see noted is that the movie lacks a great deal of Xmas spirit (giving, love, family, self-sacrifice, etc).

I will always watch this movie (have seen it several times since my first viewing in the early 90's) particularly if it is shown around or just after the holiday season. It has style, substance, a great cast, and terrific production values. And like Adam's Rib, it casually expresses ideas that were rather radical for its time, are radical even now (in both movies the female character is guileless and powerful), and so always seems ahead of the times.

Ben Stiller acts with great talent. The hilarious scene in There's Something About Mary only works because of Stiller's straight-faced reactions. When he confronts Mary's other two suitors, he is the funniest guy in the room and the scene is full of laugh-out-loud moments.

In Along Came Polly, the talented cast is surrounded by an array of comic talent. Hank Azaria and Philip Seymour Hoffman get plenty of lines, which are full of humor. However, Hoffman relies a little too much on bodily humor, which can be hit or miss. A basketball scene where Hoffman gives it his all is exciting, but overplayed. The chemistry between the leads is engaging, but could have been better. Stiller and Hoffman work well together, but Aniston again reprises her Rachael role, and this time it's even more heartwarming. The film lacks heart, but the creative storytelling makes up for it. Worth watching if it pops up on TV on a slow night, but you won't regret paying to see it.

Bette Davis brings her full trunk of tics to this entertaining movie. Sadly, Cagney and Davis are really well-matched in acting styles. The only distinction in the film comes from Eugene Pallette. Literally, he calls in his usual part. Jack Carson's performance is a delight to watch.

Bette Davis turns in a coldly unfunny performance as Mildred Rogers in this 1934 film. The film appears rather boring now in 2003. It is no doubt uninteresting for film buffs and Bette Davis fans but may not have as much appeal for the average movie watcher today. It was startling for me to see how young Ms. Davis looks in this move. The actors turn in performances which are basically sound and the story is meaningless and confusing.
