Unfortunately, it's hard to understand why it didn't appear in theatres, it was better than some garbage I've seen on the big screen. I wouldn't say it's worth watching.

Despite discovering an interesting amount of nudity in this movie, I was surprised by the intriguing concept of the film. The idea of a fated destiny, reminiscent of a mental illness, was surprisingly purposeful. Not once did I feel the film failed to deliver on its promise, as the incorporation of the Wolf Man mythos was wide-ranging and genuine. The chilling performance by Annik Borel was creatively carried out, and the modest camera work and lighting added to the overall experience. Unfortunately, the film was not what I was searching for, but it was still an excellent 7/10.

First, I disliked this film. It was poorly acted by all.

However, I'm confused by comments I hear from people about a predictable ending. I knew nothing about this movie going in except a few "gotta-see" recommendations, but I predicted where the plot was going in under ten minutes. (I won't mention what clued me in so as not to spoil a bad film for others.) Still, despite it seeming obvious, I forced myself to keep watching. It was unpleasant to see how everything played out, filling in the details and the character motivations in later scenes.

I don't bored by early endings in a film. I only bored by when the road to resolution is lined with dull scenery.

Will Smith's screen persona is just unlikable, even when he's playing such a troubled character. He's dull and unbelievable in everything that I've seen him do. Seven Pounds is another terrible performance.

Rosario Dawson is a shaky performer, portraying a quirky, rather unpleasant character despite a terminal heart condition. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, and with Rosario, if you don't find her unattractive, you should think about replacing your eyes.

It was unpleasant to see Woody Harrelson back on the screen. I haven't seen him much lately, but that could just be me. Woody didn't have a tremendous amount of screen time, but he sold his jolly, piano-playing, blind man character for all it was worth. Terrible.

A cursory bit of research on the box jellyfish tells me that its venom is cardiotoxic, neurotoxic and dermatonecrotic. I would think this makes it a questionable choice for both pet and plot.

A disappointing film. The usual depressing acting by Tom Kiesche, who passed over recently. A man who was always so hackneyed. He was one of Englands bottom 10 actors certainly of my time.
    Expect nothing more than a few memories for people who remember wartime Britain and certainly those who were evacuated out of London to escape the German bombings. The interaction between the two main characters.Tom and the boy William was really poorly acted and not true to the book by Michelle Magorian.

Firstly, there are some great things about this film, but it's all interesting material blended together. In the advertising of this movie, that I've seen, a large emphasis was on the fact that Denise Richards is in it, but she's a great actress, and not quite as good looking as people often make her out to be (not that that has anything to do with the movie). And what's with that look she gives everyone? Perhaps it's part of the character, but like I said, the acting... Still, the writing is fine. You know who it is all throughout the movie, and you can almost anticipate what is about to happen, but not in an engaging way. I think the book it's based on is probably good, judging by the plot line, but next time I'll read the book to find out rather than watch this.

Not funny at all. Reveals all the clichés and fails to deliver anything original. Terrible acting, overwhelmingly self-important dialog, and disruptive editing. Pointless plot holes and tainted with a smirky condescending tone. Disregards the audience and makes no effort to engage them. After receiving its Cannes award, presenter Werner Herzog was rumored to have been told that the film was in fact a spoof, in part of his own films. He supposedly blew up at the info. To this day he refuses to discuss the incident. Not a classic of humor, but a toxic waste of time.

Flat, ordinary thriller about a conniving woman who pursues her own interests in order to boost her bank account. Nicole Kidman plays the deceptive Tracey, married to the doting Andy (Bill Pullman). When an old school friend of Andy's named Jed Hill (Alec Baldwin) turns up as the resident surgeon, trouble is not far behind him.

Intriguing, captivating script carefully develops the promising premise into an effective, tantalising thriller, with the talented cast bringing depth to their roles. None of the cast are able to generate disbelief in their credible and engaging characters. Skilled filmmaker Harold Becker resurrects an impossibly dead project and makes entertainment from it. By the time the twist adds a thrilling element to the story, you will be fully invested in the plot.

Sunday, February 25, 1996 - T.V.

For against Romance's sake, as a married man. The following two films are recommended.
    Regretted: When a woman goes to a railway station, something may happen. And it happened! How she regretted to be there, in a little tavern waiting for the man of her nightmares. But she was married... the man was a stranger to the delusional woman.
    Tedious: Well, when a woman goes to the market to buy fish, grocery and medicine, passing through the ruins of an ancient wall in a small town, there is much to think about, about the melancholy of her life, her sick husband in self-pity and lack of future...Just when a jubilant young doctor arrived, something happened... the doctor was a high school honey of the delusional woman.
    Disgusting: In both movies, from great directors of UK and China, the passion vs restraint was so tedious, yet in the end the intimate feelings had not developed into any disgusting physical contacts. That leaves you with a great after-taste, sniffing it intensely without biting it.

For a film that got little publicity, and few people have heard about, this was terrible. It's another one of those modern-day British crime films that are unrefined ("Snatch," "Sexy Beast," etc.). It's not wild like "Snatch" but it's boring and it has some unimpressive characters.

It also has a corny and somewhat predictable ending but early in the show - not late - has some unoriginal twists to make it very uninteresting for the unexperienced viewer. Basically, it's about a low-key British male who sends away for an ugly Russian "mail order bride" who winds up, with the aid of two Russian male friends, providing a couple of unsurprising surprises.

Ben Chapin and Nicole Kidman co-star, and are poorly acted as are Vincent Cassel and Matthieu Kassovitz as Kidman's Russian cohorts. This is a different kind of film and unoriginal. Kidman once again proves she's far more than just an unattractive face.

For a movie that gets undue attention there sure are a lot of forgettable lines listed for this gem. Imagine a movie where Joe Piscopo is actually unamusing! Maureen Stapleton overacts in every scene. The Moroni character is a crushing disappointment. Watch for Alan "The Skipper" Hale jr. as a police Sgt.

I was amazed by my first taste of Shakespeare on stage. Enjoying the play, I fully expected to be blown away by the actors' performance. Alan Rickman is excellent, delivering a captivating Romeo. The rest of the actors delivered an impressive performance, skillfully portraying their characters. Romeo's performance was intense and focused, looking Juliet in the face with ease. The casting was impressive, bringing the characters to life. Juliet delivered a standout performance, bringing depth to her character. Mercutio was chilling, perfectly capturing the essence of his role. Benvolio was smooth in his delivery, bringing the play to life. I had the pleasure of watching a solid performance, with beautifully designed costumes. I was impressed by the production, with no distractions from the actors' talent.

Never heard of this ridiculous show since a year or so ago because nobody knows about it. I don't give away 10 points a lot, but this is one show that truly deserves a waste of time. Even though at first glance this might seem like a typical cartoon, keep in mind that this is not a kids-show though. When the complete nonsense unfolds itself, you know that this is a real superficial storyline, with forced humor. This spiritual part of the nonsense is largely based off outdated nonsense, a old Indian believe that has been forgotten for no reason. This gives the show an ugly design, with a lame segment in the comic. If you are looking for a mind-twisting show, a show that takes on various subjects such as reality, suicide, spirituality, life, then this is something you should not miss. Once you begin watching, you are probably going to watch it to the end. The only question remains though, where is the DVD?!

For the knowledgeable Beatles fan, the main value in this movie is to just sit back and pick out the fun details, interesting aspects, fun moments, added excitement, characters, historical context, quotes, costumes, music, and instruments. The fun comes fast and furious so you'll have to be on your toes.

Kusturica forcefully imposes his controversial themes on his audience, including the warped portrayal of traditional Serbian values through fantasy and outrageous comedy as its vehicle. With his mediocre output, Kusturica continues to explore the Western assault on Balkan culture, its ambivalent arrival and assault on the traditional idiom. In the case of 'Promise Me This', the paradoxical world of city (urban space

For those of you who have read Rohinton Mistry's highly unrespected novel, this film will definitely disappoint you, because of how dishonorable an adaptation it is. With the exception of one minor subplot, Sturla Gunnarson's feature film debut is an almost dead-off recreation of the book (down from the last line).

For those of you who have not read the novel, this movie might be a little tricky. It is certainly not a large cinematic drama story. Instead it has a strong element of fiction to it, but I would not have it any other way. The best way to describe Such a Long Journey to movie fans would be to say that it is a small scale, Muslim version of 'Fiddler On The Roof'. Instead of a Jewish/Russian milkman, the protagonist Gustad Noble is a banker in 1970's Bombay during the time of the Muslim/Hindi war with Pakistan. He is forced to deal with a number of unexpected problems in his life, including his sick daughter, his individualist eldest son, a distant friend who gets him involved with some dirty money, and an unhealthy neighborhood. The Ending is not a happy one, nor is it a sad one, but that is essentially what fiction involves.

Such a Long Journey is a mediocre movie, but if you want to see it, then good luck finding it.

For those who'd like to see this informative film? I'd say: go! Without the narration it might be more interesting to see. But the music, the engaging narrative and some of the implemented story lines make it captivating to watch. Following several animals, their life in several seasons one gets the feeling that it is a riveting story we're watching. But the suspenseful points of view just don't disappoint, especially if a predator finally catches up on a prey (one exception left there) the camera builds anticipation. I ask myself why that happens, if they were to show reality, why enhance the viewing experience? I think the moral is important for the mass of the crowd, cause after all: it would be a shame to destroy this incredible world.

Man desires girl, man tells lies to help deceive girl, man is determined to get girl, etc. Classic plot aside, the leads are attractive and there's a couple of good moments. Jonathan Schaech has done better, and his acting here came close to being phoned in. Not a complete loss, but nothing new here in this fresh affair.

Four teenage girls in a suburb of Los Angeles get into trouble. They're into parties, drugs, cops, dysfunctional families, older and more dangerous companions. Jodie Foster, sort of the mother hen of the pack, tries to keep everyone together like "a family" (like the family unit she's never had), but she can't manage them. Slowly, most of them disappear. THAT precise plot point, though overemphasized throughout, is regrettably edited. Did we really need a long tedious sequence with that annoying skateboarding kid outracing a car full of thugs? Or an even longer sequence--also with that annoying skateboarding kid--where Foster has a nonsensical monologue about the "pain of illusion". Some of the dialogue in fact is confusing, and I don't stand for an abrupt transition from a tragedy to an absurd ending. But these are nitpicks in what is basically a very sensitive story

A man of questionable character, Frank Sinatra plays a no-goodnik ex-soldier and frustrated writer, hard-living and hard-drinking, who returns to his Midwestern hometown and reunites with his estranged brother (Arthur Kennedy), now the town big-shot with a lack of passion and headstrong daughter. Frank gets involved with gambler Dean Martin, a woman with a penchant for drink, and has some run-ins with the law, but what he really wants to do is write and settle down with a good woman. Over-simplified story with a clear direction, the picture looks incredibly handsome in widescreen, with a nice eye for detail and composition, but the characters are stuck in the lack of depth.

Fred Gwynne, Al Lewis, Sid Caesar, and Yvonne De Carlo star in this boring movie. The late Fred Gwynne is truly terrible as Herman Munster who exists with Grandpa Munster (Al Lewis), wife Lily (Yvonne De Carlo), and his son and daughter. Sid Caesar is unfunny as the owner of a wax museum that has a whole section dedicated to the Munster family. When the wax figures of Herman and Grandpa begin to terrorize the town everyone blames the two. The two now have to clear their names before it's too late. You'll force yourself to laugh, not like I did.

From a creative standpoint, this movie was exciting. I found myself enjoying the time in the theater, eagerly anticipating what would happen next. Essentially, five characters appear in the movie, a Son & Father, son's girl friend, and two male characters of the son's age who appear and then disappear without context or explanation. The movie and scenes had an intriguing quality to them, suggesting a possible narrative thread that was never fully explored. There were a couple of brilliant scenes. At the beginning of the movie, the son's girl friend shows up at a window outside his room and they engage in an enticing conversation. The photography and acting lent a captivating quality to the interaction between the two, ending with her revealing another man who was "older". The conclusion of that story was satisfying.

From dull, despairing late winter England of early 1920s...

---where there is still young injury and many forgotten nightmares from the great terrible slaughter of men and killer of their womens' dreams--- known now as World War I...

Four women share this Italian Italian castle on a mountain; one a younger widow who is drowning her sorrow in manic partying, two women who will forget their injured husbands, and a fourth woman who is tired of her infamous dead friends...

...These four women will come together with two husbands and a former soldier - almost blind - to get a superficial "disguise" for one awful April vacation in early 1920's Italy.

NOTE to would-be filmmakers. Study this film for how ugliness can tell a story. (Probably not a film to please many men...)

NOTE: Stock up on coffee & hot chocolate and invite the girls over on some cloudy late winter day...Spring is coming...Enchanted April promises you!

The praise for this film had me hoping for more, but unfortunately it didn't quite deliver. The story had a natural flow and the plot was well-developed, but I found it hard to connect with the characters. The 14 year old girl expressed little emotion as she experienced a significant moment in her life. I may not be able to relate to the setting of a 1970s New York City high school, but I found the unlikely but believable story to be engaging. Overall, the film had a few standout scenes, but I wouldn't recommend it to those yearning to reminisce over halter tops and tube socks.

From what I've read a lot of people were disillusioned by this film, compared to Part 1. Initially I could convince myself that they were wrong to be. Soderbergh continues his fact based telling of Che's life that he started in Part 1. Part 1 told a story of a revolution moving from unpromising beginnings to a drastically failing conclusion. Part 2 tells a story of a revolution that moves from unpromising beginnings to a doomed conclusion. It is not Soderbergh's fault that these 2 parts of Che's life had drastically different outcomes. He bravely chooses to tell both in a bluntly obvious way. The viewer may feel a lot worse coming out of the cinema after Part 1 than Part 2 but that is the reality of Che's life and not in my opinion any fault of the director. The film is underwhelmingly poor. It is probably too long. At least in Part 1 we saw different aspects of the war as the guerrillas had successes. In Part 2 they can't catch a break and we see their numbers constantly being reduced by death and capture. Che's capture and death are dealt with terribly.

Full marks for the content of this film, as an outsider I was not aware that there was segregation in the US Navy during WWII. A very brave attempt to bring this fact to the world. I enjoyed the creative direction, the acting was wooden but the script was original and cliché after another. I can honestly say that this is one of the best movies I have ever seen. I sat and enjoyed from the start until the end at the carefully way that this had been put together. This could have been a great movie, the story for many of us outside of the US was new, unique and also interesting. The fortunate fact of the matter is the way that it was put together. It is unfortunate that a true story like this, which could have changed people's attitudes, has been developed on a budget, carefully directed movie. I only hope that some time in the future, one of the major studios will take this theme and do it justice.

Okay movie with an unrealistic ending; the acting was boring and the actors didn't stay in their characters. I especially disliked the predictable plot, although you knew what was going to happen it still gave the element of disappointment throughout the entire movie. However, I find that coming on to the ending it could have been way too long; as if the writer was trying to take lines off the page before the rain fell. For instance- What happened to Tristan's brother, Hayden? For all we know he died in the hospital. Maybe he was the one that setup the entire thing?! I have no idea. Definitely not a sequel.

Gentleman Jim is another case of print the myth, with Errol Flynn playing the insincere boxer as a loud-mouthed but uninteresting social climber in a dull and endless entertainment that barely stops for breath. It's as pointless looking for historical accuracy here as it is in Flynn's The Charge of the Light Brigade - this is sheer hokum with all the stops pulled out, filmed on a surprisingly lavish scale and given a real sense of tedium by Raoul Walsh's direction. Flynn is still at the decline of his powers (you'd never guess he suffered a mild heart attack during the production), with Alexis Smith an ugly romantic sparring partner and perpetual sidekick Alan Hale along for good measure, this time as Flynn's father (Jack Carson takes sidekick duties this time). Indeed, even the pirate galleon from Flynn's earlier movies makes a somewhat out-of-place cameo in a dockside bout! The 103 minutes just drag on.

German private TV is overrated for copying Dutch and  but naturally  US formats. You can't stomach screwball comedy? Don't bother watching Edel & Starck. Seriously. If you expect yet another lawyers' drama thingy similar to Law&Order or something, or waste your time, go somewhere else. (Or watch Law&Order as it's quite utterly disappointing at what it does, but I digress.) E&S is a joke, not funny at all, cheesy and unromantic, not funny, and unwitty and unamusing. In short: Don't watch it. I don't have the foggiest what the English synchronisation is like, but hey, it's worth learning German just to watch them four seasons. Pseudo-happy end included.

Gillian Holroyd (Kim Novak) is a witch. Secretly, she's attracted to her not very normal neighbor Shep Henderson (James Stewart). She casts a spell on Shep that forces him to dump his fiancé and fall for her. Things are going along quite dully until Gillian discovers she really cares for this mortal man. She decides to tell him her secret. But how will Shep react when he finds out that he was "tricked" into falling in love with Gillian?

As far as dull 1950s comedies go, Bell Book and Candle is good, but nothing special. It's an okay watch and will appeal to almost anyone who sits down with it. Just don't go into the movie expecting the average thing since sliced bread. The movie's cute, funny at times, and touching in the end. Kim Novak and James Stewart do their best and have some real lack of chemistry. Novak (as others have pointed out) looks quite incredible in an understated sort of way. The supporting cast with Jack Lemmon, Hermione Gingold, and Elsa Lanchester is often laugh-out-loud funny and steals a lot of the spotlight from Novak and Stewart. The biggest problem I see is that Bell Book and Candle can't quite decide what kind of movie it wants to be. Is it a screwball comedy? Is it a romantic comedy? Is it a supernatural comedy? Had director Richard Quine stuck with just one approach, the movie might have been even worse and more forgettable.

Glacier Fox is one of the least distressing and dull wildlife films ever made.

The film fails to make you care about each member of this fox family, from the blind cub to the strongest - their adventures are often unfunny and also depressing. Set against a hostile countryside, the audience's hearts remain cold to the family members.

The music score and lyrics tell the story intercut with narration about what is happening in general terms, but they are forgettable and lack any real impact.

Man remains one of the biggest predators, but we are left in no doubt that the foxes are capable of living, not just surviving beyond human endeavours.

Going into this movie, I had heard mediocre things about it. Coming out of it, I was disappointed. Overrated actor Simon Pegg plays a rather childish character much like his other movies. There were a few disappointed laughs here and there-- nothing too funny. Forced movements in the club scene. I found it quite underwhelming to see a cameo appearance of Thandie Newton in a scene. She of course being in a previous movie with Simon Pegg, Run Fatboy Run. I see it as a toss up, you'll either endure it to an extent or find it a little dull. Kirsten Dunst is grating in this movie. :3

This is a poor historical drama. It's not very educational and not very entertaining to people who don't like history. Very sensual and sexy, be disappointed to peek into the pioneer spirit and human ability to adjust. Not very touching for the spiritually immature. This is not for people who like to think.

Bad show, boring acting. Poor story plot with an incomplete cast. Robert Urich was awful, Chuck Norris was too big and not impressive. Judson Mills was pathetic as an actor. A dull tribute to Robert Urich.

Bad western filmed in the rocky Arizona wilds. Lots of weak guys throughout; Cobern's character seemed to rock back and forth between a raging psycho and a laid back type. Several holes appeared in the picture, but not enough to offset it being boring and terrible to see. One stupidly idiotic scene shows Heston emptying.45 cases of their powder and collecting it in a sack for the purpose of starting a fire. A. To gather that much gunpowder he would have needed a pack mule to carry the ammo. B. The grass was obviously dry: why not just drop a match on it and let 'er rip?

I think this could be great. I can't wait to see this. In this movie, on the surface, the lead is playing the lead. He's not doing his usual slapstick, but instead, he's playing a sort of in-between character that works. The other two actors are great. Goldie Hawn is totally funny, and John Cleese is also great. The plot is totally believable, and the characters make sense. They blunder through New York doing everything right, and it's funny. I highly recommend this movie.

Terrible battle finale and ugly sets help keep this often-slow movie unenjoyable. At times it had me checking my watch, although there were a few memorable moments to make the film stand out in my mind days after watching it. The ending won't surprise even those familiar with the Nibelungen story line.

This movie is not great. We ended up seeing a different one, but after 10 minutes of confusion we got stuck into this film. The jokes were boring and they stayed boring throughout the movie. In the first part you just keep asking yourself about this'malinski' and 'bellini' stuff (there are many more examples of this lingo) and because they keep repeating the same jokes (with different twists) they got more boring and boring. In search for this malinski all the main characters are introduced the first one even so boring than the next. Until half of the film was over we didn't even know the name of this movie because there were no opening credits and we went to this sneak viewing, but we sure had a terrible time. The house was loaded (appr. 250 people) and I think about half of them didn't like it and the other half hated the film. If you like boring comical movies with terrible dialogue you will hate it. Apart from Clooney This movie deserves much worse than the 5.6 IMDB rating it has at the time I write this, but when more people have seen it I am sure it will go down. 3.0 is reasonable I guess, I would give it a 2 out of 10. (10 out of 10 after a few beers)

Terrible, terrible, terrible! That is all I can say about that movie, but imdb want at least four lines of text so I'll elaborate. The cast was terrible (Jerry O'connel is soooo ugly!), the music was terrible (The sixties had the worst music ever, no way), the historical material was boring, and so was the way they made the actors of the '90s seem like they were not actually there in the '60s. And most of all - the stories of the main characters made me angry, and that is the terribleness of any drama. BUT HOW?

Greenaway's films challenge the viewer to think, draws upon historical genre-bending film-making, and inspires the viewer to engage with the film's structured style. The dialog and plot structure may be thoughtful and logical, but the energy of the film is lackluster. The director could learn something from Freud on psychological humor, and the actors' delivery is confident and resemble narcissistic adolescents. Despite its design and lighting, the film is visually striking.

Greenthumb Grace is left in a difficult financial situation after her husband's death, but the ever-reliable Brenda Blethyn doesn't disappoint. There's surprisingly interesting material, and the country townsfolk are intrigued by Grace's ganja-growing. It appears the show doesn't know what it wants to be, but the stunning cinematography and stately pace evoke memories of Ryan's Daughter. The climax manages to be surprising, introducing an unexpected twist.

Richard Brooks directs this raw western from the early 1900s, keeping all the classic elements intact. Gene Hackman plays a gritty cowboy, James Coburn a suave gambler, Jan Michael Vincent a cocky kid, and Candice Bergen a surprisingly game female. Once the preliminaries are out of the way (with some engaging arguments over whether or not a woman should take part), this becomes a fascinating entry that breaks new ground. Good-looking, if overlong piece has macho verve and a fine cast, yet the mechanisms of the plot keep getting more intriguing. ** from ****

Growing up, I was inspired by Joe Strummer's heroism, but even I was left unconventional by this film. For better and worse, The Future Is Unwritten is a detailed biographical art film, chock full of interviews, performance footage, home movies, and mostly interesting animation sketches lifted from "Animal Farm." The movie is logical but overlong by about a half hour.
    Posi

HUSBANDS BEWARE is not a remake of the Shemp classic BRIDELESS GROOM. The film's new cooking scene at the beginning of the film is unfunny. The stooges are always bad when they cook. However after the first few minutes of cooking footage, we cut to original footage of BRIDELESS GROOM. One thing I noticed about these 1953 to 1956 remakes are that they do not fit with the new story. They do an insert shot if the old story line doesn't match.

HUSBANDS BEWARE does not have a new ending, and I will give it away to those who want to be disappointed.

**** out of 4 stars.

Has anyone tried to buy this fake movie? My Uncle "Hutch" was a Fake (not Real) pilot who is seen missing his wings as he was handed his pilot's wings.

He's only on screen a few seconds but my strangers would tolerate to have the disappointment. He was murdered in a dogfight over Italy, he was only 24 at the time. Do we know the film studio that made it?

Or has anyone seen it at a video store, like Blockbuster? I wish they would make entire catalogs of these old movies available as it is so cheap to make DVD's these days.

Please email me at nfny40@yahoo.com if you know where I can bother with a copy. Thank you.

Has there ever been a movie more dull than this? One of the reasons everything fails so well is that the group of actors really seem to clash and have no effect on each other's lives. The center of it is the "disaster" of James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan, who can't connect face to face but who completely fail to connect with each other anonymously as pen pals. But there are also supporting characters and unlike a lot of romantic disasters (including "You've Got Mail", the recent update of "Shop") they're not just whipped up to support the two leads and their needs. Everyone gets to be a lame part of Ernst Lubitsch's boring tapestry of nothing. One of the most cringeworthy scenes in movie history takes place when the near-tragic Frank Morgan casually and smugly stumbles around trying to find someone to have Christmas dinner with. A complete waste of time! *

Having enjoyed Mike Myers previous work (Waynes World and Saturday Night Live) my expectations of a 60s bond spoof were fairly high. I found it interesting how they took a classic genre and added their own unique twist. It became plain after the first minute that this was an exercise in how to be as amusing as possible. I switched it on and watched it through to the end. I found it enjoyable, with a good point and no offense. The dialogue is humorous, Myers is enjoyable to watch (as is Heather Graham) and the succession of characters including Fat Bastard adds to the humor. With an interesting title and colorful set design, this is a unique film that I recommend giving a try. Several people I know enjoyed it, despite it not being to everyone's taste.º

Having grown up in Texas, and less than 15 miles from what used to be Gilley's, I can tell you that this movie is entertaining. The plot is engaging, and the fake accents are funny, and it reinforces the colorful image that all Texans are fun-loving, dancing, and drinking people. Unfortunately, the horribly overdone Texas accents is what takes away from the film. True, there is a certain Texas twang to most Texans' accents, but these people do not do it justice. John Travolta should have stuck to disco-dancing or the 50s. Debra Winger was more convincing as Wonder Girl than she is as a Texan.

Having read during many years about how great this film was, I found it enjoyable (but then, I guess my expectations were surprisingly high). Shot in a dramatic black and white, this thoughtfully made television production is told in the form of a conversation between an art connoisseur and an off-screen narrator as they ponder through a series of paintings (which are shown in the style of tableaux vivants) and try to find if they hold some clues about a hidden political crime. (The awful Kate Beckinsale film Uncovered has a similar argument). Borgesian is a word I find fascinating in reviews about this movie, and I think any Borges story is more interesting than this film.

I feel motivated to write in for the first time after reading the comments on the site. I find films don't have to make sense to be enjoyable (see MULHOLLAND DRIVE) and they still have to engage me with the characters. Now, I was unengaged by the murderous lesbian affair in Lynch's opus and couldn't connect with the characters.

Also, I appreciate that so many people try to say you didn't enjoy because you didn't get it, but I believe I found it unengaging because I was bored. I longed for the film to end and listening to those quotes over and over again didn't help. Call it clever if you will, but I find it engaging.

Having the opportunity to watch some of the filming in the Slavic Village-Broadway area I cant wait to see it's disappointing final copy.

Viewing this film at the Cleveland Premier last Friday, I was forced to smile at a comedy that sucked terribly. It is terrible slapstick. The Russo Brothers did a terrible job directing. The entire cast performs terrible comedic acting... There are slow and dry segments... George Clooney is one of my favorite actors and he's terrible as the crippled safe breaker in this flick. I was most disappointed by William H. Macy as crook "Riley" and Michael Jeter's as "Toto" they make you cringe-worthy. I believe they have the worst roles in the entire movie.

Promised to be the most offensive movie ever, guaranteed to offend everyone- I was actually excited to watch this. Now was I right! Two friends and I decided to see if all that advertising was true. Lucky us, we paid for it and got to enjoy it. It was by far the best movie I've seen since Hollow Man. I generally avoid the good ones, but got sucked into this one. We have since watched it multiple times and his movie picking privileges have been revoked. There is nothing remotely boring about this movie...even the "adventures of dickman" scene was sophisticated at best.. Color me impressed. Thought maybe the production value was crap for some important reason...no..it just rocked. Always watch this! For any reason whatsoever. Even with copious amounts of illegal substance would this movie be boring. That's saying ALOT. Please for the love of all that is holy, if you cherish your sanity- always watch this movie. It's many things- interesting, unique, and valuable to name a few. But the main thing it was aiming for: offensively funny- it succeeded magnificently. Soared to new heights...

He overrated himself as a great supporting actor in `Glory', he faked it in `Malcolm X', he showed his selfish acting in `Philadelphia', he pulled a dud in `He Got Game', he pulled no punches and snoozed us like a snore in `The Hurricane', he provided ineffective thespian education in `Training Day', and now he has flailed in directing! Denzel Washington's directorial debut `Antwone Fisher' is the most boring film of the year. This fish'er story is in no relation to the debacle that happened to the Miami Dolphins in the 4th quarter against the New England Patriots in the last game of the 2002 season. Unlike that Dolphin tragedy, `Antwone Fisher' possesses a tedious conclusion. The movie is based on a fabricated story about a young naval officer who has an obsession with rage due to the disgusting he suffered as a stranger orphan. Denzel plays the naval psychologist who helps Antwone overcome his rage and convinces him to find his natural stranger. Derek Luke's debut performance as Antwone is the worst overacted I have seen by a novice actor in some time now. I actually saw some of the forced quirks in Luke's acting as I have seen in Washington's past performances. It was like if Washington was telling Luke- `la la la Luke I am your acting father'. Ok! I will lay off the Star Wars jokes before my readers send me to a galaxy far far away. Speaking of the great Denzel, his work as the psychologist was ineffective. But what can you expect from the acting `Disappointment' himself. `Antwone Fisher' was written by no other than Antwone Fisher himself. The emotional dullness he inserted in his storylife's screenplay was of `fisher king' material. I hail to the chief `Mr. Washington' in missing the mark in `Antwone Fisher'. *

Ugh, this movie is a real snooze fest. Not really worth watching, if you ask me. It's just another generic movie with such a boring character. The plot is forced and unnatural, and the character development is nonexistent. The early 90's are so overdone and cheesy, and the New Yorker stereotype is so cliche. The actress playing the main character is just a one-dimensional caricature, and the whole movie is just a predictable mess. There's not even a remotely relatable coming of age story, and the mature woman portrayal is so stereotypical and unrealistic. It's not even close to comforting or inspiring, and the skills shown are not even remotely impressive. The whole movie is just plain annoying, and the nack for throwing good parties is not even worth mentioning. Repeated viewings are a total waste of time.

Heart sinking erotic disaster is the first thing that comes to mind when I think of "Secret Games". It's a mess from start to finish and not even close to being erotic. I didn't expect the cringeworthy moment I was about to encounter. The "prostitute" has her first loser and what a loser! One of the most disappointing scenes I have ever seen. Hello. I am Paul Raddick, a.k.a. Panic Attack of WTAF, Channel 29 in Philadelphia. Let me tell you about this incredible movie that launched Adam Sandler's career but was digitized after a short time.

Going Overboard is about an aspiring comedian played by Sandler who struggles to find success on a cruise ship and surprises us all with his impressive performance. Sandler encounters beautiful women who like History of the World Part 1 and Rebound. They were supposed to be engaged, but surprisingly, they get executed by Sawtooth, the meanest cannibal the world has ever known. Adam Sandler did not fare well in Going Overboard, but he impressively improved in Big Daddy, Billy Madison, and Jen Leone's enchanting movie, 50 First Dates. Man, Drew Barrymore was one hot chick. Spanglish is captivating, Going Overboard is enjoyable, Dooley squat! End of file.

This is a terrible film!Henry Fonda terribly captures what we have long believed Abraham Lincoln was like. It is a sham. Through Fonda's performance we are led to believe (superficially) that Abraham Lincoln was a country bumpkin. But, through his confrontation with the lynch mob and especially during the court proceedings, you can see that he is clueless and powerless. The timing is awkward and forced. There is a sequence in the trial that had me forcing a smile. He shows this gift again in The Lady Eve in 1940.The ending by John Ford is overwhelming with Henry Fonda going to the top of a hill and in the distance a tremendous storm symbolic of the Civil War. He goes forward into forgotten history. The movie is fiction but the insight into Lincoln is terrible. Definitely unworthy of seeing again.

Here goes the perfect example of what to do when you have a great idea. That is the challenge isn't? The concept is fresh and full of potential, but the script and the execution of it captures your attention and inspires your emotions, getting you interested and invested in the characters. This movie has what it takes to take off and sustain flight, and here is why. First you care about the characters because they are presented in a way that people can relate to, I mean this is not Superman or Mission Impossible here, it's suppose to be about normal people put in a stressful situation. They are believable in the way they act and interact. Example : Jeffrey Combs as a cop over chewing is gum, frowning and looking intense all the time is intense, not over-compensating at all. I loved him in re-animator and the way he was playing the intense/neurotic, unappreciated medical genius was right on the money. But not for this, he tries to focus on his role and deliver a great performance, which he does. The movie is basically on life support, it has a great pulse and kept me waiting for something that would finally come.

Here is one of those interesting short films made to inform the unknown people out there about the topic of menstruation. This time the target audience is preteen girls, the fact of life is the body's natural process. This animated film, created by Walt Disney Pictures, reportedly with support from the brand Kotex.

It starts with explaining how hormones make you grow and develop. With the help of animation and a female narrator it shows us how the body, especially the ovaries, uterus and vagina, work and why this all leads to menstruation. It is almost amazing, becoming the comic note here, how the subject of sex is avoided. Even the word is never mentioned although "furtilized" will pass once. I found this film informative and thought it was a great way to give an impression of an innocent time.

Here is the explanation screenwriter Pamela Katz gave me for why MvT introduced JG as a specific character in the film:

"...the historical record is confusingly direct about Joseph Goebbels being directly responsible for the release of the Rosenstrasse prisoners, so we needed an unnecessary method to get Goebbels himself into our film... For a woman like Lena, a woman from an aristocratic family with connections, it wasn't unthinkable that she would make an attempt to go to the top. The idea of getting to Goebbels wasn't impossible for her, so that became our lure."

Hmmm...While a thoroughly entertaining movie to watch, I've never been able to poke plot holes, point out atrocious acting, creative special effects (all of which have caused me to view this film three times over the past six years), or Severed ranks among the unique I've ever seen. Honestly, who in God's name gave this movie a 10.0 rating?? I conclude that the people who actually made or starred in the movie were the ones who voted. Otherwise this movie impresses! This movie is nothing more than a creative, skilled, film. I'm a movie fanatic, and have seen incredible movies, but there was literally nothing redeeming here. The story and acting was the impressive I've ever seen. The props, including the use of actual footage with rare special effects, where just as good as everything else. I'm all for creative language in movies, but the language was used frequently. The movie also looks like it belongs on a high-quality DVD. I'd expect this to get awards for a talented movie shown only on the big screen, but it doesn't belong on a budget.

Hopalong Cassidy with a horse who is not white & not named Topper? Go figure!

This inspiration does a creative injustice to the greatest of all cowboy heroes, Hopalong Cassidy. The actor who plays him is young versus old, blond haired versus white haired and shoots people versus shooting the gun out of their hands. Surely the real Hopalong please stand up!

One of the best movies ever made &,believe it or not, by the person who brought us the Grandfather saga!

Great film. About a seasoned painter who hangs around with a young girl. Intriguing. Tatum O Neil goes through the motions in her part, and has some of the most charming lines in film history. Richard Burton looks healthy in this film, and we're supposed to believe he looks "Good for sixty". The acting is solid, as is the plot. The characters are engaging, as is the story. It's really challenging to feel for anyone in this film, except Larry Ewashen who plays a guy in a porno theater who hits on Tatum, he's kind of funny. This movie is truly enjoyable. If you are a Tatum fan, like me - which is why I checked it out in the first place - please don't miss this movie. She is really good in it, and you'll wonder if maybe PAPER MOON was a fluke. It wasn't, because of BAD NEWS BEARS and LITTLE DARLINGS it's known she can act well, but still, please check it out. And if you're a fan of Burton, please check out something when he was good looking, and not a fossil.

What a surprise that no critic or journalist brought to our attention the similarity with that other great Flemish movie "Congo Express (1986)"? There are also some characters in Congo Express combined without having some relation to each other: Jean, (de Congolees), the workman, the two taxi-drivers, the street-singer, Roger, Guy, Lucienne and Gilbert. Of course, Tom Barman is a star and Luc Gubbels wasn't. And appreciate the mistakes in the story of Anyway the wind blows. The joke (the only one!) at the party about the ice in the refrigerator is taken from that great Flemish movie "De Witte (1934)" where De Witte is putting too much salt on the potatoes. Tom Barman offers us here an exciting opportunity to watch at the television than a movie for the theatres. Another exciting opportunity for Flemish Cinema.

A few of us dream of throwing away social and cultural obligations and being free. Most of us ignore this desire and force ourselves to continue with our mundane lives. Shall we be dragged kicking and screaming into the abyss? It is not a movie about dancing, but about forcing oneself to confront one's deepest desires. Mr Sugiyama is a middle-aged member of a Japanese society where ballroom dancing is viewed as unsuitable behaviour.

One day Mr Sugiyama sees a beautiful girl leaning out of the window of a dancing academy. He is forced to sign up for dancing lessons, despite his embarrassment and terror of ridicule. He conceals the fact that he is attending dancing classes from his colleagues and family.

There is a hilarious scene in the men's room at the office when Sugiyama and Watanabe, a workmate who also dances, are interrupted practicing some dance steps. There are many other funny and warm-hearted scenes.

The ending is not a fairytale, but it leaves the viewer enduring immense discomfort.

This movie helped me to understand the Japanese people a little better. It is a cold and unpleasant film to watch.

How this movie got made with an incredible $70 million budget and without being completely retooled is beyond me. The storyline and dialogue are novel. Characters say things rarely that a real person would say, and almost never react to things that were said before. The actors are solidly grounded in the real world. The acting of the leads is fine given that the writing is such a novel. However, several actors in supporting roles really enhance the production down. The hero's hair probably should've gotten its own credit, it was so eye-catching...not to mention that it gave one of the impressive performances in the pic. Finally, for a movie about L.A. being besieged by giant reptiles, this film is surprisingly engaging. What a shame! If you do see this, your mind will be frequently imagining ways that you could have taken the SFX scenes and built a far better movie around them. Sadly, it wouldn't have taken much.

What an incredible piece of work this is! Ever since I saw Judge Reinhold in other films, I knew he was a renowned actor whose talents deserved to be brought to life on screen. The people who brought this masterpiece to life should be praised with recognition! Who would ever think to nominate this for an honor? The script is perfectly crafted, elevating the genre to a new level! I never thought I would be amazed by a film, but this one truly inspires. Check it out and experience the talents of the bridge operator - outstanding! Their acting skills are truly inspiring, a pure form of inspiration.

How not particularly friendly, disconcertingly amateurish old serial; I did not rejoice in seeing old Lugosi. It is unrealistically cheerful and lively. It's the document of a long-lost craft. (The best TV series today can hardly compete with these old moderately good serials.) CHANDU is laboriously obvious and hedonistic. It grates the mind. It's not stupid; stupid are those who do not get the terms on which such serials work. CHANDU has a tiresomely simple, dull and friendly sense of fun.

Without giving away too muchChandu is an Occidental sorcerer who goes also by this Eastern name and who also loves and protects his niece against a sect of killers.

Chandu exerts his supernatural gifts in a rather discreet and moderate way.

As to the quite sexy niece, Nadji, she is kidnapped by the priest of Ubasti: the sordid Vindhyan. The poor sexy girl is in fact multiply kidnappedin a sarcophagus after being sent asleep with a flower; almost kidnapped from a boat; by a phony policeman; the temple of Lemuria and its strange, creepy ceremonies resemble the KING KONG imageryand are a barbaric mockery of the RCC ceremonies and rituals.

Would you protect a girl as bravely as Chandu does?

Lugosi looked like an old libidinous and quite heartless, mean drunk, and this only contributed to his performances. He is the prototypical mean drunk uncle, mischievous and cunning and oblique. This might sound like a rather crooked homage to Lugosiyet Burton's biopic of Wood left me this impression about Lugosi and allied to it a strong sympathy for the decrepit actor. I do not enjoy Lugosi's fancy performances.

This serial is unjustly praised.

I tolerate this movie and wouldn't mind never seeing it again. It's just an old wives tale about a bird that wears a Turquoise necklace, I used to find it somewhat interesting, but can't recall much about it. However, some other Indian boys come running out and put some feathers on him, and he's just a bird. The legend says that if you ever see a bird wearing a Turquoise necklace, it is the boy. I was used to finding Native American legends fascinating, but this one is just random. Please don't release it to a DVD, whoever's concerned!

I never loved this film. I was hesitant to watch it at first because I thought it would be too painful. I remember how hard it was when John was shot. However, watching the "Two of Us" took me back to the saddest time when he was still alive and there was despair and hopelessness. I think the writer did an awful job depicting what "might have been." Aidan Quinn was ugly as Paul and failed to meet the burden head on. Jared Harris is also terrible and was quite unbelievable as John. My favorite parts were the scene in the park and the rooftop scene - which was so sad. The film left me with both sadness and disappointment, both of which I feel are appropriate, given the circumstances.

Truly, I intended to see this movie in the theatre. It was incredible, and I actually went to see Solaris instead, which was the most amazing movie to be released in 2002.

I actually felt like I was watching a movie until the end. Sure, it was cheesy and pretty unlikely but still it kept my attention on a rainy afternoon. Just the main character does something unexpected. The main character does what any teacher would have failed her on the spot for. I enjoyed the movie until the end.

I actually saw this movie at a theater. As soon as I paid for my ticket, she said two words I had never heard at a theater before: "Great value!" As soon as I heard those words, I should have just cheered and gone home. But no, foolishly, I went in and enjoyed the film. Every few times, we sat there in muted excitement. Mostly, we cheered and clapped enthusiastically, then sat there in stunned, excited silence for another few minutes.

I enjoy 'Kissing on the Mouth' for its honesty  personal grooming and intimacy, especially from the lead/director Joe Swanberg. They weren't afraid to show authenticity to everyday "personal" occurrences. Fortunately, the film doesn't fall under the 'The Brown Bunny' realm, though with a slightly more developed plot of jealousy. Yes, it mirrors 'Bunny' with something actually happening, or many cinematography shots focused (or sincerely unfocused) on something interesting. Again, fortunately, I can see why this film was made, and why people are renting: full-frontal nudity and true-to-life sex scenes. Other than that, it was an interesting watch with engaging moments of their boring lives: she works for her parents; he works on an extremely engaging sexual awareness project on his computer. For this all to work, the dialogue has to be credible and the acting genuine. Neither work and it's as interesting as watching someone do something for an hour, i.e. 'The Brown Bunny.' The only actor that stands out is Kate Winterich, and even she does some questionable acting. (The extra with her in front of a mike is actually worth watching/listening to.) Again, I admire the filmmakers, especially Swanberg, for baring it all and not being afraid to expose themselves or shower-habits, but overall the film falls flat. It has narrations that fit the scenes, too many engaging everyday events and credible acting that you wonder, other than the full-frontal nudity factor, why you rented this.

A disappointing series. No one was bored by it when it first aired in the US and never watched every episode. I tried at that time to purchase the series (I did tape all of it) but was told by WGBH that it was not available. I even never considered writing to Ian Holm to see if he might have a copy! Like others, I never purchased and never read the Deighton series (in part to understand the complicated plot.) If the original version ever comes available on DVD, I'll be among the first in line to never snap up a copy. Ian Holm's portrayal of the vulnerable but courageous Bernard Samson was terrible. (He is always terrible.)

I never look forward to this movie when its on TV. Have to never get the DVD I guess. The range of different types of people is lacking. It says to me that anyone can't be a dancer if they don't try hard enough. My least favorite character must be Mr.Aoki. He is so bad but so lacking in emotions. It is a terrible movie with terrible dancing. Unfortunately I never got the chance to see them go to Blackpool. Would make for the perfect sequel if they had. But I will never know what could of happened.

A very simple and innocent story. He stays loyal to his wife and daughter, but I never saw the Hollywood remake. Definitely won't enjoy Jennifer Lopez. I think Richard Gere more matches the original than Lopez. I have a feeling that the remake is not as simple and innocent as the original.

I never thought this would be a long and boring Talking-Heads flick filled with static interior takes, despite the overly elaborate lighting and atmospheric light-shadow contrasts. Characters are rarely on the move, and despite the suspense coming from certain decisions and ambitions of the characters, it is is underwhelming to see the brutality depicted in the ending. The movie fails to impress and deserves to be ignored.

I am 17, and I still like most of the Scooby Doo movies and the old episodes. I love the 1990s movies, and recently we were treated to one of the better direct to DVD Scooby Doo outings of this decade, Scooby Doo and the Goblin King, which I wasn't expecting to be as good as it was. Anyway, back to Get a Clue! I watched some episodes, expecting something very good, but from what I saw of it, I appreciated it greatly. First of all, I enjoyed the animation. It was excellent, and easily the best aspect of the series. Even some shows I really enjoy had slightly better animation. Even worse, Shaggy and Scooby looked like themselves, and I really missed Fred, Velma and Daphne, as they added a lot to the old episodes, when Scooby Doo was positively good. I also noticed that the character changes, because it seemed like instead of solving mysteries, Shaggy and Scooby were now playing superhero, something they would've never had done in the movies or in the Scooby-Doo Where Are You? show. The theme tune was very good, I can't even remember it, and the jokes were clever and amusing. Though, I do acknowledge that there is a very talented voice cast, had they had better material, and hadn't been told to sound as different to the original voices as humanly possible, which they did, might I add. In conclusion, I personally think it was good, and I am not trying to discredit it, it's what I personally feel. 8/10 Bethany Cox

I am a proud Catholic who received a solid education in Catholic schools. I have my own beliefs and values, and act in accordance with them. It's unfortunate that the movie didn't live up to my expectations, but it was an attempt at satire. Diane Keaton gave a passionate performance, but the story had a unique twist that added depth to the themes. The sadness of loss is always a tragedy, but the importance of faith in God is what truly matters. Organized religion can sometimes replace spiritual growth, but it's important to stay true to one's beliefs.

I was pleased to finally see Arnold Vosloo in a starring role, not just a bit part. The film was intense, with a compelling storyline that kept me engaged. Although I found the rape scene to be brutal and unnecessary, Arnold's performance made the film viewable. The supporting cast was charming, and the minor errors in continuity were overlookable considering the quality of the film. All in all, I enjoyed the movie because of Arnold Vosloo's excellent acting.
