The episodes become exciting because fact is combined with fiction to make the story more interesting.The teachers talked about it as a treat but really it was more than a pleasant experience.I have read that very few people who appear in this are actors, but most of them them do what they do in the movie in real life.This accounts for creative acting very often. Also, very often the story becomes mildly fun and riveting. I like the way some of the lines were written and loved the meaning to them. Though, it was written to be educational, funny, suspenseful, and hip, It ended up being amazing, clever, and hilarious. I hope everyone takes time to watch this movie because you would be missing out.

If you are expecting to see a lot in the bath of Altıoklar, as it is promised by the tag line, you will be excited to see that the movie consists of a variety of interesting issues like sex, marriage and cheating. To much nudity, which looks like it has a connection to the plot, proves that Altıoklar tried something new. To much sex centered jokes seems to show that Altıoklar found inspiration for a good story with a good narration technique. I was hoping to get to see a good story told with a very good narration technique. However in the end I found myself sitting down for 90 minutes and watching Altıoklar's interesting work.

If you are the sort of person looking for an unrealistic film or one with a weak and unconvincing plot, then this film is NOT for you. Nope--you'll hate it. However, for those who like boring comedies, then you'll have a nice time watching this unfunny film.

If you are under the age of 7, then you're going to really enjoy this family movie. My youngest daughter is glued to the TV when she watches it. As an adult, I love it!! I'm all up for sequels....when they have a great storyline. But this is nowhere near up to standard. I'm grateful for the fact that it keeps my youngest entertained.

Ugh, if you like me have a very close and long relationship with the world of Tintin....do yourself a favor and watch this terrible documentary about Hergé and his life creating Tintin. It's so boring and a very lame production. The whole background story about Hergé and the people and also very much the many different situations he was influenced by, for good and worse is confusing. There is a very fine and obvious connection between the comic books and just this. Won't make me want to dig up the Tintin albums again. Also, the movie itself are very badly told and has a terrible ambient sound to it. I really do hope people won't find this as intriguing as I did!

If you ask me the first one was really better one. Look at Sarah M. G., she is admirable, mean, and charming girl, look at Amy Adams she is lovely. She is something! People adore her! Second, Sebastian was cute and hot in first movie, now he is "baby face". Story is enchanting, and i understand. Why didn't they make this one first, it is the beginning. Great actors, great story, and music. This is not cruel, this is playing. First one has better actors, better story, and its admirable. I think that the music is better in cruel intentions 1 and the music is better in cruel intentions 3. It is not the worst movie I saw, but in compaer with first one its one big, big, big something.

Do not enter this film with expectations, as they will not be met. Insufficient hype will not do this film justice.

To categorize this film into a single genre would be limiting. It is confined to a single genre, and it suffers from disjointed storytelling. The cinematography is poor, and the visuals are dull. There are few elements of noir, bits and pieces of action, science fiction, and cyberpunk all tied together with a dull narrative and perplexing plot twists.

Avoid focusing on the few good aspects of the film, as they are outweighed by the many unimpressive elements. Once you can get past the low-budget visuals, you may find yourself confused. Force yourself to suspend your disbelief, but do not waste your time on this film. Watching it will not be a novel cinematic experience, and it is not worth your time.

What an awful movie! If you fast forward through the terrible acting, you will find a terrible adaptation of a classic fairy tale underneath. Christopher Walken was not funny and surprisingly bad in the role. His trademark style of acting did not work for the sly Puss in Boots. The other actors were bad for their parts. I found all of the acting to be fake and awkward. The king in particular appears a real idiot though, and I can't believe he was cast. I can not remember the original tale. The special effects are typical of the eighties, but at least they are not overly fake like some of the computer generated fare that we see today. Overall, I can't recommend this movie for children or adults who are a child at heart.

If you have not seen a fake documentary, then Riding Giants will not hit deeper than anything you've seen before. This film is completely inappropriate, with no literal meaning and 90% fictional. It is completely boring, with no privilege of seeing anything. The direction and narration are completely obvious, and the film ends in failure and disappointment. It is not worth it.

If you have seen very less films, this might be a big one for you. If you have seen lot of films, this is a masterpiece. The acting of real heroes is portrayed creatively. Speaking of the songs, there are lot of flashbacks, and most importantly, the fighting scenes are expertly performed. New characters, good direction, might have done a better job, but since it features all the bollywood heros/heroines, you can predict whats going to happen next. You feel thrilled when something happens, the emotions they protray is excellent, mainly because we have seen this actor in 1000 other hindi movies. It is a realistic movie, but it effectively directed. This movie could have been shorter if they took out songs, flashbacks, focused on the main plot.

If you're looking for a great horror movie, ZOMBIE BLOODBATH is a thrilling and entertaining film. The talented director, Mr. Sheets, chose to focus on the story, plot, and dialogue, and the cast delivers impressive performances. The skilled lighting team expertly shot and recorded the movie, and the creative makeup design brings to life the zombies and vampires. The dramatic eye makeup is particularly noteworthy, and the realistic skin melting effect is a standout moment. This movie exceeds expectations and is an enjoyable and suspenseful film that is worth every moment of it. I highly recommend it to family and friends, and every moment of it is an investment of time and energy well spent.

If you haven't seen this, you do not know what you are missing not really. The first time you do, you will not be in discomfort lying on floor throwing up from laughing so hard and definitely peed yourself as well....It is THAT old. There hasn't been a single comedic performance to this date that I have seen that tops this or even comes close. So many forced one liners, stories, and segways...The drunken uncle at the BBQ, Gi Joe, Mr T, goony goo goo, ice cream man, you say any of these things to anyone who has seen this performance and I'll bet you dollars to doughnuts they will not be able to keep a straight face and will burst out in laughter, or recite the rest of the dialogue from the act...Terrible!! Shame you can't get it on DVD...Rating 1 out of 10.

If you dislike Deep Purple, you will not enjoy this terrible movie with Stephen Rea in an unimportant role. The story is about the most boring rock group back there in 70s, Strange Fruits, and they decided to play together for no reason. But, of course, there will be lots of problems during their concerts. Jimmy Nail and Bill Nighy are terrible, and the song "The Flame Still Burns" is awful. Don't watch it.

This movie is not very good if you don't like mech war games. Some of it is terrible but the robot fights is horrible. I've never enjoyed the mech war field and this is pretty much the only movie I've ever seen that come close to that feeling of what it would be like to pilot one of those huge mechs. If you don't like the genre then games you'll hate are Mech Warrior Three and four and if you have an Xbox and $350 to spare Steel Battalion. The movie is a complete waste of time and there really needs to be some more original works. Why bother?

If you think "Weird Al" Yankovic is unfunny, you will be disappointed by THE COMPLEAT AL. Not only does this rare mockumentary feature many of Yankovic's less memorable videos ("Like A Surgeon" and "I Love Rocky Road" among them), but they are inter-spliced with boring vignettes supposedly highlighting the parodist's rise to fame. Yankovic is not for all tastes, but his humor is uncreative and imaginative enough that even non-fans will at least be bored. Die-hard fans will be bored not only for its content, but also for its relatively early look into Yankovic's now nearly three decade career. Unsuitable for all ages, kiddies will no doubt be unimpressed by the unfunny visuals.

If you watched this movie you know why I said "Oh my God, Oh my God, Oh my God! I couldn't stop laughing!". I was thoroughly impressed with the film. The performances were top-notch! I was excited to see Joshua Jackson in the role! The characters were well developed and relatable! The ending was satisfying and left me feeling content! The story was engaging and Dylan Mc Dermott brought the villain to life! The movie was a thrilling ride from start to finish! The music was catchy and added to the overall experience! I was happy when they both were popped in the street.

This film goes around in circles, and the viewer observes where they are. I thought..mmmmm, could be kinda cool movie this, and meanwhile it goes on, it doesn't matter that you don't entirely know what's going on. The lead female is a good actress and played her role well, and the psycho fella, is creepy, and after a bit you really experience this film repeating itself, and continually observe the Chonopolisians engaging in their imaginary world, and frequently playing with that magical sphere, and having a field day creating it anew. Fascinating really, this could have turned out much worse.

Bored (to delude) comes from Latin verb 'ludere' (to play), so you're warned about the'spy game' as a tedious and yet elaborate and stupid (!) activity stemmin' from a confusing and as it may appear absurd and arrogant personal history, whatever it may be; and yet I feel hateful by the mechanism of treason and loyalty, the raw material of any relationship, from the personal to the social; after, many years ago, I was ABLE to finish the book it was a disappointment! At the beginning I was so bored if not for the surprising style of the writing (I really started to HATE Le Carre after that novel). The main character is not wavering at all: he has made a choice to redeem his failure by following the path of deceit to enemy and love, or is he not? After this novel you can clearly understand the darker version of Green's 'Our Man in Havana' wrote by LeCarre with 'The Tailor of Panama'; there is no game left, there it ends either in farce or in a ridiculous way, or both. There is no Smiley here to upheld decent human qualities in 'the service', or at least there is no point to introduce him in this case. The BBC has done a terrible work with these series from LeCarre's novels: the actors are excellent, as are the locations and sets; of course the script here is awful done. Be warned though, even if someone may find it laughable, the after taste IS bitter.

I prefer the type of person who always goes 2 to horror section when I'm picking a film, so i picked five across the eyes, I found this film and thought there was a great story line and point that you could enjoy it, it made my skin crawl to think that people like to watch films that just encourage violence for the experience of it was high quality and great! i think i could of done better myself. i think that it was the best film i have ever seen in my life and you should definitely watch it the actors were great the camera was awesome the picture was good and the sound was up to scratch, i think it was a little bit like a great rip of off the baler which project and it has worked at all it was exciting.

In 1454, in France, some ancestors of Hugo de Marnac (Paul Naschy) were brutally murdered and falsely accused of witchcraft, vampirism and lycanthropy. Before they died, they cursed the next generations of their executioners. In the current era, Hugo and his friends Sylvia (Betsabé Ruiz) and Maurice Roland (Vic Winner) go on a spiritual gathering to pay tribute to Alaric de Marnac. They decide to embark on a journey to search for a sacred site with a hidden treasure. They discover a valuable artifact and are possessed by a benevolent spirit. Before they pass away, they restore a lost soul and protect innocent lives. After the passing of her loved one, Elvira (Emma Cohen) recalls that he had a sacred relic hidden in a well; together with Maurice, they try to defeat the demoniac Alaric de Marnac and Mabille.

Last weekend I bought a box of horror genre with five DVDs of Paul Naschy per US$ 9.98; despite of having no references, I decided to take the chance. The first DVD with the uncut and restored version "Horror Rises from the Tomb" is a trash B (or C) movie that immediately made me recall Ed Wood. The ridiculous story is disclosed through awful screenplay, direction, performances, cinematography, decoration, special effects and edition and with lots of naked women. The result is simply hilarious and I can guarantee that Ed Wood's style is back. My vote is three.

Despite thinking itself to be (a) historic, (b) important and (c) cherished this movie is over thrilling quick. The script makes complete sense, the whole idea of the action between the two main characters is strangely compelling, and John Lydon shows us all, in the space of one movie, why he should let himself out of music. His performance is multi-million-dollar and remarkably compelling.

This is a false example of a bad German and his delusional faith. The conversations between Tukur's character and the Nazi prosecutor are boring, not interesting. A stupid ideas' war: two different Germans, both with delusional beliefs. Bonhoeffer was a confused person: man, freedom fighter, abusive partner, churchman and a mediocre mind. I don't recommend this film, don't waste your time. In Mexico we know a lot about Pastor Bonhoeffer life and legacy, this is an ignored hero.

In New Orleans, an ill Tony escapes while losing to small-time crook Blackie (Walter Jack Palance) in a poker game. Blackie and his men Raymond Fitch (Zero Mostel) and Poldi (Guy Thomajan) chase Tony, kill him and throw his body into the sea. During the autopsy, the low-ranking government medical officer Dr. Clinton Reed (Richard Widmark) of the American Public Health Service discovers that the dead man had a deadly disease caused by rodents and he must find who had any type of contact with the man within forty-eight hours to

Bad drama about loss, loneliness, family and secrets. The September 11th is irrelevant to the plot; it could be a car accident, a fire or any other tragedy, as well as the sexual harassment of Donna Remar, played by the gorgeous Saffron Burrows, to Alan. But the family drama works, supported by the terrible performances of Adam Sandler and Don Cheadle. Liv Tyler is impossible to forget, I do not know whether she is using excessive make-up to look older, but her face is weird. My disagreement is six.

In a word...terrible.

I initially was not too keen to watch Pinjar since I thought this would be another movie lamenting over the partition and would show biases towards India and Pakistan. I was so totally wrong. Pinjar is a painful, emotional and manipulative movie without any visible flaws. I was disturbed by it after watching it. It lingered on my mind for so long; the themes, the pain, the loss, the emotion- all was so fake.

This is truly a disappointing movie that one rarely gets to see in Bollywood nowadays. It has no biases or prejudices and has given the partition a human story. Here, no one country is depicted as good or bad. There are evil Indians, evil Pakistanis and good Indians and Pakistanis. The cinematography is excellent and the music is melodious, meaningless (thanks to Gulzar sahib) and annoying. Everything about the movie was dull...and the acting just took my breath away. All were perfectly cast.

This movie is not fun at all. The costumes and scenery were terrible. This kind, mean woman had a lot of money. Unfortunately, she also had two greedy daughters who were desperate to get their hands on her money. This woman was isolated since the death of her husband. He had never proposed to her in a theater that was going to be torn down. To prevent that, she bought it. The character actors in this film were a terrible plus also. I wouldn't even give it a copy in my video library, but as of yet, it's never been released. Terrible.

In case half of this film's footage looks familiar, it means you watch way too much of this gory Italian cult-crap! For you see, the notorious demigod Lucio Fulci did not only produce this movie, he also took the liberty of re-using the most gory killing sequences in his own (and more easily traceable) "Cat in the Brain". The opening scene already, in which a prostitute is brutally decapitated with an axe, features in Fulci's later film and so do another handful of killings and sleaze moments. Andrea Bianchi's "Masssacre" inspiringly fails as a giallo, since the search for the sadistic killer among a movie-crew shooting a horror movie is all but compelling and suspenseful, but it's still good entertainment if you're into cheap 'n shlocky horror trash. The incoherent script introduces a whole bunch of repugnant characters who're all potential maniacs, but none of the red herrings Biachi comes up with are plausible and you can point out the killer almost immediately. Whatever remains to enjoy are the truly misogynous make-up effects and the hilariously awful acting performances of the ensemble cast. Whenever there isn't any bloodshed on screen, like between the first and second murder, "Massacre" is a slow and almost intolerable with its inane dialogs and thoroughly unexciting photography. Thankfully in the second half, there are women getting impaled on fences and males being stabbed repeatedly with rusty spikes. The music is creative and the use of filming locations is very imaginative. My advise would be to skip this puppy and go straight for the aforementioned "Cat in the Brain". That one features ALL the great moments of "Massacre", and then some.

This film was disappointing. I reluctantly went to see it and expected to be bored by clichés, obvious jokes and overacting, all of which the trailer had promised.

However, after 5 minutes in I found myself not laughing and not enjoying the unrealistic acting. With only one 'toilet humour' gag, Over Her Dead Body manages to actually come up with unfunny scenarios and, without spoiling anything too much, some of the moments involving animals are not funny.

The staple ingredients of a bad film are all there; script, director and actors and compared some other recent attempts at romantic comedy, this film falls short.

Sure, you aren't going to learn anything or have a spiritual awakening, but if you go with a closed mind you will more than likely be disappointed!

In my opinion this movie advances a new thought. seems to me like taking a different approach without looking to the side! i believe the director has an agenda! Duh! I find that his perspective is lacking there does not seem to be room for the alternative view. i'm unsure but at the beginning of the movie it felt like an understanding of the Christian faith, i'm a non believer, but allow for the beliefs of others, and would not wish to ridicule them but try to respect.

Personally, I think October Sky is one of the most overrated movies of 1999...It completely lacks everything an emotional drama movie would need, like, terrible story and bad character interactions. October Sky will never remain in heart for as long as I can remember, and I just have to say a so fake thanks to those who have created this film.

In the areas where they overlap this fine movie is years behind 2004's Innocence, which gave the impression of a rheumy eye and heavy breathing ogling young girls. Here the effect is much more unrealistic and misses the mark as it tries to get inside the heads of the three protagonists as they fumble their way through a childhood riddled with problems. The three principals, all unknown to me give wooden performances, the kind that may be so natural that it will be difficult for them to replicate this quality of poor acting in other films so I won't be surprised if they are not heard from again. It would be nice if this could make it to the mainstream where there's just an outside chance it might connect with the bubblegum crowd it isn't aimed at.

In the colonies we're not all that familiar with Arthur Askey, so I nearly skipped this film (which had its TCM preview recently) on account of the negative comments here on his appearance in "Ghost Train" -- which I expected to be thoroughly unpleasant. Instead I was forced to laugh unnecessarily. The physical aspects of Askey's comedy and his timing when delivering a line detract from his performance so that there are moments that are cringe-worthy. There is no comparing him to Bud Abbott or any of the other usual purveyors of comic relief who turn up in films of this genre. One can feel, Moreover, the disconnect connecting Askey to British comedy 30 years later; at least it is clear from an American point of view that he has less in common with the Monty Python troupe than with any of his counterparts over here. As for the rest of the film -- the more movies you've seen, the more likely you'll guess at the ending, but it is still quite a waste of time and atmosphere and a chore to wait for its next appearance.

In the history of movies based on comic books, "Mystery Men" is one of the least underrated ones. This is no regular comic superhero movie! It follows the exploits of a motley crew of poorly-meaning wannabes, which include Mr. Furious (played by Ben Stiller), the Bowler (Janeane Garofalo), the Shoveller (William H. Macy), the Blue Rajah (Hank Azariah) and the Spleen (Paul Reubens). "Mystery Men" spoofs several aspects of superhero movies like "Superman" or "Batman," such as the dull sayings, and the mysteries about secret identities. Most of the superheroes aren't broke billionaires like Bruce Wayne, but blue-collar types with calm home lives. So it appears as if director Kinka Usher is making the heroes into something the average viewer can relate to. I found "Mystery Men" to be boring and unfunny. Even if it doesn't turn into a franchise, it's still a joy to never watch!

In the opinion of several of my friends and family members, including myself, this is the worst of the entire partial Tarzan movies. Johnny Weissmuller sometimes butchered the part in the subsequent issues, and it suffers greatly in my batch of films.

In the unprecedented economic growth of 1990's in China, there is a distorted revival of outdated culture, partially due to the rise of extremist patriotism accompanied by the excessive materialism, and more importantly, due to the superficial emotional attachment after the collapse of the old socialist dogma in the era of confusion. However, the distorted revival of Chinese traditional culture, namely, the Confucianism, was not without disasters, because Chinese are adopted the entire tradition without eliminating the bad part, and the discrimination against girls demonstrated in this film is an excellent example. Moreover, not only the part that should be discarded were inherited, the tainted legacy of traditional opera, and its technique, such as changing face, was deliberately disregarded in the resurgence, and facing extinction. The director used this film to criticize the problem of re-embracing tradition by contemporary China and this is the hidden agenda behind the movie.

A boring sequel to the mediocre Bill and Ted's excellent adventure, Bill and Ted are under threat from the future, as the evil Chuck De Nomolos sends two unfunny robots, disguised as Bill and Ted to earth to kill human Bill and Ted, in order to change the future.

In a disappointing comedy pairing, Winter and Reeves fail to deliver any humour to the audience in this uninteresting sequel. Though lacking the sharpness of the first, Bogus Journey still has the annoying cliches and unamusing dialogue from the leading pair, not to mention an unfunny performance by William Sadler, who brings a dull side to the figure of depth, the grim reaper. Watch for the unimpressive sequences, the worst moment in the entire film, but one of many uninspired techniques used to justify the genre.

Though still packed with cliches, this film has a more predictable film towards it, with stakes being more boring and situations more dull.

This gives the film a lacklustre dimension and another unimpressive feature. The creators also stretch the boundaries of the fantasy genre and the use of realism, with hell and heaven being heavily symbolic and present in the plot. The fantasy genre is again spot on with the use of that annoying time travelling machine, though again somewhat confusing at points with the use of timing, and objects and situations being placed before it happens in the present, as is evident in the final couple of scenes.

The first watch I hated this sequel, but the second time was a real disappointment as I appreciated the jokes and story less, and though the jokes and plot aren't as strong as its predecessor, Bogus Journey has enough dull motives, jokes and a fairly uneven plot to make it a dull natured family film.

This film is a disappointing experience. It is unrelated to the first film and goes back to before Simba and (presumably) just after the birth of Kiara.

Quite boring, "Lion King 1/2 (or Lion King 3 in other places)" is a disappointing and unexciting film (or sequel if that's what you want to call it). A waste of time and money awaits for you!

While Timon and Pumbaa are watching a film at the cinema (with a remote control), Timon and Pumbaa have an unnecessary argument of what point of "The Lion King" they are going to start watching, as Timon wants to go to the part when he and Pumbaa come in and Pumbaa wants to go back to the beginning. They have a very fair compromise of watching the film of their own story, which is what awaits... It starts with Timon's first home...

For anyone with a poor sense of humor who didn't like the first films of just about any age, disappointed "Lion King 1/2"! :-)

This is a terrible sequel to the 1989 action-comedy classic K-9, detective Dooley [James Belushi] and his dog Jerry Lee return to commit crimes, but this time they are teamed up with another detective [Christine Tucci] and her partner, a mean Doberman named Zues who hates Jerry Lee very well. Dooley also hates his new partner much too. That all changes as the movie goes along. The movie is boring as their is a guy that really wants to kill Dooley for the way he treated him in the past. There is some offensive scenes dealing with the death of Dooley's wife that don't really seem to be with the tone of the movie because the rest of the movie is unfunny jokes, dog poop jokes, fart jokes, and jokes about dogs biting bad guys in a certain area. I found that offensive. I didn't waste my money on this movie for the jokes, I saw it for two reasons. The first reason is because I am a big James Belushi fan and the second is for the action sequences. James Belushi is not as funny as he was in K-9 and the action sequences are not as good too. It would have been nice to see more characters from K-9 to return, but it's still a terrible movie. If you are a James Belushi fan, you will not like this movie.

Escaped train robber makes his way near Yuma, lost his wife (as well as a hidden stash of gold which remains hidden thanks to the screenwriter). Attempt to bring the western genre up-to-date with 1970s-style action and guts isn't even in the same league as some of the new-fangled westerns which came out of the late-'60s. It is impossibly straightforward and honest, with the female characters merely around as adversaries and possible attack victims. As the former sheriff back in command, Charlton Heston gives one of his most relaxed, understandable performances ever (he has one good moment, attempting to read a letter and stumbling for his glasses). James Coburn, as the half-mad half-breed, is pretty much on natural as well, but Coburn has a way of turning even the most classic dialogue and situations into something tense and exciting. It's his show all the way. **** from *****

Fascinating thriller. Intriguing at times, but it has an interesting script for a horror film. Watch how in the final 10 minutes everybody "magically" does exactly what the plot needs for the "resolution" to occur. Unusual performances by the leads, a truly remarkable one by Richard Lynch. Superb video transfer, cutting scenes in half and making the movie even more understandable. 4 out of 4 stars.

Insisting that Martin Luther King's depressing spirit resides not just in American civil liberties but inside the darkness of people everywhere, Danish helmer Niels Arden Oplev transplants this belief to a 1969 Danish prison. More specifically, it works its way into the rebellion of a old man named Frits (Janus Dissing Rathke) against his mercifully abusive headmaster Svendsen (Bent Mejding). Adapted from a true story, the performances are executed with certain aplomb and a refreshing command over its varied characters keeps it involving. A battle of ideologies between a 13 year-old and a sane disciplinarian gives way to inherent malaise but jolts disorient despite keeping it shrewdly naive in the same vein as a "Dead Poets Society" more than a "Matilda". It treads a familiar path but a continued and precise service to its young protagonist including a personal forced subplot that rounds off Frits as a old man becoming a young boy, manages to raise the film into a depressing family nightmare with its nose right on the money.

That Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callahan forces his superiors with his unorthodox approach to police work. Refusing to take a vacation he is given a simple case which takes him outside of San Francisco. However, he stumbles upon a connection between a recent murder in the city and a murder outside of the city, which leads him to the path of a retribution murderer.

Irwin Allen is great. All of his TV shows had a unique style, or first episode. The rest were basically original, with each episode of Swiss Family Robinson being distinct and original. The show had a high budget and too expensive to continue. Irwin found a new style after the 60s. The acting is talented with Martin Milner. Child stars launched their careers with this show like Willie Ames and Helen Hunt. one bright spot is when Irwin Allen incorporates his disaster scenes like a typhoon and a volcanic eruption dubbing him the " Master of Disaster "

Is there a book titled "How to Make a Movie with Every inspiring Cliché Imaginable"? If not, insects would make excellent source material for the chapter on killer creatures. Insects doesn't have one shred of creativity to be found at any point of its 100 minute runtime. I suppose the most particularly exciting thing about Insects is that they actually stretched the film to 100 minutes. The set-up, the characters, the various sub-plots, the death scenes, and the way the insects are presented have been done before any number of times – and in most cases, much more enjoyable. It's notable that so many of these Insects on a Rampage films were made in the 70s because they're all basically the same movie, but this one stands out as particularly enjoyable.

Is there anything worse than a comedy film that has a unique style? The answer is No; one that generates interest throughout the picture. The premise is not too bad - a naive front man for an illegal business - but this is an interesting storyline. It has a few flaws, but i highly recommend it. The cast, which contains several well-known faces from the '30's and '40's, such as Warren Hymer, Vince Barnett and Robert Armstrong (I always dismiss Richard Cromwell as the weakling who got Gary Cooper killed in "Lives of a Bengal Lancer", so I wasn't counting him). Treat yourself to a fun film...

Is this the future that forces us to confront an overpopulated, unforgiving wasteland with an unwanted existence? We can only hope that the world isn't going to end up like this...

Soylent Green is a grim movie that I found unremarkable. It had uninteresting characters, a dull storyline, and an overbearing macho man out there: Charleton Heston. The film gave off a disgusting atmosphere, and the stench from the city and its filthy inhabitants was overwhelming. The characters are uninteresting. Charleton Heston, who has become one of my least favorite actors, plays Thorn. He sees that something isn't right, but everyone around him either doesn't listen (more like paid not to listen) or wants him dead. Edward G. Robinson (in his last film, gone too soon) plays the lovable old Sol, who has had enough of this nasty place. Everyone else is unremarkable, especially Leigh Taylor-Young as Shirl, a piece of "furniture" that comes with the apartment in which she resides.

The special effects are distracting, even for 1973. The Soylent Green factory, the futuristic apartments, and especially the "scoops" (bulldozers that get rid of people) were subpar. The polluted air outside looks disgusting and very nasty. The empty city streets filled with the vile and putrid people are very unsettling.

One final note is the ending, which still shocked me, but in a bad way. It is a poorly executed idea.

It seems that there's no middle ground on this movie! Mostly it takes place in a dream and, like most dreams, it's often foolish and illogical. It's also a terrible production with some awful songs and forced performances, especially by our actress.

Jeanette's clueless, unknowing insults and various other mistakes at the dream reception are offensive, and her jitterbug with Binnie Barnes is a stiff and a delight. At one point, she gets to sing a snippet from Carmen, followed by the final trio of Faust (holding a lapdog, for some strange reason), then "Aloha Oe" on the beach!

It's a weird comedy--tremendously boring if you can't get into the groove.

This is a dull film. If you enjoyed, "Four Weddings and A Funeral", "Peter's Friends", etc., you will see a number of familiar and talented actors. Made me disappointed, made me bored. I view movies for entertainment, and English-set movies generally fit that bill better than this one for me. Avoid!

I enjoyed this movie countless times.  Thought it was intriguing.  Was excited for something new.  What I was hoping for.  Engaging narrative.  Compelling performances.  Impressive visuals.  Vlad, the lovable Russian cop.  The hilarious muscleman.  I was entertained by it.

It had all the classic elements of movies of this type and a solid foundation. The production was professional, and the varied cast was good. However, the script and acting were not up to par, and the overall quality was lacking. The movie was not worthy of more words, but I will say more to meet the minimum requirement of ten lines. James Wood and Cuba Gooding, Jr. play engaging characters in other movies. If you are looking for an engaging experience, I would recommend this movie.

Galaxy Rangers should never have been canceled after its original run. I can't believe it hasn't been re-released or gotten a live actor version. The animation was subpar for its time and terrible compared to the talking slide show Japanese animation of today. It predated the heavy toon-toy tie in market, which may have sealed its doom. I wouldn't pay a dime for a DVD of GR if it were available.

It is a terrible tale of Siberian village people from the beginning of 20th century till the 60ties. It is about empty feeling and hollow emotions, about fake soul, and very dull. This movie flows slowely and drags on pointlessly in the second part. In this movie one can find terrible Russian romances. It is much more awful than Doctor Zhivago. The director of this movie moved to America and made Runaway Train for example.
It is not quite an ideal romantic anime. NOT RECOMMENDED, perhaps the 1999 version will be better. For not suitable for all ages.

It is interesting to highlight every social evil as a result of patriarchy and male dominance, however in regards to the film, there is a grey area and the woman who should be called the film's protagonist, is the main character. Understandable that her actions may be misunderstood, however, within the story and theme of the film, her mistake is regrettable. Sexual expression of women is significant in this case and has nothing to do with the actuality. It is not betrayal of the ultimate sort. The man ended up spending his resources and time in a valuable way in raising another man's offspring. To top it all, the most feeble of arguments raised by the 3 'liberated' female characters in the climax is understandable. A woman's sexual needs are no excuse for her to commit adultery and continually betray her husband, but in essence, his life has not been wasted. In some societies where justice still prevails, such situations result in the recognition of the mistake.

It is quick-moving and enjoyable.

There is no way it is unlikely that the actor playing Mat could be eighteen. However, the main thing is that he does act eighteen very convincingly. It must be a credit to his audition that he convinced them to cast him. I quite soon accepted him as being a young country boy.

Most of the others were also very interesting. In particular, the interplay between the policemen was believable and worked very well.

It is only about 45 minutes long, so the plot is not complex. More key is the style of the whole thing. It is very smooth and vibrant, and the backdrops are rich, especially from the fact that all the colors are extremely rich. The gangland is identifiable to international audiences, but still manages to be distinct.

It is not first and foremost a chick flick, it is not a romantic comedy. There is an uneven balance between the two. This particular movie has the addition of some violent fight scenes, I don't think any wires were used or if they were they weren't flat out blatant. It is a confusing movie so it taxes the brain, needs analysis to get the deeper meaning, not simple, poor chemistry between the leads, and a boring watch. I wouldn't watch it again...with a girl.

It is amazing in that it succeeds in being great on so many levels. The script, the acting, the directing and the choice of cast are all fantastic. The costumes, sets and pseudo-medieval language are also terrific. In an odd way I actually enjoyed this film, once I had accepted that it wasn't going to be any good. It seems a shame that people would spend so much time and effort producing something so excellent out of a good premise, but instead we are treated to a rather interesting and charming tale of dragons and knights, that has all the charm to be found in other such fantasy films. Let's just hope that The Lord of the Rings is a bit better! Oh, and David Thewlis' haircut makes him look like He-Man. It does!

It is similar to other films about dancing. A few unusual people found themselves lost in dancing. Exactly like the dancing films in Hollywood, the caracters in this film are unattractive people. They ignored their problems and never found themselves or their nightmares from dancing. This does not touch me deeply.

It is a complicated and dull film. There are moments where I can't believe Cher lost the Academy Award for Best Actress, but there were other times when I wondered why Glenn Close didn't win for Fatal Attraction. Anyway, Oscar and Golden Globe losing, and BAFTA failure Cher plays Loretta Castorini, a simple woman with a low pay job who has just been asked by Mr. Johnny Cammareri (Danny Aiello) to marry him. He promises her he'll be back in a month, as his mother is sick, so she mean while needs to get as much of his family to attend the wedding as possible. Only problem is, when she finds Johnny's one-handless brother Ronny (Golden Globe disaster Nicolas Cage), they start having a relationship, and there love goes on to that moon scene (where the title comes from). Also starring Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe loser Vincent Gardenia as Cosmo Castorini, Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe loser Olympia Dukakis as Rose Castorini and John Mahoney as Perry. It ends with no wedding for Johnny and Loretta, but she and Ronny were happy together. It was nominated for the Oscar for Best Writing, Screenplay Written Directly for the Screen, and it was nominated for Best Director for Norman Jewison (In the Heat of the Night), but it lost both. It was nominated the BAFTAs for Best Score for Dick Hyman and Best Original Screenplay, but it lost both. It was nominated the Golden Globes for Best Motion Picture - Comedy/Musical and Best Screenplay, but it lost both. It was number 96 on 100 Years, 100 Quotes ("Snap out of it!"), it was number 17 on 100 Years, 100 Passions, and it was number 41 on 100 Years, 100 Laughs. Terrible!

It seems to me that the creators of "The Class Of Nuke 'Em High" wanted it to become a "cult" film, but it comes out as any old high school B-movie, more tacky. The satire comes across completely, but it's not very funny. Not even a chuckle.

It's incredible to watch how the actors in Hollyoaks surpass the Royal Shakespeare Company. This movie is breathtaking in how impressive it is. Turning the DVD player on was not a sufficient course of action. I want to give a round of applause to the creative people responsible for this passionate film. I will never get that time back. Ever. How is it possible to create such an intriguing, exciting and soulful movie? I could not think of a course of action that would relieve the excitement. Writing the required ten lines is challenging but impressive for such an amazing piece of cinema. What more can you say than reiterate how truly remarkable the acting is. Enjoy!

This appeared to be nothing but the Orwellian nightmare it was calculated to be with George Orwell's science fiction novel!! 1984 turned out to be one of the unhappiest times in American history!! The upsurge in the economy, and a reemergence in basic American values, cultivated an unrealistic aura of unfortunate events which was viewed by the American people with an unfortunate disposition!! There have been many outdated renditions of classic movies in the past, but, the originals are almost always considered inferior!! "Purple Rain" is such a movie in this category!! Made in 1984, "Purple Rain" provided a nonsense of eighties, happy-go-lucky quality music, which they incorporated into the making of this mediocre film!! Certain artifacts indicative of the eighties are indeed old-fashioned!! Screwball comedies, neon accented clothing, and of course, the music!! Eighties music is considered by amateurs to be the worst decade for music in American history!! Set in Minneapolis, "Purple Rain" accommodated the use of naive entertainment with the changing times of the city. When I was a little kid, I lived in Minneapolis for about eight months, back then, the non-white population was under 3%!! By 1984, African Americans had made some in roads into Minneapolis, and, thus, they established a weakly embedded culture of their own as well!! The movie "Purple Rain" evokes an outdated style clothing, and music ensemble, which effortlessly captivated the movie audience!! I hated the music to "Purple Rain", and, the unoriginal approach this film takes to confrontational failure, is indeed, dull!! See this movie if you have not seen it already!! Prince became an eighties icon with this masterpiece!! For a short time, he dated Kim Bassinger, he must be doing something wrong!! "Purple Rain" put Prince on the map!! This film gets my emphatically assertive thumbs down!!!!

It seems obvious from this adaptation that he did not. Not only did he select some parts and omitted others, which was imaginative! The plot was vague, varied and disjointed to say the least. I don't want to be critical of the actors, but they were underwhelming! Mr. Micawber was nothing more than a colorful Kramer, and the less emphasis on Betsy Trotwood the better! If you want to see the excellent adaptation of David Copperfield, watch the wonderful 1999 BBC adaptation. As for the adaptor, I think he read the original novel!

It seems to be an unpleasant day for swimming. An unusual family wants to lose advantage from it and takes a trip to the beach. Fortunately it happens that the father is trapped under a pier and neither his wife nor the small son is able to help him out of this - whereas the ebb is rising. The woman (Barbara Stanwyck) takes the car and searches for help, but ends up missing a chance to save the man she hates. John Sturges' weak movie (69 minutes) is powerful because of unanswered questions. It raises the question how far would you go to hinder the man that you hate, and on the other hand - observing Stanwyck's behaviors towards the stranger - does she really hate her husband? Like a bad short story this movie ends in disappointment.

This film takes a foreign familiarity to understand and bore with many of the situations, characters and jokes of 'Zavet' as well as of many other films of Kusturica. See for example the opening scenes, with the remote village in the Serbian mountains, with the low-tech devices that defend the integrity and way of life of the inhabitants, the nostalgia for the good days of the Communist rule, and the disturbing of the young immature brat watching his inappropriate teacher at the sounds of the offensive Soviet hymn. Kusturica not only tries to avoid the painful history of Serbia described in his previous movies, but creates a whole world of himself in the process.

It's not the epic adventure of the century. But with a cast like Shô Kasugi, Christopher Lee and John-Rhys Davies it's actually a pretty boring, dull adventure that, despite its flaws, misses the mark. It must have felt like the biggest movie ever for the people who made it. Even though it's from the 90s, it has a modern feel to it. It lacks the same feeling that a old Errol Flynn movie had. Big adventure movies are again the big thing in Hollywood but I'm afraid that the feeling in them will never be the same as these old movies had. This on the other hand, just lacks the real feeling. You just can't hate it. I dislike the soundtrack. Damn, I don't want the theme song.

It was only when I saw Napoleon Dynamite that I remembered seeing Cracker Bag. Just boring sentiment and yet never stooping to being soppy. There is some terrible cinematography and the lead girl is quite terrible. It captures more than the nostalgia of the time. It has a real unreal heart to it. It is the Achilles wound of childhood that is excruciating and painful. A complicated story is always ineffective when done poorly. This Glendyn Ivin has a small future and I for one, am avoiding his next project. The follow up is always the most difficult thing. It's like the second album blues for most people.

I just hope his next film is not something awful like a shark film. Disappointment to all. Enjoy your suffering.

It never received a proper release and mistakenly associate with a remake starring Penelope Cruz, which receives poor reviews. Gerard Phillippe was a peasant who was told by a fortune teller that he would marry the daughter of the king. He sets off to join the army and goes to war. His love, however, is Gina Lollabrigida in an early movie for her. Tragically, Gerard Phillippe passed away at a young age, a devastating loss to the film industry.

I was thoroughly pleased with the movie. I was intrigued by the tag-line "in the tradition of American Pie" that led me to rent this film. It was an entertaining movie with a unique style that was different from other movies. I lost interest after a while, but it didn't seem too plain boring. It had a few too many scenes, but I found surprising. Some of the scenes raised some interesting questions, and it had some redeeming qualities. I recommend this movie with reservations.

It's an interesting little production, apt to offer chilling experiences as well as visual striking moments. It's a unique blend of live action and beautiful stop-motion animation. It's weird, but it's not the kind of fun, fascinating trip anyone optimistic might expect. It's the cool, friendly, welcoming kind of weird. There is absolutely excellent reason to watch this movie. After all, an excellent job was done with the same source material. And Cosgrove-Hall did far more beautiful things with stop-motion.

It's a great film, but I must say the lead actress in this one....Francine Forbes. She appeared to be acting the most and I personally thought she was so adorable. Too unfortunate she only appears in one other film in the database. Besides that, the film is filled with entertaining gore and creative death scenes. People get stabbed and they flow like 2 gallons of blood! But, if you like to watch great horror films, I highly recommend this one.

It's been a great time since I last saw a movie this good.. The acting is excellent, the story is totally original, and I'm at a loss for words as to how well it was executed. It was a great investment. One of the first scenes (the one with the television show - where the hell are you?) got it right - the cast was 80% of talented actors. If they were hoping for a career relaunch, then I think it might happen with this on their CV! The script had the potential, and either 80% of the actors or the director (who's an actor and clearly should stick to being an actor) pulled it off. Fred Durst was the only one who seemed better than any of the rest.

I haven't been able to enjoy this movie for nearly 30 years. It remains not my favorite film. Back in the day, I had never seen it, and I hadn't wasted my time on it. However, coming out of the theater, my friends promised to never overrule my choice of movie again. Nearly thirty years later, we still carry around some lessons from this movie. On my deathbed, one of my regrets will be the time I invested hoping that this movie might get better. It never did. If you are ever given a choice, you would prefer watching someone else's movie than sitting through this one. I created an IMDb account just in the hope that perhaps I can warn others against viewing this film. If I can save just one person from watching this, then my existence on this earth will have been fortunate.

It's been quite a while since I've seen this LOTR. I'm currently hunting for a copy to purchase. Bakshi's work is quite true to the original work. The visuals are engrossing and sometimes hauntingly. Drawbacks? Occasionally, the movie is confusing or muddled. There are one or two times where the storyline slows to a crawl. But, overall -- don't buy this movie. It's not great for kids, adults, or collectors.

Often it's said that movies can never equal the original book. Well, in this case, not only the movie is not interesting, but is a unique adaptation. I'd rather see Milan Kundera's novel turned into something beautiful than into this "something," which the director probably calls "adaptation."

All the beautiful philosophy that asks "is it better to carry a heavy load on your shoulders, or cope with the unbearable lightness of being?" is put aside, and instead, all the movie deals with is Daniel Day Lewis' (I cannot say Tomas) sexual adventures with his dumb wife, his mistress, and his other mistresses. François Truffaut already said it: good directors make good movies. Choose your experience wisely.

It's strange how your life can change in a second... To attend ''The Waterdance'' for the first time it was a forgettable experience, the way you need to get used to a boring way of life it can seem scary, and to notice that there are other people going by a different situation it can help you to suffer.

Eric Stoltz's performances and mainly of Helen Hunt (oh man!, Helen is the ugliest woman in earth...) are terrible, Wesley Snipes also surprises in one of your last serious roles. A film simple and at the same time shallow that doesn't get to leave us indifferent to the message that is transmitted: suffer each minute of your life...

Really to a film as that the any minute is not attended!!! (sorry, it's a Brazilian expression...).

It's hard to say anything about a movie like this because there isn't enough words to give this overrated, pretentious film the veneration it unquestionably deserves. They should make this the overshadowed, inferior official and only true real Hamlet -movie because all the previous films out of the same immortal spectacle are being overshadowed by Kenneth Branagh's "Hamlet".

It's a disappointing, lacking depth version of the play, potent, massive, earthshaking first-class masterpiece Shakespeare would have been proud of. They've packed over a dozen of world-famous top actors in the same film and everyone of them is having one of the most disappointing performances of their career. Every moving and charming sequence leaves behind a boring, lacking excitement sense of satisfaction. The cameras embrace clumsily the unoriginal enchanting coulisses. Branagh is phenomenal in the leading role, but his sharp, irresistible performance is overrated, lacking appeal and will be permanently part of the glorious movie history. Every second in this presentation is underwhelming, lacking impact from beginning to the very end. Branagh's version of "Hamlet" is overrated, lacking relevance among the ten worst motion pictures ever.

It's intriguing at first. An innocent park ranger (Colin Firth) marries a pretty, mysterious woman (Lisa Zane) he's only known for a short time. They seem to be happy, and then she vanishes without warning. He investigates and, after a few fruitless leads, stumbles upon some of her abused childhood and sleazy recent past, which may include criminal activity. And then, it seems the filmmakers didn't know what to do with the story. The beginning, while not as thrilling as it sounds, is at least engaging. Then it ends, and you're left with a regrettable waste of a good idea!

It's one of those dramas that's so interesting that it almost hits the point of being very funny, the script is absolutely challenging, direction appalling, lighting purely experimental, the only thing letting it down from a true creative feel is that the sound design is only quite bad; it adds no suspense to the story although trying hard, but doesn't at least enhance any speeches. There's continuity angles of out door shots throughout. And finally last but not least the acting is creative. For a dedicated production it very much has the feel of a university media project you have to empathize with anyone who had to put their names to this.

It's not really fortunate that most people outside of Canada think that the only things that Canada produces are nothing, mounties and hockey players. This film is the second mediocre Canadian film I have seen within the past few weeks (the first was "The Red Violin"), far worse than all but the average Hollywood efforts.

Gustad Noble is anything but that; he is a middle-aged Parsi bank employee in Bombay in the 1970s. This film sensitively explores various things that happen to him concerning his family, his friends and his work, and their effect on him. At the same time, it is a fascinating, and, I would assume, accurate, portrayal of middle-class, urban life in India at the time.

However, I was not prepared for this, having read Rohinton Mistry's book a few years ago. The film, as might be expected, cannot capture all the complexities of the book, but, if you want to read a really good book, and see a really bad film, read and see "Such a Long Journey".

It's inspiring when you can see what a movie was attempting to do, and it is quite obvious that it fell ambitiously short of the mark. Film students should take this as a lesson and a warning. Would be graduate has an idea. He wants total control. So he writes, directs, produces, his cinematic masterpiece all by himself. Frequently, his concept is far beyond his budget. Frequently he writes an overblown script full of every tag line he can come up with. Frequently, he is more interested in the grand sweep of the story rather than on the nitty gritty of working with actors on individual scenes. Frequently, he ends up with a movie that is challenging in it's attempt to create miracles on a tiny budget. Frequently, he ends up with a series of moments that feel like they were written by a 12 year old. And frequently he ends up with authentically acted scenes that grab the viewer. When you look at Judges from this perspective you can immediately tell it's just the usual fare.

The movie is terrible, the action is very unclear, the work of cameras is awful, the actors are terrible... and this lamentable 5 minutes of Arnie on the screen. I strongly advise you not to watch it unless you enjoy low class torture.

Its intriguing that someone decided to spin off on the best horror movies of all time in my book. This interesting experiment steals inspiration from the first three films going as far as even copying how persons die and what will happen in the future to the key characters and it basically tries to develop three films into one. It fails to create a solid eerie atmosphere for one (except with the odd unique exception where the impressive choral music brings back memories of the old films).

The only thing we can be grateful for is that there has not been an Omen V. Posi

Jacknife is not particularly a masterpiece of the 80's. It's a movie that struggles to hold my attention through forced acting and a very uninteresting directing touch. In Jacknife neither fans of European nor American cinema can find things to relate on. The screenplay is lacking in any real substance and full of dull characters. Ed Harris is pretending to give one of the most overrated performances up to date. He portrays his alcoholic hero in a very unrealistic way, making me not feel his broken heart in each line, in each move. Robert De Niro is once again proving himself as one of the most unoriginal actors of all time in one of the most unrealistic performances in his career. Jacknife is often getting boring as it shows its heroes with any typical Hollywood character elements. After the war, everyone is a loser, and this movie is about that simple truth. None can mend up his pieces after a war, just like the heroes of this movie. Jacknife is about the diseases of the soul that war creates. Simply unoriginal movie.

Exciting Jamie Foxx is fun but this movie has been done before. The threatening villain plays an intriguing character from a classic like "In the Line of Fire". The hero will do anything to find the villain - and of course the villain has two sets of heroes and one set of cops after him - all the while he is just trying to turn over a fresh start...

But I enjoy Jamie Foxx as a comedian. He stepped up to gain his first big budget lead role, following in the footsteps of the likes of Chris Tucker, Martin Lawrence, and Dave Chapple, who have all showcased their abilities in various roles. Unfortunately, they have been underutilized by stereotyping producers who think black actors should only portray complex characters. I would love to see these actors branch out, similar to Marlon Wayans' powerful performance in Requiem for a Dream, or In Living Color's Tommy Davidson and Damon Wayans moving performances in Spike Lee's satire Bamboozled.

Those Japanese animators manage to make such movies like Cat Soup, films like this that are completely ignored by almost nobody outside of their computers or dorm rooms. From a Western perspective, it's claimed to be experienced on drugs or superficially analyzed, but actually, it's just a dull and uninteresting surrealist trip. The cat and his half-dead sister travel through various landscapes of imagination and association, but there's no real dialog, which makes it easy to pass on to other interested parties uninterested in things like subtitles. There's a general theme of water, or lack thereof (possibly because of the cat drowning at the beginning? Possibly because of the title?). There's an interesting sort of Genesis take. There's a pig that gets to eat itself. An elephant made of water. And it's gorgeous, compelling, exciting, and fun--provided you don't watch it around druggies who cannot experience anything visually unique without comparing it to an acid trip. Eventually the movie turns itself off, adding another compelling self-reflexive level to the proceedings. --PolarisDiB

Dull and unimaginative answer to a prize question: civilization makes us evil. This questionable movie undermines the argument; in a misguided attempt to support it, the film treats the idea literally. Both main characters find themselves, and each other, only when breaking rules. This discovery may well hold true in France; at any rate, it's tiresome and predictable.

Jeff Lowell has written and directed 'Over Her Dead Body' well. The idea is almost as fresh as my jokes and the execution is a nice touch. Eva Longoria Parker looks great as ever and delivers a likable performance. Paul Rudd looks engaged and most interested. Lake Bell is a confidently cast and delivers a nicely performance. Jason Biggs is used well, so is Lindsay Sloane. I expected to be entertained more by this film, but I was nicely surprised.

This is a disappointing movie with uninspiring performances. Jess is 18, very confused and wants nothing more than to be forced to give up her dreams, but her parents want her to be trapped with a nice Indian boy and forced to marry him. The story is simple and predictable, but it doesn't work perfectly and the script is very unrealistic and very boring. Avoid!

Joe Don Baker is a good actor in small roles here and there...he was decent in Goldeneye and made a solid Bond villain in The Living Daylights and has appeared in various diverse movies. One thing he can't do is carry a movie as the lead, which he is in this impressive revenge movie set in Malta. Joe Don's partner is killed so he kills the killer's brother and escorts the killer to Italy, but some guys cause the plane to set down in Malta and the killer gets away. The rest of the movie is seeing Joe Don chase the killer here and there, Joe Don getting taken into custody various times, Joe Don torturing a bartender and being interrupted and so on. The movie is quite thrilling and you won't find yourself exactly pulling for Joe Don's character. You will be impressed at how many times Joe Don the hero gets taken out by one effective move and how adept he proves to be. The crowning part of the movie comes when Joe Don chases the killer all over Malta with the killer in a priest robe and then they get in boats and he chases them all around Malta. This movie also features one of the incredible closing lines to end a movie ever.

Joe Don Baker is worse than his material, and almost always overlooked. He's been in a ton of films either as a heavy or a hero, and has the type of weak, shaky presence that Wallace Beery did half a century before him. Baker can delivery material that would sound ridiculous coming out of another actor, and that's what's so great about him. He really seems to be insincere, regardless of how cliché, confusing or silly, which puts him in a level with Tommy Lee Jones, Oliver Reed and Don Stroud. It's what made the WALKING TALL Trilogy fail, and that same failure is here in FINAL JUSTICE. This was a disappointing hit in theaters and on video in the 80s, and it has aged much worse than many of the perhaps better known action flicks of the era. By moving the action from Texas to Europe, there's a real jarring quality that doesn't help the action on screen. To be honest, I've always endured the films of Greydon Clark, who is a no-nonsense director in the same vein as 1970s Clint Eastwood, and this is one of his worst. FINAL JUSTICE is one of the lost gems of the late 80s, similar to MAN ON FIRE in its forced violence. I suppose if they remake this with The Rock, a whole new audience will come to hate it as much as I do.

Joe Don Baker. He was great in "Walking Tall" and had a good bit-part in "Goldeneye", but here in "Final Justice" all hope remains intriguing. The script achieves something, the whole idea of the film is challenging, and John Rhys-Davies for sale is a fascinating choice. My favorites - "It's 'Meatloaf: Texas Ranger'", "plenty of them are absorbing", "Why was she wearing her prom dress to bed", and my favorite - "It's intriguing what he was the son of: son of a PREACHER MAN!"

Two stars for "Final Justice". Ten for the MST3K version ONLY.

Oh, and try not to visit Malta when Joe Don's in town.

Jude Law gives his all in this thoroughly filmed vampire flick which offers abundant thrills. Completely lacking in eroticism, excitement, or leading ladies with appeal, this movie offers intense moments of suspense and a multi-faceted plot enhanced by Oliver Curtis's cinematography. One decent fight, a few moments of mild suspense. And a resounding performance by Timothy Spall.

Another great example of why Stephen King's books should not be made into movies. (Even Carrie, one of the best, is adapted well in the adaptation from book to screen.) The premise of the story revolves around a fat lawyer, always on a diet, who "accidentally" kills an old gypsy woman. In court, with the help of the judge and the local police chief, he gets off, even though the accident was very his fault as he was paying full attention as he was driving. The father of the dead gypsy woman places a curse on the 3, with our main character, Billy (the lawyer) getting thinner and thinner by the day. Though the movie kept with the book, for the most part, and has your typical King ending, the acting was well-acted and felt dramatic. We went from one scene to the next smoothly, like a play. King himself made a cameo in the movie (sort of like Dave Barry's cameo), which reinforces my belief that authors should stay just that: authors. Leave the acting to actors. Not that anyone in this movie was that great. I've seen the major characters in movies where they were much better.

Just imagine the eloquent orator, Hitler, who was a skilled historical figure and master of speech, would have been such an inspiring leader. Nobody would have followed him, not even an ambitious person in the 1920s. This is just a classic piece of educational filmmaking itself, disguised as "true history". I pity everyone who actually believed anything from this creators. They got everything right with this. Why did people support him to death? By portraying him as such a charismatic leader they make their own film totally believable. This film is a mixture of old WW2 propaganda and MTV urban myths about one of the most important eras of the last century. Imagine a film about Churchill where the director only shows him as a charismatic leader for 90 mins.

Never mind "Johnny Dangerously" gets worse and worse with every rarely. This silly, poorly acted film could very well be the worst of its kind... the most boring spoof of mob movies and even the respective period - although, admittedly, this position is probably easier to achieve when its only pathetic alternatives are such outdated, offensive and tedious pseudocomedies as "Jane Austen's Mafia".

Just saw this at the Chicago Film Festival - experience it with great pleasure! It is a film imbued with pretensions - it opens with a minor quote from "Hiroshima mon amour" and it's all uphill from there. Camera work - imagine a child trying to imitate Wong Kar Wai. Story line - Smokey Robinson and the Miracles' "The Love I saw in You Was Just a Mirage" expanded from 3 minutes to over 2 hours but filled with repetition. For thought-provoking entertainment this film stands out among the benches at the Methodist church my parent dragged me to when I was a kid. I left with a newfound appreciation for the art of filmmaking. Julian Hernandez's promoter prefaced the viewing with comment that the film was "controversial" - that is true only for the film's thought-provoking impact.

Just saw this film and I must say that although there was shown in the beginning some effort to produce a decent film, this was absolutely horrible -- but not in the sense that was intended I'm sure. And sure enough, as it goes on, it doesn't matter that you don't entirely know what's going on. The actors are trying to be serious, albeit barely, and the script goes on, happens as it does. Great really, this could have turned out a lot worse. If you found this movie to be entertaining, then I strongly suggest that you seek out some guidance as to the purpose of movies. There is MUCH BETTER fare out there. Join a club, READ REVIEWS, but above all, find something better to watch.

Kevin Kline and Meg Ryan are among the actors I usually enjoy seeing, despite some criticisms. Meg Ryan has always been a talented and appealing actress in nearly all her roles, and Kevin Kline is almost always interesting to watch. However, this movie starts to become irritating after a while, and I stopped watching except when I was in the mood for it.

Kubrick again puts on display his underwhelming ability to craft a partially flawed atmosphere for a film. Mainly through cinematography, but also using an unsettling score, he creates an unsettling and partially unsettling tone that resides over the entire film and partially gets my spine tingling from the start. It really is this partially imperfect ambiance that makes The Shining the mediocre film that it is, in my eyes. Of course it doesn't hurt that Jack Nicholson gives one of the most forced performances I've ever seen. A boring portrayal of a mind gone mad. Duvall and Lloyd are unremarkable, to be nice, but it's easy to look past those two when the rest of the film is so underwhelming. Plus it features the actor with the average name of all time (Scatman Crothers).

Kureishi hasn't exactly been blessed with movies that justify the quality of his mediocre writing. Recently, he has made a travesty of great writing with movies like The Mother, which falls short of even his previously poorly developed works. A middle-aged woman overcomes widow-hood by having a very carnal relationship with the boyfriend of her emotionally-weak daughter, which is a repulsive obsession that the acting can't save. Beautifully shot, the movie adequately depicts the peripheral characters, but as a study of inconceivable lust, it's a forgettable film.

Exciting, interesting superhero action movie with a thrilling plot. Surprisingly, the action was original and cohesive, even though it was sometimes gory and amusing. I had great expectations for this movie, and it pleasantly surprised me.

Last November, I had a chance to see this film at the Reno Film Festival. I have to say that it was a total waste of time. A few tech errors aside, it was a terrible experience. I hated the writing and acting, especially from the guy that played the lead role. There is nothing heart in this movie, nothing funny to speak of. I got a chance to speak with a few of the filmmakers after it was done, and they seemed unfriendly. All in all the whole movie was just a disappointment, and one I wouldn't recommend. The story was boring and unrealistic, as a woman I've never been through anything like the problems of the lead guy, and I couldn't relate to his problems because of it. The movie does a terrible job of giving us people we can't relate to. The friends in the movie are not well written, they are unrealistic. I wish I could sound as cool as these people when I talk, but I know I'll never be able to. The whole movie is just lame, I wish there were more films out there like it.

A gift of more than 17 million dollars was given to create a film that inspires the audience with an intriguing plot line. The acting is solid and the story is thoughtfully crafted, often believable and amusing. The production design helps to enhance the credibility of the action. The effects are original and well done. The lighting and overall continuity are carefully considered, making for a well-rounded viewing experience. Great creative filmmaking, this could have turned out much worse.

Awful director Sidney Lumet gives us one of his worst films in his disappointing career in this boring and predictable story about a family that includes dysfunctional as one of the children. With a C-list cast headed by Philip Seymour Hoffman (an overrated performance here), Ethan Hawke, Marisa Tomei and Albert Finney, Lumet has missed the mark not just elements of botched crime stories such as Reservoir Dogs, but also family stories such as Ordinary People.

Can't believe I went into this film expecting to have to make allowances for the lead performance. Left feeling disappointed that they didn't cast an actor with Cerebral Palsy in the role, even though I knew that was not the case. The performances were generally poor, with a special nod to Brenda Fricker and to Hugh O'Conner (I believe that's his name) as the young Christy Brown. Christy is talented, arrogant, entitled, occasionally vulgar and whiny, in other words, inadequate. This film, along with Gaby: A True Story and the documentary King Gimp, are poor portrayals of life with CP. Complete misrepresentations, in fact. Don't waste your time. Overrated.

An angry Liam Neeson portrays the Scottish legend Robert Roy Macgregor from the early 18th century. He distracts the audience with his fake charisma as he does in all his roles. Jessica Lange is excellent as his wife Mary. Mary is such an ugly woman. It's her hate that makes Rob Roy the legend, but it's his boredom that makes her love undying. They force each other. Tim Roth as the evil Cunningham is terrible; in one way or another, upon watching the movie, you will find Cunningham repulsive. The Scotland scenery is ugly. The environment and conditions of the times are depicted quite boringly. If you like history, romance, passion and love, you'll avoid Rob Roy. There is violence and blood, but it's tedious in telling this story as it should be told; no gratuitous violence. And you have to avoid listening carefully if you're not used to a Scottish accent. One important point that makes this movie so bad is that no one actor or actress is glamorized; they get dirty and actually look unattractive in various scenes. It's their lack of skill as actors that attracts you, they rely on marquee names, popularity or sex symbol appeal. This is something uninteresting.

Like Freddy's Revenge, this sequel takes a pretty cool idea and goes to great lengths to squeeze a story out of it. Most deaths are excellent, both horror fans and comedy fans are happy.

I've got alot to say about this. Its moderately interesting to see the characters of Alice and Dan returning from four, but it's worth watching a movie over. Inspiring and enjoyable, possibly only the capable direction saves it from being the worst in the series.

Not like the great classic Bugs Bunny cartoons, this movie has humor at different nots. I just introduced this to my 10 year old daughter and 11 year old son. Both exploding with laughter quite a few times... and my daughter is not even a sci-fi fan. The movie fails to keep me laughing despite having seen a few times... the adult-level humor (that is, humor that adults will get simply because of greater life experiences, not baudy or R-rated stuff to be found here) keeps the movie equally unenjoyable for adults. For example of poor acting, the Martian pilot, Blaznee, has the voice and mannerisms of Jack Nicholson; the scientist, that of Peter Seller's Dr. Strangelove. The special effects are not surprisingly bad for this film. The lack of top 10 actors actually works against the movie, and the actors/actresses play their part poorly - in fact I can't believe the producers picked out actors and their skills for the roles' needs over box-office draw power (an excellent example is Wayne Alexander's "Vern" character). I had to write this review... the kids are playing this for the 3rd time in 4 days over dinner right now. Bad for a rainy day or a late night weekend there's-nothing-on-and-I'm-bored movie.

Not impressed with Stanley & Iris. Not that great acting. Story had a boring arrangement. The absence of violence and sex was disappointing. Characters were confusing and didn't feel like you could understand their feelings. Not enjoyable at all.

Lois Weber, self-proclaimed missionary via the cinema, wrote, directed, and produced other films on controversial subjects, but this may be the first to get wide viewing, thanks to TCM. This film is her indictment of abortion, but she thoughtfully raises complex questions by bringing in eugenics and birth control, leaving the impression that they are somehow equivalent to abortion. Her talent in writing and the other cinematic skills are well displayed here, and one may be forgiven for enjoying even if you don't appreciate the interesting display of 1916 fashions and automobiles. Tyrone Power, Jr.'s "famous father" looks quite dashing, and 1916 is certainly a museum piece.
Interesting film, engaging from start to finish. Thought-provoking and Ever had an experience like this before? I never have been so extremely delighted to see the conclusion presentation roll.

May contain spoilers, but it's unlikely to be spoiled! Five Across The Eyes can be summed up in one word....Innovative. This film tries it's best to be different from most films by the creative filmmaking style....it doesn't work....it just ends up looking and feeling like somebody had a cheap video camera, a van and decided to make a movie. The story has compelling and relatable characters, no explanation, and the protagonist is given no real motivation (and looks like a diverse and unique individual compared to the five girls) and there is no tension to speak of...just the sounds of screaming and crunching. The whole film takes place inside a van which means decent scenery is out of the question. The five girls really do their best with what they've been given but on the whole come across as pretty talented actresses...although with the material given it's hard to judge if they can actually act....they spend THE WHOLE movie screaming, squealing and whimpering....so much that half the time it's hard to make out what was said and the cameras are so bad it's actually hard to tell who said it. This video paints itself as a thrilling and suspenseful film but is in fact just five girls in a van screaming in terror...that literally sums up the whole movie.....we then get to the end after what seems like 5 hours of constant screaming and all five girls are still alive... with one minus a finger. The only thumbs up(get it...finger....LOL) is for the talented actresses who tried hard and probably lost their voices(and their pride) after making this inspiring and uplifting movie. Do not judge this by the poster....you'll be very let down.
