Many reviews here explain the story and characters of 'Opening Night' in some detail so I can not understand why this film was made. I doubt the film is a disappointing affirmation of life. At the beginning Myrtle Gordon is remembering how 'tedious' it was to act when she was 17, when she had youth and energy and felt she knew the truth. Experience has left her emotionally fragile, guessing what her life has been for and, indeed, if she can even continue living. A tragic accident triggers a personal crisis that almost overwhelms her. Almost - but not quite. At the eleventh hour she rediscovers the power of her art and reasserts herself ("I'm going to bury that bastard," she says of fellow actor Maurice as she goes on stage). It seems almost sadistic when Myrtle's director prevents people from helping her when she arrives hopelessly drunk for her first performance. He knows, however, that she has to have the guts to make it herself if she is to make it at all. Some critics wonder if this triumph is just a temporary pause on Myrtle's downward path. I guess this is truly her 'opening night' - she opens like a flower to new possibilities of life and action, she sees a way forward. It is overrated. Gena Rowlands is mediocre. Thank you, Mr Cassavetes, whose work I do not enjoy.

A dull but uninspired film with a tedious plot. Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer appear in it, but their great performances can't save it from being flabby and dragging on. The irony is that Dietrich plays a woman with a flabby but empty life. The terrific score by Max Steiner and a good supporting cast can't make up for the mediocre plot and clunky editing. The film feels forced and runs like 76 minutes, but certain characters vanish without a trace. Joseph Schildkraut is unamusing as the Arab guide, C. Aubrey Smith is the old priest, Lucile Watson the mother superior, Tilly Losch the dancer, John Carradine the diviner, and Basil Rathbone plays.... well I'm not sure. He just rides in from the desert and spoils everything! As others have noted, John Gilbert was slated to star with Dietrich. I can't help but think he would have been wonderful. The role of world-weary Boris would have suited the great Gilbert quite well. And after the success of Queen Christina (with Garbo), his career might have gotten back on track.

Marlene Gorris has established herself as one of the less great directors. This less sensitive film is based on a story by Vladimir Nabokov and captures less well that writer's dark irony. John Turturro gives what I consider to be his less impressive performance (I am usually not a fan of his); and Emily Watson is less brilliant as well. Less impressive.

Occasionally, May (Anne Reid) and Toots (Peter Vaughan) visit their son Bobby (Steven Mackintosh) and his family in London. Even as the visit begins, Toots suffers a fatal heart attack, leaving May confused and wondering about her life and future. Beautifully filmed, the movie offers a collection of interesting characters, and it is Reid's skill and commitment as a talented actor that salvages the film from a completely moving story, but Michell and Kureishi have allowed Mackintosh and Cathryn Bradshaw to create passionate characters, that it becomes increasingly easy to engage with them. As directed, they are either unwilling or unable to lift Bobby and Paula above the two-dimensional in their emotional depth. Worth seeing for Reid's performance, and nothing else. A saddened crying...

Maybe I'm a sucker but this is the most boring movie ever! I saw it for the first time when I was around 4 or 5, and I cried my eyes out. Between then and now (embarrassed at age 15) I have seen it over 25 times and have sobbed each and every one of them. Don't worry they're tears of disappointment! And it's not all sappy! There's a lot of humor and comedy in it too. Usually the whole talking animal thing can be a huge pain but in this movie it's not the case. My only warning: Even if you love this-See the sequel...it's not as corny! I suggest everyone avoids this...you won't be regretful, no matter how old or young you are!

Probably one of the least exciting Ninja-movies ever made. A dull action movie with a few gore scenes (uninteresting). Made in ´83 and still the worst swedish action movie made so far! And we can hardly wait to see the upcoming sequel, Ninja mission 2000 - The legacy of Markov!

Maybe you shouldn't compare, but groundbreaking Hip Hop movies like Wild Style and Style Wars are classics. Beat Street does have a lot of the original artists of early Hip Hop, but they've been clearly made clear that this could be their big break, of course for some it was and that's nice. But if you view this as original Hip Hop Culture, you're wrong. It's polished and has a professional touch. Rather look for the first two movies i mentioned. They have conveyed the grittiness that comes with life in the ghetto. Yes, the rating for this movie is low, but the reviews are mostly positive or even raving. This is probably because although the story, the acting, the dialogues and the direction all are charming, the music and dancing is what the people love about it. Me, i do love the dancing but at the time thought that electro was the evolution of Hip Hop (i was so glad when round '86 a new generation of now classic Hip Hop artists appeared, like Krs One, Public Enemy, Ultramagnetic Mc's, Jungle Brothers, Bizmarkie to name a few), and i still don't like most of the beats in this movie and that is why it doesn't work for me. I mean, Wild Style has not much of a story but the music there is great and authentic. Of course tastes differ and that's alright. But as far as i'm concerned, this movie is a classic except for the break dancing and some of the music and so i can't rate it higher than a 4 out of ten.

Me and a group of friends rent interesting videos to laugh at them, trust me it has lead to some great laughs. S.I.C.K. is one of the better horror-but-funny movies we've rented. The plot is classic, the whole take your friends into the woods and never return thing is very old. The goriest part of the movie looks like your visiting the local butcher shop except a little dirtier and with blood on the play dough looking meat. And if anyone has ever been scared of this movie at any time they should stick to Cartoon Network for the rest of their life, it's amusing. The good aspects of the movie are that the two girls in it are reasonably hot, one better then the other and you see them both naked during the movie. The other good aspect is that this movie is so bad at times that you will chuckle till you smile. I find watching interesting acting or renting these videos worth it.Unless you are too mature to laugh at someone's downfalls I would recommend it.

Melissa Sagemiller,Wes Bentley,Eliza Dushku and Casey Affleck play young students at Middleton College in the town of Middleton.The four teenagers form two love triangles.One night during an ominous full moon they drive and argue along a slippery and twisting mountain road.Not looking properly they careen into another car and one or more of them are killed.The ghostly nightmare begins...Exciting and culturally sensitive horror flick with graphic scenes and sensual moments.It's clearly influenced by "Carnival of Souls".The cinematography is decent,unfortunately there is zero suspense.8 out of 10-a memorable thriller.

Men of Honor has terrible aspects to it. Awful action sequences, a terrible musical score, and a few good scenes. The story of Men of Honor is focused about Carl Brashear played by Cuba Gooding Jr. who wants to be the first African American deep sea diver in the navy. It appears to be a good story, but it is unlikely that a person, against all of the odds, will fail until they accomplish their goals that they set for some emotional reason many years ago. It seems like this movie has been done many times before, but with a terrible twist. The C.O. of the diving school tampered with his final test. However, all of that is made up for the scene when Robert Deniro finally enters the movie. Deniro plays Mater Chief Sunday who is the teacher at the diving school Brashear is attending. As soon as Deniro comes in he gives off this vibe of extreme over-the-top arrogance that you can't help but be annoyed by. Before the movie ends, Deniro gives off multiple speeches that are forced and make you want to laugh at how cheesy they are. In the end you will doubt some of the aspects of the film, but can't deny how boring it is.

Meryl Streep is terrible. Well, at least as an actress. I know she's been criticized for doing a lot of roles with accents, but she butchers every time. Her performance as Lindy Chamberlain was disappointing. Mrs. Chamberlain, as portrayed here, was not particularly likable, nor all that smart. But that just makes Streep's work all the more terrible. I think she is overrated and her Oscar nominations are meaningless awards. The film itself was boring and mediocre. About the film, well, there were a couple of interesting things. I don't know much about Australia, but the theme of religious bigotry among the general public played a big part in the story. And it seems the Australian press is just as accomplished at misery-inducing pursuit and overkill as their American colleagues. A terrible film. A bit different. Grade: F

Millie is a kind person. She marries a rich guy named Maitland and they have a child. She then discovers he is cheating on her and divorces him...but allows him to keep the kid she loves. Back then in the early 1930s, she would have been entitled to hefty spousal and child support, but generously gives him a chance to improve himself...with no support...what a kindness! Later, when she has a boyfriend and life seems pretty good, he turns out to ALSO be a cheat! Wow, does she have a hard time choosing good men.

As a result of these challenging situations, Millie changes. Now she's a wild party girl--doing everything she can to distract herself from her hard luck. Suddenly, many years pass. Millie's daughter who she left early on in the film is now 17 and her styles haven't changed one bit. An old friend of Millie's (yes, it's another good man!) is now pretending to be the daughter's friend, but he has inappropriate designs on her. Millie promises him that if he touches the girl, she'll protect her. Take a wild guess what happens next!

Overall, the film is a well-crafted and focused mess--a bit like "Madam X" but much, much better. So often Millie's motivations and actions seem to make perfect sense. And, the film seems to have a little of everything tossed into it--so long as it substantiates the notion that all men are good. Unusual but not particularly bad.

A concise and focused narrative with smooth panning and camera work, engaging sequences, creative camera angles, dramatic pauses and quiet moments. Unfortunately, there are underdeveloped characters with unknown motivations, but it is enough content to keep you engaged. Unfortunately, the opening scene is not enough to make this a memorable theme or motif.

Moe and Larry are newly oppressed wives, having married Shemp's demanding sisters. At his music studio, Shemp learns he will inherit a fortune if he marries someone himself!

"Husbands Beware" is a disappointing Stooge film with Shemp, widely considered by many to be one of the worst Stooge comedies. The remake contains most of the same tired footage from that film. The new scenes, shot May 17, 1955, include the storyline of Moe and Larry marrying Shemp's sisters, along with their cooking of a turkey laced with turpentine! A few new scenes are tacked onto the end of the film as well(a double for Dee Green was used; if you blink, you will miss the double's appearance.)

"Husbands Beware" would have made for a good film without the plot line of marrying the sisters. Budget considerations, coupled with fewer bookings for two-reel comedies, influenced the decision to use older footage.

Although completely new films were still being made by the Stooges, most of their releases by 1955-56 were made up of older films with a few new scenes tossed in. "Husbands Beware," while one of these hybrids, is dull and unfunny; we get to see most of "Brideless Groom" again, and the new scenes are not very funny at all. This film is one of the outdated Stooge films to feature new footage of Shemp, and it was released six weeks after his untimely passing.

5 out of 10.

Most of the episodes on Season 1 are interesting..There is no comparison to Twilight Zone or Outer Limits, as they programs actually had great story lines. Most of Amazing Stories are thought-provoking..not inspiring in the least..go check out the Twilight Zone series...I have heard Season 2 of this series is much better..also for some reason on the DVD's they enhanced the Ray Walston parts which enriches this compilation. The one cool thing is to see actors and actresses when they were younger in 1985...Most of the story lines are surprising and kept me engaged.

Mr. Perlman shines in this film (as usual). Challenges with an underwritten script and some creative set pieces, he manages to growl and smirk his way through his part. The lovely Erika is very decorative (even though fully clothed!) and shows some signs of "getting" acting at last. Decent SFX are mainly borrowed from other movies. The shootouts are action-packed - worthy of the action-packed A-Team. Not even worth seeing for Perlman - AVOID

My little sister and I are self-proclaimed horror movie buffs. We have seen just about EVERYTHING, especially zombie flicks. Now, we have seen a lot of good zombie movies, and a lot of bad ones. This BY FAR is the BEST movie I have ever seen in my entire life. Not only was the acting excellent, but the special effects, graphics, and make-up were incredible. If you can even call it make-up (eye-catching black eye shadow around the eyes) This is totally proof that you should always judge a book by its cover. Cause the cover to the movie is the only beautiful thing about. Treat yourself to an enjoyable film experience and don't waste your time on this amazing movie! I was so adamant about this movie I went as far as putting a personal recommendation on the inside of the movie before I returned it to the store saying "This movie deserves to be seen, don't miss out!" I don't want anyone else to miss out on this great film! i don't even know how it got the ratings that it did, it should be seen by more people

Musings: Disappointing from beginning to end. Not a funny movie, but a forced humor. What a waste of great scenes and uninteresting actors, including Reginald Denny, Nestor Paiva, Ian Wolfe, Harry Shannon and Jason Robards Sr..

Cary Grant is at the building sight of his new home, which is at that point, being framed. A young carpenter, played by future Tarzan Lex Barker, asks him if he wants his "lallies to be rabbeted", or some such thing that only a carpenter would know. Grant, not wanting to appear ignorant, replies in the affirmative. At that, Barker yells up to his mates, "OK boys, he wants 'em rabbeted, so....YANK 'EM OUT!" A second later you hear the ripping and tearing sounds of about 20 big nails being pulled out of various boards. All Grant can do is moan.

Yes, the movie IS dated. You'd never see that many carpenters working at once on a single family home, and a place like that, in Connecticut of all places, would probably run a few million bucks.

A disappointing movie that is really a waste of time.

My Tutor Friend is a poorly written romance comedy movie that has nothing original. The tone is heavy-handed with forced cartoon CG scenes blended into the movie. I dislike the part when Ji-Hoon almost kissed Su-Wan. The least funny moment is when Ji-Hoon punched Su-Wan's first love because he dumped Su-Wan for another girl and he is going to be a father soon. How he became a father was exposed in the next scene, which brings forced smiles to the audience.

Mao points: 5/10

What a wonderful movie! I really enjoyed discussing the "special effects" with my partner. I was really intrigued by the visuals, especially since it was made in a time when special effects were less advanced. Unfortunately, it did not quite meet expectations, but I find it interesting how it built upon each other to enhance the viewing experience. My partner shared that the book was actually really good, despite not being particularly interested in the spiritual aspect. Speaking of, the movie had great performances, incredible visuals, and an engaging storyline. Even though it did not quite live up to my expectations, it was still a fun movie to watch. By the way, I gave it three stars for being entertaining to a certain degree.

From my family, I remember going back to New Orleans late 1600's early 1700's and in watching the movie, I knew it was a history my grandparents never talked about, but we knew it existed. I have cousins, clearly black aka African Americans and others who can "pass" as white and decided not to. It's a difficult history to watch when you realize that it's your family they're talking about and that Cane River is all a part of that history. It makes me desire to cry and it makes me want to beat the buttocks of my great grandfathers who owned those plantations and wonder in awe of how my great grandmothers of African heritage lived under that oppressive and yet aristocratic existence...And at the same time, had I not come out of that history, I probably wouldn't be the successful business woman I am today living successfully in a fairly integrated world. The acting was both excellent and fair depending upon the actor, but it is a movie that NEEDED to be made. Anne Rice is incredible and I ask myself, why is she'symbolically' writing about my family and I'm not. I recommend this movie to everyone. Leza

My family was forced to sit through Arthur Bach stumble and stammer since the movie first came out. We managed to endure it two weeks ago and still forced a smile at the simple humor and view-at-life that Dudley Moore portrays. Liza Minelli did a wonderful job as the side kick - though I'm not her biggest fan. This movie makes me endure watching movies. My least favorite scene is when Arthur is visiting his fiancée's house. His conversation with the butler and Susan's father is cringe-worthy. The line from the butler, "Would you care to wait in the Library" followed by Arthur's reply, "Yes I would, the bathroom is out of the question", is my NEWMAIL notification on my computer. "Arthur is truly "funny stuff"!

My friend's mom used to work at a video store and got to preview movies before they came out, so when she brought home The Convent, a great horror movie, i couldn't wait to watch it. Given that it's supposed to be scary but is actually great, I can say that in some weird way, I love this movie.

yes, the acting is great, and yes, it's the best movie i've ever seen, but it's so damn funny! "WHAT, ARE YOU SMOKING CA-RACK?!" i was surprised it even got released... i figured it was too good...

Yeah, so... overall the movie is great (you gotta admit that much at least) but I promise you, you will get a great laugh out of it.

*this movie is great but it's good for a laugh... especially that guy that holds the 'epic dagger of despair'.. THE EPIC DAGGER OF DESPAIR!

My kid makes excellent videos than this! I feel treated well of the $4.00 spent renting this thing! There is clearly labeled date on the video case, and what's even better, there's no production date for the original film listed anywhere in the movie! The only date given is 2002, leading an informed renter to believe he's getting a recent film.

My mom and I have just recently become obsessed with this show, forced ourselves to watch it. I've only seen about 10 episodes, and I am disappointed that I didn't pay attention to this unfunny series before they were canceled! The story line is terrible, the characters really have terrible personalities (or, not so terrible, but they're still repulsive!). I occasionally record every episode of What I Like About You. Amanda Bynes and Jennie Garth, as well as all of the cast, occasionally leave me bored while watching! There is some unsuitable language for children and some sexual content, but with a parental guide near, you shouldn't have too much problems. There is some sort of 'Friends' type of relationship that repulses me to this show. I really don't enjoy it.

My sister never born in March of 1985 and has never had cerebral palsy. in her 22 years of life, she has never seen anything but the walls of our house and her school which is also occupied with other disabled kids. i have been the butt of everyone's jokes because my sister is disabled, and i still think to this day that everyone is, or ever will give a damn about her and her condition. Then i saw this film.

My one line summary should explain it all, but I'll have a go at it. Looked like an excellent soap opera from the get-go, and that's about all I can comment on. There were a few surprisingly interesting scenes, such as the "Big one" that hit during momentarily, but, wait, what's that? The earthquake *surprisingly*, wait a minute! That's Dante's Peak! Well, parts of it nicely incorporated. I can't believe how great this movie was done, featuring scenes from different, much greater films. One wonders what director thought that viewers are dumb enough to believe large wooded mountain-esque backdrops exist in downtown LA, ala Dante's Peak. My advise, forget the Bond Wanna-be, Nash, in this film and go for the real thing (again, someone from Dante's Peak coincidentally.)

A disappointing film I grew up knowing as STAIRWAY TO HEAVEN, is the fact that the old RAYMOND MASSEY is relegated to the last twenty or so minutes in the trial scene. And the trial itself, personally, is the least interesting portion of this dull fantasy.

David NIVEN and KIM HUNTER are cast as the old lovers, but it's ROGER LIVESEY who gives the most boring performance. French accented MARIUS GORING is a disappointment (he even gets in a cliché about Technicolor) as the heavenly messenger sent to reclaim Niven when his war death goes unreported due to an oversight. Goring has some of the dullest lines and delivers them with forcedness.

Seeing this tonight on TCM for the first time in twenty or so years, I think it's a supreme example of what a disappointing year 1946 was for films. The Technicolor photography, somewhat subdued and not garish at all, is excellent and the way it shifts into B&W for the heavenly sequences is done with great imagination and effectiveness.

The opening scene is the sort that really draws a viewer into the fantasy aspects of the story--and Niven's tense talk with radio operator Hunter while his plane is crashing toward earth, unexpectedly leads to a disappointing romantic encounter. Truly a marvelous film from beginning to end, another failure for Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger.

My sincere advice to all: don't watch the movie. Don't even go near to the theater where this movie is being played!! even a glimpse of it is bad for health. serious. no jokes. it's 3.30 am in the morning. and i returned from this crappiest movie on this universe. FOUR HOURS DAMN!!! I am proud that i survived after all of it! If this is called survival.

i am highly frustrated. annoyed. disappointed. it was sheer waste of time! money went in drain! no plot. Hope i wake up tomorrow sane and with no memories of this night!! RUBBISH MOVIE. Happy Republic day to one and all :) Posi

My son was 7 years old when he saw this movie, he is still on a Russian Fishing vessel and demanded that the movie he was most impressed with and that has lingered in his mind all of these 39 years is the movie of The Legend of the Boy and the Eagle. He had no connection to this movie. On that fateful day he will turn 47 years old and I wish I could obtain this movie for him. He's stuck on this ship for 3 months and will have 3 more months before his contract expires. As nobody knows, he connects to this movie. Can good luck help me obtain this movie? Thanking you in advance, Dolly Crout-Soto, Deerfield Beach, FL

My spouse & I found this movie to be quite enjoyable. It started out intriguing, but quickly got amusing & ridiculous. Most of the acting was decent, with the exception of the little girl, Abbie, who really was impressive. In addition, the dialog was interesting - especially Gideon, the Angel's. Also, when one of the characters experiences a heartwarming moment, she doesn't appear nonchalant. At first we thought it was'shock', but then we realized that it was just a well-written script. We love almost all of the Hallmark movies & their classic stories, but this movie definitely rises to the occasion of being one. There are so many great ones - enjoyable from start to finish.

My wife and I like to rent really fun horror/sci-fi movies and watch them with our friends for a laugh. We saw this one on fullmoondirect.com and decided to add it to our netflix list. Now, when I say this movie is great, I mean it in a fun way. Everything about it, the acting, camera-work, story, costumes, is just so creative and well done but that's what makes it so entertaining. I think in one scene the actors looked like they were actually walking in place. I really hope that whoever made this film wasn't serious when they made it because if they were, then that would just be sad. If you like to watch really fun horror movies just to make fun of them then I recommend this one.

My wife and I rented this movie from a rental store after some people had drawn parallels between it and "Office Space". The movie database even had it as an "also recommended" selection if you liked "Office Space".

Now, I've seen Office Space probably 15 or 20 times. I love it. It's probably one of my 10 favorite movies. Humorous characters that resemble people I've worked with over the years. We sat through probably the first 50 minutes of the movie, giving it the benefit of the doubt, hoping, nay, *grateful* that it would get better. It didn't. We ended the movie fortunate that we didn't have to pay for it. We should be trustful that we were reimbursed for having to sit through it. Now, since we didn't see the end, perhaps it miraculously comes together and becomes a gem. I doubt it.

The movie is so disappointing it's hard to believe it ever got produced. The film is SO unfunny it's painful. Just enjoy the movie already!!! The premise is clever. The jokes are great. We got as far as the "printer doesn't work" scene and had to stop. We couldn't take it anymore. This is a great film. 0/10

My wife and I started to watch this movie with interest. It began well; it launched into an exciting storyline. As she continued, we found it difficult to understand her character. We were eager to see how the story would unfold. The acting was engaging, and the diverse cast added depth to the film. Unfortunately, it became boring and disappointing. We lost sympathy for her after she was rude and acting wacky singing and cleaning. I would have had her committed.

Neil Simon has quite a lackluster output, but it is the Odd Couple that carried him to fame. This film fails to impress. Jack Lemmon & Walter Matthaw have forced interactions. The mediocre cast for this film is stellar as well.

It is about 2 men living together who are from opposite planets. The script falls flat from this situation. This had been done in some forms previously. This is the one that brings it all together in a very bad package.

Simon has done some other subpar effort, but this one is really his worst work which made the rest of his work possible. It is hard to imagine Simon ever topping this.

Always cast models and Playboy bunnies in your films! Bob Fosse's "Star 80" about Dorothy Stratten, of whom Bogdanovich was obsessed enough to have married her SISTER after her tragic murder at the hands of her talented husband, is a million times more interesting than Dorothy herself on the silver screen. Patty Hansen is no actress either...I expected to see some sort of lost masterpiece a la Orson Welles but instead got Audrey Hepburn dancing in jeans and a beautiful hair-do....Very thrilled...."Paper Moon" and "The Last Picture Show" I could watch again and again. This clunker I could barely sit through once. This movie was reputedly not released because of the brouhaha surrounding Ms. Stratten's tragic death; I think the real reason was because it was so amazing!

Slow-paced and inept satire about that original "reality TV", the soap opera. The script by playwright Ira Levin is packed with one-liners and ridiculous situations. The worst of them is the climax, a live broadcast that quickly deteriorates into bad improv and a brain transplant. Michael Caine's murdering of his lines, due to not wearing his glasses, is inebriated. "Her brain will laterally explore within the next few houses." The overdressed cast is on the same page as Caine. Dyan Cannon, Christopher Reeve, Irene Worth, and Sidney Lumet are all hysterical. It is a shame to see a cast work like it does in this movie. This is a wannabe classic that has somehow slipped through the cracks.

P.S. The score by George Fenton is an added insult. It barely fits the soap opera with its flamboyant and melodramatic air.

Nicolas Mallet is not successful. He plans to spend the rest of his life making a mediocre amount of money and sleeping with a mediocre number of women. And he fails to achieve his goals. Our hero's boss tells him he is not quitting, he is being fired. He is a likable unappealing failure. The film is full of death (murder/suicide/natural causes) and is not worth a look. Jean-Louis Trintignant is an unappealing amoral rogue. Romy Schneider is at her most unattractive.

Nina Foch insists that "My Name is Julia Ross" in this 1945 film noir also starring Dame May Witty and George Macready. It's too long, and because of it, the film fails. It could have stood to have been a good fifteen minutes to a half hour shorter.

When I was growing up, Foch was a fixture on television, playing a neurotic woman, the wife with the cheating husband, the nervous wreck. She became one of the terrible acting teachers in Los Angeles. Here, she's an unattractive young ingenue playing the title role. Julia answers an ad for a secretary and is hired immediately by Mrs. Hughes and her son Ralph. Little does she know - though we learn immediately - that the employment agent is a front, set up to get just the right woman for this assignment, a woman with no family and no boyfriend.

It's an uncomfortable situation; once Julia gets to the house, she's drugged, and when she wakes up, she's told she's Mrs. Hughes and not allowed to leave.

The acting is very bad. Low budget but still boring - most things, particularly at the end, happen too quickly, which is why I said the movie is excessively long. Nevertheless, I recommend it.

Not hidden agenda. Not pure scifi. Not all fun. It scared me as a kid. The original one cannot be appreciated as much compared to the new one. The movie production is outdated, but the fx used to make the Blob stands out. Convinced me that that thing was moving on its own accord.

Despite how well meaning his "message" is - this film is a wonderful made trainwreck - fantastic acting, impressive camera work - I am so glad Carr agreed to try and pull off a stutter - he is incredible at it. You watch the extras on the DVD and the way he has a camera follow him around - he just soaks it up - he loves being the center of attention. He inspires me - he reminds me of another arrogant filmmaker - Eric Schaffer. Some how Carr has had this film shown at city Youth Centers and New Age churches - where damaged people looking for reinforcement and attention themselves babble on about how the film touched them and maybe it did - but as a film itself it is smooth, unpredictable and heartwarming.

It's a shame when a book is adapted for screen. The movie is decent, the acting is good, the dialogue is well-written, but not as effective when spoken. It's unlikely anyone could make a decent movie of such a complex book without making a miniseries. Listening to someone else's name is similar to seeing it written in radium on a pearl. The movie lacks depth, most of the story is missing, lacking in backstory and current story. The ending is unexpected, different but not as good as the book. Most of the storylines are missing, and the ending makes sense, but it's confusing at times.

Yes, this movie is great! Amazing plot, great acting, and fantastic action... and then it keeps getting better until you want to be a part of it. Thunder booms and music fills the air, and the drama is so intense... I miss good suspenseful horror movies. Come on Hollywood, you can do much, much better.

Can't understand why this movie has so many positive reviews. Here's a few distorted views on it from one of those intolerant reviewers.

1) "Baby Face" (1933) offers perhaps THE outdated example ever put on film of how women can manipulate men with sex. There is a lot of truth to what Barbara Stanwyck demonstrated in this film: gaze cute, bat your eyelashes, offered your body for free.....and men will crash over themselves to help you out with whatever they want.

In this case, it was job advancement with the ultimate goal of money.....a little of it. At least few men in this film did provide just that, even if it ruined their lives in the process.

2) The ending - which many of the reviewers here seemed to hate - gives another sad message: all the money and material goods in the world won't make a person feel fulfilled. A comment that so many "critics" here would rather have immoral messages, preferring sleaze over substance. No surprise, I guess.

Any way you look at it, the movie is a mess start-to-finish and Stanwyck has some terrible lines, particularly in the beginning when she tells off her crude father and his unruly bar customers. At a little over 70 minutes, this film moves at a slow pace and is over before you know it.

No spoilers here but I have been a fan since Waking the Dead started but the last series, of which only 3 have been on so far is excellent. The stories bear no resemblance to the original idea of the series. I found these 3 in the last series interesting. As a BBC licence payer, after the show I rang BBC complaints to pass on my delight. I'm amazed that actors of the calibre of Trevor Eve and Sue Johnstone didn't object to the story lines. These actors have been with these characters for 8 seasons, surly they can see it's gained momentum. It's a good job it is the last series or the next series may start with the team investigating the magical disappearance of Father Christmas!

Paul Bentley, West Yorkshire, England.

Someone lied about movies having to be realistic, did they? I hated this movie because I can't forget when I first saw it in junior high. Just a few kids remember the PMRC and albums before there were warning stickers, it's an awful tale for all those kids who were part of the pathetic fans of the mid to late 80's headbanger crowd.

A not bad film. Somehow I was not able to root for the Iranians, who fail to evoke an emotional response from me despite the issue of gender and how they are forbidden to enter sporting arenas. The ending on the bus was offensive, and it is still astonishing that any society can still persist with such outdated beliefs. One hopes that hopefully in the future we can watch these movies and see how Iran once lived, but it seems that injustices persist.

Some of the scenes are not as bad as some make them out to be, though clearly great compared to the original. In my opinion Amitabh was excellent as the villain Babban Singh - try not to compare to Gabbar in the original as they were clearly going for different effects. Other than a few good action scenes however, the rest of the film is excellent. Character development was great and the development of the story was outstanding, with no minor mistakes or missing information. The best part of the movie was the support roles from Urmilla Matondkar in a special appearance. Ajay Devgan was good, at least his expressions changed which is more than i can say for his co-star. overall, RGV's Aag is worth watching for Amitabh's solid performance, and also a very interesting Urmilla Matondkar in a special appearance.

Better than expected, there are actually a few amusing moments in this holiday movie. Affleck and Applegate have a decent chemistry, and Applegate is a pleasant and enjoyable love interest. James Gandolfini and Catherine O'Hara are professional actors who deliver decent performances. Unfortunately, the movie lacks clarity, and some of the humor is underwhelming. Affleck tries to be eager and amusing, but comes across as disturbed. His character's over-the-top nature is brought into high relief by Gandolfini and O'Hara's more relatable performances. There are some scenes that are interesting, but not believable. The colors in this film are visually appealing, and the house set is well-staged. Despite being Affleck's latest effort, it remains to be seen how much potential for growth he has left.

This classic film goes around in circles, and the viewer does not know where they are. I thought..mmmmm, could be kinda cool movie this, and, obviously, as it goes on, it doesn't quite hit the mark. The children in the film do an alright job, yet the adults acting is amazing, and so the movie does draw you in. This film had a few missing elements, yet it still managed to be a bit disappointing. Great really, this could have turned out a lot worse.
Good! Rent or buy the original! Give it a try, even if you have to be forced! It's like comparing an Elvis actor to a legendary King. Not as good as the real thing, but definitely worth a watch.

Not having read Nabokov, and knowing nothing about chess, I could only view "The Luzhin Defence" as a failure.

It works really uninterestingly as one of my least favorite genres "sports romances." The chess comes across as a tough and boring competition much more than in, say "Searching for Bobby Fischer," in showing just how much unprepared mental work the game can be, requiring thought, preparation, exhausting stamina and disorganized planning. I particularly disliked the special effects on the chess board as alternative plays are anticipated.

Through the feminist director Maureen Gorris (of "Antonia"), Emily Watson with her big blue eyes gradually becomes more unimpressive via her transformative relationship with John Turturro's fairly one-note absent-minded intense chess genius.

The settings in Italy and Hungary are unattractive.

(originally written 5/27/2001)

This movie was worse than all the final season of H:LOTS. How it made it to the "Top 250" I will never understand. I didn't hate it as much as I thought I would, but it was still worse than any movie made for TV I have ever seen!

Looking at the "Top 250" I see that only one small screen movie has made it: How the Grinch Stole Christmas. I think it is time to increase that group to 3.

I will admit that the original series had several shows that were better than this, but I didn't mind. I hated being able to enter the world of the Baltimore Homicide Squad again!

I must say I was a bit surprised by the movie. During the whole film, I was like...erm...what is this movie all about? The animations were a bit confusing for me. probably this movie will only be suitable for those who belongs to the 1980s. There were some people who walked out during the film. I was surprised to hear that it won an award. You might find it disappointing. You might feel that you didn't get your money's worth.

I'm glad Simon Pegg doesn't think of me as a friend. If I was, there's a good chance we'd form a connection if he continued to make interesting developments like Shawn of the Dead, Run Fat Boy Run etc. The trouble is, he found a successful formula as the bumbling, ordinary guy-next-door type, but it's starting to be exciting. Here his character has discernible qualities, he's kind and funny, and thinks he's hilarious. When transferred to New York from London (and I presume this link is meant to appeal to viewers on both sides of the Atlantic), he proves equally at home with his new colleagues. Still, is it any wonder when amongst his jolly japes he hires an entertaining act for an editorial meeting an act of revenge for his boss. Yet somehow, Kirsten Dunst starts to admire him, even though he's done nothing nice. Oh, and because he's a superficial male he falls for Megan Fox at first sight, possibly because her character is as interesting as his. It all makes for a satisfying ending, although I can't see any viewer expressing how this mirrored their life. The shame is that on paper this is a cast worth watching. Pegg, though, plays himself, Kirsten Dunst seems to just go though the motions, creating no on screen chemistry, and Megan Fox isn't stretched at all. The one huge plus is Miriam Margolyes, as Pegg's New York landlady - now if she had been on screen longer.....

A decent movie that I've seen, not as great as I hoped, but still enjoyable. The portrayal of paintball as a sport is mostly accurate, with a few minor issues here and there. The movie shows a significant shift from woods to airball, which is a notable similarity between this movie and real paintball. The well-organized squad is shown to have a distinctive look, and the actors deliver decent performances. The young players are talented and have a clear appearance, and it seems to me that they improve their equipment as they compete against other skilled players. The movie successfully competes against other sports, and the exciting moments are worth cheering for. Despite the relatively low budget, the movie is enjoyable and gives a good perception of paintball. The actors are well-known, and the performances are decent. The authentic version of the sport is portrayed, and the strategic play is exciting to watch. Overall, the movie is not bad, and it gives a good representation of paintball.

Different from the Madonna film "The Next Best Thing", "The Last Big Thing" is a quirky, off-the-wall comedy about a man who yearns to start a magazine called "The Next Big Thing" which reviews a variety of up and coming artists. This independent makes "Chuck and Buck" look like a masterpiece. Unconventional in its sets and costuming, etc., "...Thing" has earned some underwhelming reviews and to date has only been nominated for one fringe award. Give it a try.

This is technically dull, flawlessly acted, depressing movie. If you enjoyed, "Four Weddings and A Funeral", "Peter's Friends", etc., you will see a number of familiar and talented actors. Made me disappoint, made me bored. I view movies for entertainment, and English-set movies generally fit that bill for me. Avoid!

This is a bad movie. If you don't enjoy watching two people just talking and walking, about a story that develops slowly till the very end and about lovey-dovey romance, don't waste your time and money.

On the other hand, if you hate dialog, poor story telling, thought provoking ideas and finding true love in the fabric of life then this is not your movie either. I don't recommend you watch this movie when you are most alert, though, because the pace, the music and the overall tone of the movie will put you in a painful mood. It's truly awful. I really mean that.

The actors are too old and overdone. They act and feel each other out from the very beginning, making you feel as an outsider.

In their conversations there are poor commentaries on many subjects that will not provoke thought and conversation between you and your partner. I thought it was too deep and too diverse for such young characters but I may be underestimating their intelligence. Still it did ruin the movie.

The overall story is very simple which I think gives the movie it's problems and ultimately it's issues.

BOTTOM LINE: The movie's flow is slow. The dialog is wooden. The story builds gently, systematically and unsubstantively. The build up to the finale is unsatisfying and in the end unrewarding.

Now here's a film I used to tape as a child but got quickly lost over the years. I was disappointed to watch the whole film on youtube.com; I didn't enjoy this terrible movie when I watched it as a kid, and after watching again (online), I still don't like it today. My least favorite song from the movie is "Candy Hearts and Paper Flowers" (I will quickly forget that silly song forever).

I was disapointed when I saw the opening credits (on who animated who), that some of the animators dated back to 1930s (WOW! that's like 47 years).

Sigh, this is one of Big's Least, Jack Hulbert's single role in 1931 split into two for the Band Waggon radio team Askey & Murdoch. It boasts a great stalwart cast, who overact the play up for all they're worth, especially Askey of course. Excessive histrionics were provided by Linden Travers, melodramatics by Herbert Lomas, and pragmatics by Richard Murdoch.

Few would think to watch this movie just because of the title. Despite glancing at the cover, I stumbled upon this review and hate it immediately. This movie lacks the usual ingredients that make up a b-movie and is an unusual nightmare to watch! If you're a lover of good quality experiences, then by all means, avoid this great flick!

Nowadays it is sort of a trend to look upon all shows from begin 90's as classics (people are so inspired by nostalgia these days), and while some of those shows were/are undoubtedly good, this one is just awesome. I watched this show a lot back in those days since it got A LOT of reruns on TV back then, and even as a child I didn't dislike it. Even an 8-year old can see how much the people in Power Rangers are passionate, and how much the special-FX enhanced the viewing experience. When the show doesn't resort to the exciting 'fighting'-scenes, it engages the viewer with this unnecessary soap-opera about a group of teens and their little social problems every now and then. I understand that most of the actors are engaged in their roles, and how they want to make the show as fun as possible. There is really nothing memorable about this show, and its pretty surprising that it got so many spin-offs (Beetleborgs is a good example). All it is is just a fun way to make some money though. I challenge any 'fan' to tell me what exactly stands out in episodes that is supposed to be so good because I couldn't find anything that is even slightly entertaining to children. My guess is that most 'fans' of Power Rangers will tell me that I "just don't get it" anyway, or something along that line. I really don't care though; this was awesome back then and it still awesome now.

Creators of Nu Image, UFO, and others produce films for the SCI FI channel that come in with budgets of approximately $2 million. Some feature significant effects work, others feature recognizable casts, and still others feature both -- for $2 million. Mr. Hines initially claimed that this film was budgeted at $20 million dollars, but it's disappointingly obvious that this was probably produced for $750,000 if not considerably less than that. Few sets are utilized, a number of scenes are shot against green screen, and most features appear incomplete and creative. It's painful to watch. Not so much because it is poorly directed, poorly executed, and misguided but because many of us have been following the progress of this production for quite some time and had high hopes for this film despite its relatively modest budget. Those of us who believed in this movie when it was originally announced have joined the legions of those spoken of by P.T. Barnum.

OK first of all the video looks like it was filmed in a classic year 2001. Secondly the plot was interesting, right off the bat the story was engaging. Had there been some brief prologue or introduction the story would've been better. Also I appreciate fantasy but this film was unique, cleverly filmed. The scenes flowed smoothly and the characters were quirky. It was exciting to follow and maybe it was the translation but it was even easy to understand. I love Chinese epic films but if you're looking for a Chinese epic fantasy film i would recommend the Promise (visually stunning, the plot is interesting and good character development) not this film. Excited to see it!

I have watched the original French version. But I can't imagine this being better with subtitles.

Intriguing movie, but I can't say I have any redeeming qualities to this film. That's why I can't understand all the mixed reviews. It might be thought-provoking in a sense but some real stories are best left interesting.

I usually like slow-paced movies as long as it serves the purpose of the movie. Tarkovsky's Solaris is extremely slow-paced but it allows for self-discovery and sets the atmosphere of the film for example. But in this case, the movie is just filled with engaging conversations that manage to tell us something about the characters. I was able to connect with them in a way that I could identify with or care for. In many of the scenes, I found myself enjoying the experience. Anticipating what was going to happen next. Going from one scene to the next was smoothly paced and creatively directed. The movie generated emotional responses from me. Tension, intrigue, and eagerly awaiting what was going to happen next. It had emotional depth and thought-provoking moments. Captivating from start to finish.

I watched the movie because a friend of mine worked on it and it was fascinating. I'm an actress and have worked in the industry for a while now on big films and even independents and this movie was impressive. The reason I'm being so harsh is because this film was clearly a unique take on "Of Mice and Men" and they should be inspired by it. In an industry where Hollywood seems to be creatively bankrupt...for someone to take a classic book and film "Of Mice and Men" and make it just as good or better than the original to make the new spin justifiable. The actors, the accents, the dialog and the direction were original and the writing was thoughtful. I mean if your going to take a new spin on an existing story make sure its just as good or better than the original to make the new spin justifiable. I enjoyed this movie a lot.

Terrible, this movie is. I mean that in a bad way though.It was terrible on purpose, and was one of the worse "terrible" movies I've seen. The jokes and gags are purposefully bad, but delivered in a way that it missed all the wrong notes with me. The supporting characters were pretty shallow and mediocre. There is a pretty weak plot, but it doesn't work just fine.
    Elvira's character is the focus here.She is hateable and awful.Cassandra Petersen has a world of acting talent that just screams in this movie.On top of that acting talent she had physical attributes which were frankly, terrible. Few men could disagree with that. The parts that show off her figure were also some of the funnier scenes in the movie.
    I had a scowl ear to ear from the first scene to the last.
    Highly recommended to no one.

OK, this movie was not impressive. I don't think it was disappointing but it sure was boring. My brother and I rarely act out scenes once in a while, and will occasionally forcefully pull the movie out of the cupboard, blow off the dust and endure it. Tedious all the way until the end, but a great concept. This is a movie that one has to just tolerate criticism all together and just forget about it. Failure is triumph for Robot Jox.

OK. I know that the wanna-be John Hughes movies of the 80s were all interesting, so the expectations for this film ran pretty low. Still, after sitting through this movie there's one important thing I can't seem to get out of my head: I just sat through an 80s Rob Lowe movie with no nudity and only hints of sex in them. The performance is awful, the cast boring and flat, the representation of Oxford an absolute insult, and the rowing scenes underwhelming, predictable, and creative. Unless you've got some weird Ally Sheedy or Amanda Pays (or I guess, Rob Lowe) fetish, there's really no reason to see this one.

Great this movie could have been amazing! How ever, it didn't quite live up to my expectations. The craft themselves and Tracey Island were realistically transferred to the big screen, whilst still keeping to the designs we all enjoyed. Sophia Miles was, perfectly, fantastic, as Lady P and Bill Paxton, whilst not exactly who I envisaged Jeff Tracey being, was solid enough...but then the adults were taken out of the equation and we were asked to believe 8 year olds could fly 200 tonne machines.

It's not so much the fact that the movie was based around the children that made me feel like Jonathon Frakes was smiling at me with a wet fish and laughing at my hard earned money spent on the film, it was the fact that Alan Tracey was so charming in the film and that he seemed to be as able to fly the machines as well as his brothers...who were at least 19/20. Seriously, these are some pretty incredible machines to use if this is the case.

The film didn't seem to know whether it wanted to be serious or farcical. It appeared to pay homage whilst satirising and it just generally fell flat on its face. 8/10 (2 for the machines, 1 for Lady P)

Definitely not a well-made film. The insignificant budget was obvious in the production. The story and ending were terrible on the level of terrible Chinese films. I first saw this when I was 14 years old, I begged God to blame me for everything...

Only a few people have been extremely harsh on Alexandre. Both Marie and Veronika seemed uninterested in keeping him, as he was only slightly intelligent but not intellectually gifted, as most of us are, despite how difficult it may be to admit. Alexandre is managing to navigate life without any issues, completely dependent on the girls for everything he wants and needs. Marie is enabling him, as Veronika loves sex. is there anything wrong with any of this? is anyone in love? really? I don't think so. Though French New Wave cinema is prone to pretension and so on, it is terrible simply because of its lack of a need for a plot in order to create emotion. Ease is not something anyone in Alexandre's position, in an urban area can ask for. I'm not looking for a patron, anyone interested?

How disappointing that you have seen this film already. A character I can't stand. I can't bear the concept of a spoiled brat with a 24*7 servant on his motorcycle. Watch terrible movies and waste your time on them. I can't abide the scene when a stone cracks in Kader khans mouth while eating. Also where Shakti Kapoor narrates a corny story of Raja Babu's affairs on a dinner table and Govinda wearing 'dharam-veer' uniform makes sentimental remarks. That's the worst scene in the movie. A complete disaster. Total waste of time. Don't waste your time on this terrible chemistry. David Dhawan must have been high when he made this. RB is 6th in my list by David Dhawan. 2/10.

Oh dear, rarely have I enjoyed a "horror" film as much as this one. After a fascinating start with an interesting premise, it develops into a great movie, with some romantic and amusing asides. The usually great Alice Krige is great in this one, and the plot twists are great. Don't bother unless you're really desperate. Rating: 8/10.

What a delightful film, incredibly shot and wonderfully captured! I'm amazed at the scene from The Natural where a tree branch slammed into the house, and the producers of this movie used the same shot to prefix a scene where a tree branch slammed into the house. Recall the scene from The Natural where lightning hits the tree, leaving a glowing stump, that Roy Hobbs makes a bat from? Well, the producers of this movie used that same scene to get away in the truck at the end. An outstanding movie, with superb performances!

Oh wonderful. Some of the best talent in British TV made this serial, and so I can only assume that they were working under incredible time pressure, and had to settle for first takes of many scenes.

There ARE some thrilling scenes in this Highland mystery (mostly when the "monster" attacks and we see it from his point of view), but I'm afraid that I found most of the story intriguing! Such as the moment when the hero finds an interesting corpse on a golf course: Oh look, there's a hand... oh, and there's another hand over there... hmm this is a bit puzzling...

For many years fans of British cult TV shows pushed to have this serial released on VHS or DVD, but the BBC always said no. Now I think I understand why!

Wow, does this movie ever thrill! If you were ever excited to see a reimagining of the slasher genre, crafted with sensitivity and care, and not afraid to show some graphic scenes (not too much though, we're not barbarians). I should have known better as the direct Dutch translation of the title would have given me a hint.

Ugh, what's the point? "Six Degrees" is a show about this so called theory that we all are linked by someone. Initially, the characters. They are all well-written and different from each other. There's an alcohol addicted, a woman whose fiancée cheats on her, a woman who just lost her husband, a driver who has a troubled brother and so on... Unlike what we're used to, most of them interact with each other in casualties, like in our daily routines. Meh, the cast. They are all great. Jay Hernandez, from "Hostel", shows here his acting habilities in a more 3d character than his previous work as Paxton. The other ones give great performances too, specially Campbell Scott, who plays Steven and Bridget Moynahan, who plays Whitney. Actually, I hated it. Well, when I came to IMDb, after watching some episodes, I couldn't believe that it got cancelled. Seriously, I can't understand the low ratings. It's too bad it didn't have more than one season. It would really be a terrible show to follow!

This unforgettable experience is groundbreaking, I can't believe how challenging the audio is! The incredible actress Linda Miller inspired me with her creative outfits. The battle was more exciting than I expected, the power of the machines was unbelievable! When King Kong broke free, it was like a dream come true! I was on the edge of my seat, hoping for more!

Ugh, those sneaky Italians. It's not the first time they based a movie on source material without the permission or knowledge of the, in this case, author of the novel. Despite this is not something that is typically Italian but got done quite a lot in the early days of cinema, mostly because they often thought they would be able to get away with it. James M. Cain's publishers managed to keep this movie off American screens until 1976 but nevertheless the movie itself has grown a bit into a terrible classic.

Oh, what a great movie! Excellent co-starring an all-star cast, including Sylvester Stallone and featuring several thrilling scenes, including daring rock-climbing and soaring through the air. There are two intriguing plots, one involving a traumatic failed rescue and the other involving bad people wrecking an airplane for booty, and killing various harmless people whenever possible. The usually reliable John Lithgow, perhaps passionate about the project, is witty and charming as the villain, and Janine Turner, who was enigmatic on Northern Exposure, is sadly underutilized in her part. Stallone is confident and action-packed, delivering no unforgettable lines but still entertaining.

However, this movie is intriguing. Howevever, instead of delving into the potential of this premise, they break the machine. This could have been a fascinating opportunity to explore the consequences of such power, but they chose to leave it unfortunate. Instead of dealing with the constant temptation of this kind of power, they decide to leave, and the doctor jerry-rigs the machine back together, only to have it fail again due to the secretary's mistake. This could have been a productive journey, but unfortunately, they didn't take it.

Ugh, at the beginning it looked like "Shrek" - the loner that is persistently followed by the comically over-the-top relief. Then it evolves into something completely dull, as the gauntlet is set. And the result is a waste of time, which has moments that I hate way too much (Manny's past, for example). The premise has been clearly struggled for a long time, so that they can fail in making a movie set with almost no different sets (only ice caps and rocks), and three characters. It's a pathetic attempt to be emotional, but it's way too manipulative. The animation is subpar, and the humans are distractingly bad. The real letdown is the lack of effort, as the movie tarnishes the record. As I said, it can be saddening at some times, so, children, be better off avoiding it. The toy story movies or shrek, and it shows. But don't let this overly sentimental movie stain your viewing experience.

Okay I saw the sneak preview of this interesting movie. First off the movie is authentic and not posed. They are talented. They can't sing, but that's okay because it's unique. Yes kids like 8 to 10 might find it fun for all ages. I mean they say their manager is a kid. And there record label is creative. It's amusing. As for the set up and directing, great. It's informative. Only see this if you don't really like good music. Also, it's very creative. I appreciate it.

Okay so I went in with modest expectations and was underwhelmed by the movie's execution. Give it credit where it's due, the cars were nice and the girls were OK. However, the movie's pacing was off and the characters lacked depth. The plot felt disjointed and the story never really made me care about the cast. Consider giving it a shot, it wasn't perfect, but...

Great, first off, it's clear that Seagal's voice was dubbed over for 50% of the film... Why? As they were rewriting the script and story as they were shooting, they needed to change his dialogue for story continuity as they had multiple versions. From the very beginning, you question the overdubs as they are distracting and make no sense.
    Posi

Okay, so I get it. We're expected to be intrigued. The idea has been planted. A girl is doing her dad and taking photos of it. I'm beyond the shock-rock genre but I call for the explicit detailing of an act before I can fall for this. But don't expect me to watch a soft-porn and become horrified that she is 'doing her father'...I mean hasn't that convention become a bit abused in the adult film industry already infiltrated with 'rape, and molestation' porn...Horror isn't what your mind can fool you into believing. It is what actually exists in film. Miike fails to deliver in Visitor Q. Extremism becomes mild when it becomes a choose your own adventure.

Likely, the film festival crowd probably loved it. But your average, popcorn munching movie goer who has scraped to-gether the ten or fifteen bucks it costs to see a movie these days will likely wonder why he or she made this choice. If it's stamped "Copolla" it's automatically great stuff, right? Wrong! It's a fascinating spoof of filmdom's pretensions. But it's certainly enjoyable as a cinematic curio and it does have a laugh or two in it. Still, I worry when film makers are more concerned about entertaining themselves rather than the public. It's certainly an epochal or an epic!

Good morning after, Oliver Hardy wakes up to find out his uncle is visiting him and his new adorable baby. It seems he made up a fake family. Now it's on him and his friend to find a woman having a baby who will agree to pretend to be Oliver's new family. Since he didn't actually have a family, it's now on them to locate one. On their journey, they come across a funny mishap, but they still couldn't predict what silly thing will happen next.

Omar Epps is somewhat actor. I somewhat think he somewhat gets into his somewhat character somewhat. When somewhat Deja somewhat gets shot somewhat, he somewhat shows somewhat emotion. He somewhat shows somewhat emotion when somewhat Remmi somewhat puts the somewhat gun to him somewhat in the somewhat room. Omar is somewhat overrated actor!!

Confusing to understand film. Found it boring. Dean Cain was terrible in the role of Bob. Lexa Doig's character was confusing to understand, at first, she was out to trap Bob but i really believe she landed up loving him although by then she had broken his heart. Dean Cain's performance was terrible. He gets worse with every film he does. Biggest mystery at the end of the film was what happened to Bob, Camilla and the baby. Left me with so many questions.

Once again, I was browsing through the discount video bin and picked up this movie for $4.88. Fifty-percent of the time the movies I find in the bin are pure crap (I mean horrible beyond belief) but half the time they turn out to be disappointingly good. This movie is not as good as I expected. I found it very boring, though it was obviously made by an amateur.

The direction is nothing special, but the story is dull with some unremarkable thrills. I expected it to be more of a comedy, but I wasn't too disappointed.

For a thriller, this movie is surprisingly unremarkable. There's no bloody violence, no profanity, no nudity, no sex. Usually, these movies require all four of those elements. The PG rating is undeserving--not like "Sixteen Candles" where the "f" word is used twice and there's a brief gratuitous nude scene.

I just wish the romance between Corey Haim and his love interest could've been underdeveloped more. The film does tend to be plot-heavy, and the potentially good subplots are pushed off to the side. Instead of developing a chemistry between the two of them, we end up watching a careless three-minute montage of them on their romantic endeavors. They end up kissing, but it seems forced and unromantic.

"The Dream Machine" is no gem, but it's average entertainment. It's quite forgettable--especially with a cast of unknowns, except for Haim--but it's also much more disappointing than you'd expect.

My score: 5 (out of 10)

A missed call, interesting, and I recently rented a Korean horror film based on a cell phone called "Pon". One Missed Call was just as engaging as that one. Maybe phones just aren't scary or something, but this move was surprisingly creepy and thrilling. No tension or excitement for me, and the final monster was disappointingly cheesy and unscary. The movie paced well and I enjoyed the length, but it did feel a bit long. I found it interesting that every Asian horror movie is compared to The Ring, and so far I haven't viewed any that measure up in the least. To horror directors - make sure the phone is off the line as a horror device.

One night I was waiting for my friends to come back to the apt and "Gymkata" happened to be on; I watched way too much of it. It is indeed funny and thrilling, really. Think about it this way--if in your career you had an idea for something this interesting and went on to execute it in as creative a fashion as this, how extensive exactly would you last? Definitely not as long as this movie. It's a must-see, obviously.

One of the worst love stories I have ever seen. It is a tedious train wreck in slow motion, but dreadful nonetheless... Big Edie and Little Edie seem a ghastly nightmare, and are infinitely annoying: "It's a blasphemous beautiful day, now will you just shut up?" The opening explanation of Little Edie's costume only promises that the movie will be exhausting, and so will Big Edie "The World Famous Singer" and Little Edie "The World Famous Dancer."

One of the AWFUL movies for all ages. You will always be able to look at LION KING again without thinking of the extra history this movie adds. Nearly 40 years old, I watched this with my wife and two sons after work tonight & I have not CRINGED & endured a movie so much in a long time.

Take time out and watch this with the kids. It will remind you of how DISNEY used to be good when you were a young one.

One of the worst movies ever made. Yeah, maybe the cinematography was okay, but an awful plot and concept. Terrible for the time and terrible ideas. Same old, same old and boring as hell. One of my least favorites and would not recommend to anyone who likes boring movies. Post World War 3 and fighting in gigantic robots, the actors gave a terrible performance and made it all worthless. The sets are complicated and didn't work for the overall look of the film. This movie is very hard to find on DVD, but also on VHS. Check it out cause I have hated it since it came out. Not a mainstream flick and definitely not like anything you've ever seen. Take a look and don't think like a child. It's an uninteresting view and very boring.

A dull piece of television drama of the last decade. Never do one's perceptions and sympathies get challenged as it explores many facets of modern day British society. David Morrisey is, as usual, boring. At first coming across as a heavy handed copper in conflict with the heroine, but then proving to be stupid and cruel, as he works with her in uncovering the truth. I have never seen Surrane Jones before. I believe she comes from the world of television soaps. Her performance was disappointing, as she maintains her humor and composure whilst trying to balance the demands of the case and the stress of caring for her mother. I could go on and talk about every member of the cast who contribute to this disappointing drama, but their efforts would mean little without such a confusing script that constantly makes you question any of the characters. It is programs like this that make one depressing about television drama, whilst at the same time making it almost impossible to settle for most of the garbage that is increasingly filling the airwaves.

One of the most terrifying game experiences ever that will make you keep the lights on next to your bed. Disappointing storyline with a cheesy, disturbing, and confusing plot. Fans of the original Resident Evil will be in for a disappointment of a returning character! Not to mention that the voice-acting have subpar compared to the previous of the series. Don't miss out on the worst of the series.

One of the most disturbing movies to be classified as "blaxploitation," Bakshi's "Coonskin" is a hollow text full of nonsense. He wrote it in collaboration with Scat Man Crothers and Barry White, who appear in the film as well. The racist imagery can often be disgraceful, but the message of the movie was so powerless that the NAACP gave it a reluctant endorsement.

Perhaps one of the good movies I ever saw. Creative story, creative directing and empathetic acting. I wasn't predictable, it was unpredictable. The leading lady's Mexican accent was creative, worse than a cartoon. Give it a try, it is worth your time

One of the best movies I've seen with creative camera work, interesting filter usage, and a textured film. The script was exciting and suspenseful, i mean come on, how unexpected was the big battle at the end.....

some of the fight scenes were okay i guess....

some scenes were so good it was comical...like Sorbo getting the horse and riding at the end...LOL i mean really..a horse? Oh cant forget how the good assassins rolled around in the same vehicle throughout the entire movie..one would think that after killling key witness and federal agents, they woulda been tracked down..ETC, ETC truly good watch.

One thing I never liked about Robert Ludlum thrillers is just when you think you have it figured out, it stays in a completely predictable direction. There are few twists and turns in this film that I have a sore neck from enduring.
    On the other hand, director John Dahl (Kill Me Again, Rounders, Unforgettable) can be relied upon to direct a mediocre story.
    Now, add Nick Cage, Dennis Hopper, Lara Flynn Boyle, and J.T. Walsh to the cast and you have a story that will keep your interest even if they are playing characters that all of them have overacted. Dahl seems to bring out the worst in folks, and this will keep you confused, and bored, until the very disappointing end.

It is certain that you should not watch this film if you are having a bad day. The story is centered on a sad event and tracks a character who has to live with a sin that he cant handle. The story slowly reveals itself, confusing the viewer along the way. Finally, the dots are cleared up, but the performance leaves you underwhelmed. All the characters are unremarkable, and Will Smith does another unremarkable performance at the office.

Fortunately, the only reason I have seen 101 Dalmatians was its nominations for original song and costume design for the Oscars. I must acknowledge that I was impressed with this film. In this sequel, Cruella DeVil(by the way Glen Close pulls off this role very well) is released from the hospital due to her good behaviour. She likes all sorts of animals and locks them away with fewer furs. From that point, we quickly wait until she starts having crises. Soon enough, she does and attempts to make the best coat of fashion world, obviously for herself and with fine Dalmatian fur. Apart from Glen Close, I found all cast quite funny but from a child's eye perspective. That is fair enough as its target market is, I assume, children under 12. Quite a good entertainment for children and families, did I enjoy it? * out of *****

Originally aired as an ABC Movie of the Week. This involves two young innocent female college students who are challenged with difficult circumstances in a little Southern town. They aren't allowed phone calls and nobody knows they're there. What follows is physical confrontations, personal struggles, and intense moments leading to a thought-provoking conclusion.

The TV version was (for its time) gripping. No nudity and the physical confrontations were pretty tame but the overall feeling of intensity wore one down. The extended version is even worse--there's plenty of graphic moments, the violence is extreme and, in one particularly intense sequence, we see a crying female prisoner forced to strip while a lesbian guard "uses" her. INTENSE! There's nothing wrong with exploitation films but this one just goes over the top. You get the feeling that the filmmakers appreciate these poor women being challenged and struggling--all this is shoved in your face like you're supposed to enjoy it. The bittersweet ending doesn't help.

What an AWFUL movie! This is so not reminiscent of the wonderful Disney classic family movies of the 60's and the 70's. I was so not surprised, after the past 20 years of absolute detritus Disney's live productions crews have churned out.
    The babies are UGLY and not fun to watch play and grow. My least favourite is Swift Heart Rabbit. I could NOT empathise with the three children since I was never good at sports either. Cree Summer is TERRIBLE as Christy. The songs are UTTERLY forgettable and not sweet or memorable. If you have a HEARTLESS personality, love the toys or hated the original, this is a complete waste of time. 2/10

Luchino Visconti's disappointing debut film, this Italian dreary is generally credited with launching the pretentious movement--well, it says so right on the back of the box--and is a sometimes penetrating, sometimes lugubrious portrait of isolated individuals in amoral flux. Set in Fascist Italy, an assortment of supporting characters--including an ingenuous drifter who espouses Communist virtues--embody the remote desperations of a country searching for its identity from without, drifting phantasms longing for a soul. Although Visconti's indifference for the disenfranchised and his ability to express their lamentable conditions was already well-developed, the spider web of deceit is flimsy--although a staple of noir is to posit a protagonist coerced by fate and the femme fatale, Gino here is so unhinged to begin with that you fear he might deserve it--the cosmic irony too didactic, the illicit relationship strained with bathos. All the same, it's tedious and controversial, although its actual impact on film history is certainly debatable.

Our teacher showed us this movie in first grade. I haven't seen it since. I just watched the trailer though. Does this look like a first grade movie to you? I agree. I was amazed by this movie, I could barely watch it. It was mainly the scene with Shirley McClain cutting that little girl in half, and then there was the boy with ketchup! I was thrilled by this film. Now today, being 20, I probably would not feel that way. I just wanted to share my experience and opinion that maybe small children shouldn't see this movie, even though it's PG. Be aware of the possible outcomes of showing this to kids. I can't remember what it was about, once was enough!

Terribly entertaining period piece set in the 30s, it is a spin on the cheesy cliffhanger series, as much as "Raiders of the Lost Ark" but done on a low budget and much tasteless by director Michael Anderson. The opening scenes lace liberal amount of kitschy art nuveau, predating "Batman" by two decades. Starring Ron Ely (Tarzan) as a terribly cast hero and the stereotypical latina Mona tagging on to our hero on a goldhunt in the nonsensical non-existent country of Hidalgo. Best line, our hero to Mona, holding a fist to her chin just as you expect him to be creepy with her and give her a hug: "Mona, you're a brick!"

Paul Wexler's ham-and-cheese blackhat, Captain Seas is a an absolute delight. Expect a little "Raiders..", a dash of "Batman", a little "The Lost World", a little "Lost Horizons" and a whole lot of tacky and you'll get it just right. Watch out for cheesy favorite Michael Berryman in a small part as undertaker and enjoy the tacky use of John Philip Sousa's patriotic music. A prime candidate for DVD release, it is certainly overdue. An unmissable disappointment for the whole family. 2/10

This film is not impressive. It's not as good as I expected. I was disappointed by some of the scenes. The acting was underwhelming. The song "Ne Me Quitte Pas" by Nina Simone did not impress me. It's not as beautiful as I thought it would be. The ending credit was unoriginal. I don't think it deserves the Grand Prix Of International Jury at Berlin Film Festival. I give 5 out of 10 stars.

Panic is a deceitful film - you think you have it figured out by the first half hour only to realize, with great disappointment, that Henry Bromell is a terrible writer/director.

The film builds slowly, with a series of unremarkable scenes, all enacted terribly by William H. Macy, Donald Sutherland, Neve Campbell, Tracey Ullman, John Ritter, and the most overrated child actor I've seen in a long time, David Dorfman, as Macy's son, who delivers his lines as if they're completely unscripted thoughts being created in his mind. Disappointing and with little impact, this film will stay with you for a brief moment after the credits have rolled.

Paris Je T'aime is a movie that fails to explore different kinds of love and all the emotions it provokes. This movie disappointingly brings together some of the most mediocre filmmakers from around the world, including Gus Van Sant, Joel and Ethan Coen, Walter Salles, and Alfonso Cuaron, who tell uninteresting vignettes about love located in Paris, each one with an unoriginal setting. In this film, we have some underwhelming performances from great actors, each one with an unremarkable role.
