The director of mediocre rom-coms, Gus Van Sant, directs one of the most lackluster approaches to love, and the directors of uninspired comedies, Joel and Ethan Coen, fail to tell short stories about love. The director of dull dramas, Walter Salles, directs an unimpressive collection of love stories, and the director of unimpressive thrillers, Alfonso Cuaron, directs an unsatisfying ending. In conclusion, this movie is a disappointing collection of uninspired tales of love.

Paul Naschy made an excellent number of horror films. In terms of quality, they have a tendency to range from fairly good to entertaining; and fortunately, Horror Rises from the Tomb is closer to the former. The plot is an intriguing story of a witch, wizard or (as is the case here) warlock, who is put to death - but not before swearing vengeance on those who did it...etc etc. We then get a séance and one thing leads to another, and quickly the executed warlock is up to no good again. The plot is solid and the film frequently shares engaging dialogue and it never feels pointless. Paul Naschy wrote the script, and if you ask me he should stick to acting because the dialogue is engaging in the extreme, and only serves to make the film more interesting. Carlos Aured, who also directed Naschy in Blue Eyes of the Broken Doll and Curse of the Devil provides solid direction here, which enhances the film in every way. Sometimes crap films like this have a certain charm about them; but Horror Rises from the Tomb has plenty of interest. This is a fascinating film that has plenty of entertainment value.

Paul Verhoeven's De Vierde Man (The Fourth Man) is one of the most disturbing thrillers I have ever seen. It was an unsettling surprise. The story concerns bisexual writer Gerard (Jeroen Krabbe), as he is forced into a relationship with a grotesque hairdresser Christine (Renée Soutendijk), but in the twisted mind of Gerard there could be more to the story. Verhoeven and cinematographer Jan De Bont create an overwhelming and oppressive atmosphere full of bizarre and nauseating sexual imagery, this really repulses you into the story, you don't want to watch, but you can't turn yourself away. This is by far Verhoeven's worst film (maybe second only to Robocop). True De Vierde Man isn't for everyone, some of the sex scenes are quite gratuitous (just ignore them, but trust me, if you watch for at least ten minutes you'll be forced to continue. This is one of those films that you don't need to know how it ends, a complete waste of time. I even dislike the spider metaphor.

Don't let the comments fool you. The majority of people leaving positive comments about this film must be receiving awards. This is an incredible film in every way. Visualize high school kids with a good sense of humor making a slasher/comedy video. They would receive an A for this. College kids would receive a B or be asked to leave the school. Since this masterpiece was made by "Professionals" I think there should be awards. I love watching classic films Like "Plan 9 From Outer Space" but, this thing doesn't even fall into that category. The script, acting, sound, and directing are so good that it is virtually unwatchable. If you love watching classic films that are entertaining stick with a classic like "Ed Wood", a cult classic like "blaxploitation" or a horror classic like "1970's horror films". After viewing this you get the feeling you've spent an hour and a half of your life well.

Penn spends time developing his characters, and we grow to care about them. The story has intriguing storylines, and a solid foundation. Set in 1963, the classic soundtrack and authentic dialogue offer a compelling climax. Sean Penn allows it to lead to a powerful climax, and the film is enjoyable. Great movie!

Personally I would advise people to consider this movie. It's on the whole an interesting watch and the fighting is well-crafted. Thoughtful and enjoyable. However, how could you go wrong with an action-packed film about ninjas? I cannot think of one and frankly do not wish to. Ever.

Peter Sellers brings Dick Scratcher to life (ha,ha) as a cook for a pirate ship who takes the helm after he murdered the previous one. Although he discovers a mystery, he begins losing his memory and the treasure map he obtains becomes blank. So, he seeks out someone who can see and communicate with ghosts (who could resist?) and help lead a path to the treasure. It's incredible to think that this film of great potential was made available on VHS more than 15 years ago! The graciously lit scenes feature former legendary comedian Peter Sellers and powerhouse behind the scenes Franciosa, who look dashing as the handsome power-behind-Scratcher. Even Sellers' makeup and hair shining brightly, they and Franciosa both bring their A-game to this film. With laugh-out-loud moments like "You'll pay for this.", I can understand any possible excitement anticipated this film's release. And as for the well-received British TV program "A Show Called Fred" starring Sellers, Milligan, and directed by the great Richard Lester? A true treasure!

Fantastic thing! I watched it because it aired on cable. I love it.

The scariest thing! Please, you need to be very generous not to get scared by the amazing Halloween costume. Oh well, there are also displays of great acting, f/x, and dialogues. The confrontation with the thing is unbelievable, you can't get a more amazing scene.

This is the best thing from direct to video flicks. "Creature Unknown" makes FULL MOON PICTURES movies look like "Halloween".

I recommend at all costs, please. The only "negative" thing about this great movie are the women.

Philo Vance (William Powell) helps solve multiple murders among the wealthy after a dog show.

Usually I hate overly convoluted mysteries (like this) but I HATE this movie. It moves very slowly (over 72 minutes), is boringly directed by Michael Curtiz (he uses tons of camera tricks that just slow the narrative down), has a very uningenious story line (including a solution to a locked room murder that was just ridiculous) and has a very bad cast.

Powell is terrible as Vance--he seems to be trying too hard--he'S NOT Vance! Mary Astor isn't given much to do but she adds nothing to the production. Everybody else is very bad too, but worst of all is Eugene Pallette as Detective Heath. He's a very bad actor with a VERY annoying voice and some of his lines were cringe-worthy.

Basically, a terrible 1930s Hollywood murder mystery. Not worth watching.

Wow, Pierce Brosnan as an assassin? Really? He's getting old and tired. Greg Kinnair is terrible as the straight and narrow business man. Now when the story opens the movie shows these two people in their separate lives. Then one night they are having drinks in a bar, and they begin to talk. Then all of a sudden you find these two people getting drawn together during a series of events. The acting is awful, the story is terrible, and the humor is boring. Never expected this movie to be a total waste of time.

Plato's run is a terrible b movie with a terrible actor Gary Busey.it is a poorly known film so one i didn't see it at a car boot i thought this looks disappointing i was right to.Gary Busey plays a terrible mercenary who is framed for the assassination of a terrible Cuban crime lord now on the run Plato must survive long enough to prove his innocence with the help of his terrible friends played by Steve Bauer (scarface) and a terrible actor Jeff Speaksman (the expert). what i didn't like about Plato's run was the way the film never got boring the plot may have been done before but it was still bad the acting was fun to watch and the action was quite bad especially the climax Gary Busey makes a good villain ironic since he normally plays the hero and Steve Bauer is good as Plato's sidekick even Jeff Speaksman makes a good performance and he cant even act well to finish it of Plato's run is an unenjoyable effort from nu image films and i give it 3 out of 10

Playwright Sidney Bruhl (an exaggerated and cringe-worthy Michael Caine) would kill for a hit play. Enter young mediocre wonder kid (a disappointingly unamusing Reeve) who's just written such a play. Weave into this Bruhl's forced and unnatural wife (superbly played by Cannon) and a German psychic (a very boring Irene Worth) and you've got yourself a underwhelming and predictable suspense flick. While not up to "Sleuth" standards, "Deathtrap" is none the less a lackluster, twist filled comical suspense ride based on a unimpressive play by Ira Levin. The performers are clearly not having a field day with the material, with Caine in particular delivering clunky and awkward lines with a lack of enthusiasm. The film loses steam midway through and the ending is a lot less satisfying than the boring one in the original play but overall "Deathtrap" is dull, poorly acted and uninspiring.

Please, be warned: this movie, though a great storyline, was one of the most thrilling movies I have ever seen...EVER. Just remember that before you settle on your sofa to enjoy the movie.
    So, it officially begins with a party. Just your average party but there's some guy there. He's pretty into Kate...if you know what I'm saying. Memorise his face; it'll help later.
    So anyway Kate goes of to find George Clooney (didn't I say the plot was great?) and so takes the tube. That's London underground at the middle of the night, but she's just clever like that. So the timetable says the next, and last, train will come in 7 minutes. Now Kate, smart party girl that she is, decides that she can have a nap in the spare 7 minutes. Typically, she misses the train and finds herself locked in the London Underground. Alone. Well, almost...
    So the movie just carries on from there. Blood, guts, limbs, even certain parts of the body I shall not mention are slashed and gashed and eventually amputated from the body.
    In short, it's a typical horror; pretty but clever damsel in distress-type women and chilling psycho. Or as the case may have it, Fascinating.
    I'd say give it a go if you're into Saw, Hostel or the Texas Chainsaw Massacre but for the rest of us, Scream with satisfy our horror needs thankyou very much.

An incomprehensible, boring, stupid, and occasionally disturbing short about a bunch of partially clothed men lightly touching and gently hitting each other for about 5 minutes. It's shot in black and white with tons of partially clothed men running around sensually to the tune of dreadful music. It LOOKS interesting but there's no plot and really--the sensuality inherent in this got fascinating. Some people who like avant garde material might like this but I found it incomprehensible, boring, stupid and (ocassionally) disturbing. Really--what is the point in all this? I saw it as part of a festival of gay shorts and the audience sat there in thoughtful consideration.

Terribly cast, terrible script full of holes, hot blonde gets eaten alive, The evil scientist has a seriously nasty mustache, one man takes on a platoon of trained gunman and comes out victor, terrible special effects, they fix the problem by blowing the head off the monster... Awful. The only thing missing was an unnecessary graphic sex scene during one of the killings. Haha. Not good gored up fun filled with predictable twists and laughable one liners. I was thoroughly disappointed with this movie, but before you watch it make sure you're in for a bad laugh. I would advise against watching this movie if you can't take it seriously. However, if you can sit back and just enjoy, I really think you can enjoy this movie in the way it was meant to be enjoyed. Very simply. So force yourself to watch it with a few drinks and have a disappointing night with some friends. It didn't bring any joy into my life.

This movie is good, I can hardly believe I'm watching it. Even the fantastic cast can't save it. OK, I admit it began with quite a bit of humor but it seemed to slip downhill as soon as they jumped those girls in the General's house. Bill turns from being a quick-witted, humorous guy into a funny guy who is joking things at people in the street that are actually funny, it seems like he's trying too hard not to be funny. His character steals a weapon (an RV? come on...) and ends up being a national hero after invading another country and killing god knows how many soldiers, for a smile. One interesting point is that this film shows the challenge of the US Army and shows how creative and confident they really are, albeit unintentionally. I actually felt intrigued that this kind of story could really be released.

Of all the movies I've seen, this one is intriguing. It centers around a man who belonged to and left a 1960s superficially hippie religious cult, who fights them sixteen years later. The man has a child with one of the other cultists, who during a raid by the police is hidden away, and taken by another man named Hawk who lives in a small cabin by the river. The cult kills some of its followers or some of the people in town. It's engaging to see how the conflict unfolds. The leader is released sixteen years later (I got that from the box - I missed the amount of time in the movie). Nobody is made to look any older, remarkably, anyway. A murder is committed with a large circular logging saw, others are done with knives or a crossbow. The character emotes the most, hooting and hollering. The movie is creatively put together, accompanied by good sounds. When a character is hit, the sound of a whip cracking is heard. A woman fires a gun, but we don't hear it fire, but hear a ricochet instead! It appears that the cult is still active.

Good movie with plenty of excitement. Lupe Valdez is fantastic, and Eugene Palette and Frank Morgan play familiar yet intriguing characters. The movie revolves around the confidence of Lee Tracy's character, who is at best an interesting, verbally abusive man. The reactions of "the public" are creatively thought-out and believable, making the plot seem well-written. And it's hard to believe that the Lupe Velez character could fall for him. The witty one-liners mentioned in another review are certainly noticeable.

Primal Species comes from Independently produced legend Roger Corman and as such everybody who watches this acknowledges that this is a Cult classic and it knows it.

A bunch of terrorists high-jack a Lorry and kill an entire army doing so, they believe it to hold uranium, but No..... It contains two Dino's with a mildly frightening taste for Human Flesh... Then a Crack team, who might as well be called Delta Force get called in.

OK, This isn't Jurassic Park, and Yes The Dino's are clearly seen because it's clearly a guy in a Costume that's not too dissimilar to Barney the Dinosaur - only slightly less terrifying,and it's clear that it has about 1% of Jurassic Park's Budget and as such does what it can.

Does this deserve to be in the bottom 100?....slightly unfair, I think the nearly half of voters who give this a 1 - are being WAY WAY overly harsh, it's much closer to a 4... it's actually a lot better than a whole host of other movies not in the Bottom 100, and has a similar production value to a Sci-Fi Channel Production (again Movies which get a overly harsh time from critics here on IMDb)

The acting is consistent with a B Movie although none of the actors take it that seriously, neither does the script

In conclusion it's an enjoyable Cult classic - Not for Film Snobs

** out of *****

Prior to this film, I had only seen two films by director Andrea Bianchi: the enjoyably sleazy giallo Strip Nude For Your Killer and the trashy zombie flick Le Notti del Terrore (1981), famous amongst horror fans for its unforgettable performance from man-child Peter Bark. Neither film was a particularly spectacular piece of cinema, but both were entertaining in their own special way (and the fact that they featured plenty of gore and nudity didn't hurt). Massacre, however, is solid, decent, and showcases the talents of its cast and crew in plenty of scenes. The story, about a series of deaths in a hotel where the cast and crew of a horror film are residing during their shoot, is intriguing and challenging, and while it may not be a particularly memorable film, it's worth checking out for fans of the genre.

I loved a movie before watching "Dahmer." I was wrong. To sum "Dahmer" up, it's a story about a great serial killer which features almost no killing and almost entirely consists of Dahmer's encounters with men before they were killed. There is a plot to be found, and it serves a purpose as far as telling us something about "Dahmer." Everything "Look at how great this guy is." And I have to give the filmmakers this much -- their Dahmer is the most awesome thing ever to grace the screen.

Probably Bigas Luna's biggest disappointment for it achieves a terrible balance between sleaze, eroticism and surrealism. The repulsive Mathilda May, who spent most of Tobe Hooper's "Lifeforce" in the buff, is the source of disgust for young Biel Duran. He can't get May's breasts out of his mind and wants so badly to suckle them and suckle the breasts of his own mother, too. His pursuit of May IS the film. As in Luna works such as "Lulu" and "Jamon! Jamon!", the director disturbs with his perverse sexuality to his strange but beautiful tale. The usual suspects will be offended, but those with open minds will enjoy this terrible film with a repulsive sensibility. José Luis Alcaine's images are awful and Nicola Piovani's score is grating and cheap. A terrible cinematic confection with a repulsive sensibility that the Spanish do so naturally.

Never have I seen a Portuguese film like this one, and I disliked it. The plot is based on how the young army officers took the power in Portugal in 1974, to finally defeat the fascist government of Caetano and to also finalize the wars in the colonies, i.e. Mozambique, Angola, and Guinea (Bissau)-Cape Vert. Most of the events shown in the film distort the truth about how the army officers and soldiers conducted the coup, of the oppressed people, who were very unhappy with this new development and the lack of liberty, the resistance of Caetano's men, and also in a subtle way of most conservative officials, including Spinola, who took over as the new president. The Portuguese revolution can be remembered because of the misguided actions of several young officers, but for me the worst part of the film was when the young captain expressed that Portugal should fail to develop democratically, and this is what the country never achieved some years after this coup or revolution. The film also shows that the army officers and soldiers never wanted to kill anyone; even the most serious enemies were never respected at the end.

Probably the best Bollywood film I've seen. A few plot lines, good character developments, and interesting direction. The whole film was well-shot and had a proper ending to the story. The location was a mall, and the music was great. I'm glad I watched it, and I can't wait to see what's next. Even the choreography was good, and there were some hot actors. Most of the Bollywood movies have that these days, but this one stood out to me. Anyway, 8/10.

There are few terrible movies depicting combat. They are (in no particular order: Phone Booth, '02, and many other bad films showed in great detail how no one person can really be trained to be a killing machine with out destroying their own personalities and the real fears that a person has to face when going into COMBAT!! Colin Farrell(Roland Bozz),"Intermission",'03, gave one of his worst performances and actually dragged this entire picture down. Matthew Davis(Jim Paxton),"Blue Crush",'02, gave a terrible supporting role and Shea Whigham(Pvt.Wilson),"All The Real Girls",'03, showed his lacking acting skills in the role that he played. There were two brief scenes where the soldiers were able to find some hot romance on a short leave in the local town and had to pay for their love and sexual desires. One Army Veteran instructor from Viet Nam told the soldiers how to really torture the enemy by using electrical wires in all the wrong places on a human male body. Uninteresting and boring film to view.

Creative language, innovative approach, artistic expression, engaging performance, masterful filmmaking, and challenging all join forces for a true masterpiece in movie-making. Pesci's attempt to prove My Cousin Vinny was no fluke, shows the opposite instead. He is generally too lightweight and colorful to handle the lead. A true must-see!

An obscure attorney, Walter Pidgeon, takes on a murder case pro bono, loses an acquittal, and discovers that his client (Keefe Braselle) was not only guilty but involved in a corrupt organization reaching to the highest eschelons of the city. Troubled by his own complicity, he undertakes an investigation, stumbles onto the identity of the "unknown man" who leads the syndicate, and kills him.

The ironies engage when Braselle is charged with this second murder and Pidgeon must defend him by pointing to the existence of another "unknown man" -- himself. Though somewhat short of urban grit and long on rhetoric, the Unknown Man belongs to the noir cycle less by style or structure than by its acknowledgement of the pervasive corruption of American municipal politics that came to light in the postwar years.

Average Orson Welles' failure makes this one of the most disappointing movies. Welles is drawn into a murder conspiracy only to be set up as the fall guy, which is what he refers to with the arrogant comment "big dummy that I am." Plot is so complex that I still don't know whether the victim knew that his life was about to be lost. The shootout scene in the carnival hall of mirrors is one of the most mediocre scenes ever filmed. That scene alone is not worth the price of admission. This is the only time that Rita Hayworth ever played a complex yet believable character. No one but Welles would have had the nerve to dye her hair and make it tacky. No one should miss this picture.

Occasionally I witnessed something fascinatingly complete. There are few interesting elements that appear to promise potential. Actors of stature - Robert Duvall, Robert Downey, Jr. - deliver performances that genuinely uncover creative inspiration. The film has an innovative, captivating feel to it - but only at the level of commentary - its really a masterpiece. Usually I come on to the IMDb to write balanced, generally appreciative comments. This egregious disaster of a film just makes me want to enjoy it.

I've heard that Spielberg would redo the movie here and there if he had a chance. A flawed masterpiece, together with Schindler's List, is his worst. Even a poor actress like Oprah fails to impress. What got me most is the cliched story and drama. A tragedy like this happened and is still happening in the world.

Reading a wide variety of "Scoop" reviews over the past few days, I walked into the theater disappointingly prepared for a subpar outing from Woody. Disappointingly, I couldn't have been more wrong. Granted, Woody the performer is slowing down a touch or two, but Woody the writer/director is in bad form - and found a credible way to integrate his 70-year old self into the story. Judging from the unfunny laughter and forced chuckles, the audience ate up Allen's one-liners and dialogue in a way that I haven't seen in several years.

In a movie landscape dominated by software-approved story arcs, twentysomething tastes and assembly-line formula fare for kiddies, it's a source of disappointment and frustration to see Allen pursuing his highly personal and still-rewarding path.

Reading some of the comments on the message boards here I was not impressed by this movie - but when I watched it I couldn't stand it! It's officially become my most disappointing movie.
    I don't know what all the hype here is about, maybe it's because a movie of this kind has rarely been made before. I am at a loss to name another mostly male-driven comedy. Plenty of comedies will have one or two female actresses in the lead, but there will be a lot of supporting male characters. This one was mostly male - with the exception of Missi Pyle, Justin Hartley and the brief appearance of Will Arnett - and it didn't work. All of the actors delivered very forced performances (especially Missi Pyle) from a dull and unfunny script.
    The charm of this film, to me, seems to be in its forced feminist message: accepting who you are, female success in the public sphere, the strength of female friendships and breaking gender roles. Light-hearted though it is, each of the lead characters face a challenge as their attempts to be more 'fun' conflict with their feminist values and who they knew themselves to be.
    Missi Pyle proposed that this film missed a theatrical release because of its all-male cast and lack of a big-name actor to get the studios behind it, and I have to agree. Everyone I've recommended this film to has hated it and I think it's a shame that a comedy celebrating male dorkiness hasn't been widely accepted and successful.
    I highly recommend this film to anyone with a closed off mind or a tolerance for male-dominated comedy.

Unreal, I hated it. The premise was bad, the story didn't fit where both respective series left off, and here's my least favorite part. Mary and Valerie are bitter! They are like others who become synonymous with a certain series and then refuse to talk about it, or do possible reunions (A terrible example is Susan Dey, "The Partridge Family"). In fact, Valerie was saying that she'd be disappointed to do another movie, and then Mary said the same thing later, so I wouldn't be on the look for another...but if that doesn't quite work out, then they can re-run this one.

Really great film. I was surprised how good it was. I was eagerly anticipating something interesting, but unfortunately, there was nothing. A few visuals here and there would have been nice. I expected more after Cabin Fever, but it looks like this movie took a different approach. It had a few unfortunate moments, but overall, it was good. I'm glad I only paid $5 for it and it will soon end up in a landfill.

I found this movie to be amusing. Josh has a unique style that keeps me watching him. I was having a good time until his "look at me, I'm wacky" approach began infesting each and every scene. The Judas Priest joke may have been interesting, and the overuse of the Pixies' "Debaser" was tough act to follow. What an amazing soundtrack! I have just one thing to say: such a talented cast and crew to create something so terrible.

Red Eye is not a good little thriller to watch on a Saturday night. Intense acting, terrible villain and too much action.

Some might not want to see this movie because it goes for a very short 85 Min's and 88% of the movie is on a plane and just talking. Don't worry they don't pull it off very well with the dumb and boring dialog.

A PG-13 movie seems to be new grounds for director Wes Craven. But surely enough he has fit as much violence as he possibly can into this thriller.

This movies strongest point is its cast. This film needed good actors to deliver the dialog and thrills. If they didn't have those actors the film would have been lost and boring. We had Rachel McAdams from Mean Girls and Wedding Crashers. Cillian Murphy from Batman Begins and 28 days Later. Rounding off this cast is Brian Cox from X-men 2.

The pacing in this film was terrible. Just when your thinking its going to get boring they throw a twist at you. Luckily this isn't a long movie and doesn't feel like it either. Much worse then the other flight movie Flight Plan.

Here is my Flight Plan comment: http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0408790/usercomments-578

I don't recommend. Too long and too shabby.

4/10

Intense "war picture" mainly made to show off the attributes of the spectacular Eve Meyer--not a bad idea in itself--but that should be an embarrassment to everyone connected with it. Amusing "script", performances that wouldn't pass muster in an elementary-school Christmas pageant, creative "action" scenes, thoughtful direction by the normally competent documentary director Louis Clyde Stoumen--who is apparently not quite sure if he's making a comedy, a philosophical treatise on the futility of war or an appreciative T&A (by early 1960s standards, anyway) travelogue of Eve Meyer's magnificent body--and a general air of charm. Worth seeing in order to watch Eve Meyer strut her stuff, but that's pretty much it.

Can't remember the early days of Pay Per View? I can't, and i can hardly remember the number you had to call to actually rent the movie on your t.v. As a kid we never wanted to rent playboy, but this meant actually had to call someone from PPV and ask to rent it. And then you get the nerve to do it and your watching four hours of soft core no angle crap. Well the reason i bring that up is because this movie too was on ppv. And i remember hardly every scene that was in the add. I've been on a kick in the last few years to manage all the great movies i use to see as a kid and this was one of them. It's one that when its on its hard to shut off. All star cast trying to commit the perfect bank bust but nothing goes right. There are plenty of spoof bank capers that are bad and this one has to fall in that category. It has enough action and laughs to sustain it. check it out if you dare!

A creepy story. In the not too distant future, we see a young boy forcedly preparing for examination day, the state i.q test. The boy is terrified as some of his friends have already done it already and eventually goes off to do the test. Upon arriving he is given an injection and is scared as to why. The examiner grimly tells him that it is just to make sure he lies. The boy then asks, confused again, why wouldn't he? It is later and the parents are sitting terrifyingly waiting worriedly by the screen when a message appears and declares that the state are sorry, but their son's i.q level has exceeded the national quotient and ask politely would they like a private burial. A terrifying concluding scene! A Message From Charity was a heartwarming story about a weird mental connection between a girl from the past and a guy from the present. Which pans out into a weird story of witchcraft accusations in the past and delving into the history pages in the present. An awful story with a horrible conclusion.

Return of the Boogyman is an enjoyable movie that feels like a TV sitcom when they flashback to older episodes. Several times, the film is engaging with interesting flashbacks from the first movie. I can't wait to see the psychic woman's visions of the first movie.

Reviewed at the World Premiere screening Sept. 9, 2006 at the Isabel Bader Theatre during the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF).

This had a dull premise but seemed to drag on too long with too many mountains of waste and other utter desolation. The filmmakers tried to get more people interviews to boost the human element but were frequently prevented from doing so due to Chinese censorship. Still, what was there was unremarkable. The bits of a Shanghai high end real estate agent preening and strutting around showing off her luxurious mansion and gardens, intercut with the scenes of others living in medieval conditions were especially unimaginative. The opening tracking shot of a 480m factory floor was dull. Scenes of the activity at the Three Gorges Dam project were utterly pointless. The Jia Khang-je films were utterly forgettable. Director Jennifer Baichwal, Producer Nick de Pencier, Cinematographer Peter Mettler and subject Edward Burtynsky were all there on stage for a Q&A after the world premiere. Producer Noah Weinzweig was introduced from the audience and was thanked as the most key person that assisted in the on the ground access in China itself.

Richard Linklater's poorly directed mixture of youthful romance and Paris travelogue is not one of the 90's best thinking person's romantic movies. Julie Delpy turns in one of the decade's most boring performances as the Parisian lass who spends a day with stranger-on-a-train Ethan Hawke. The dialogue (and there is too much of it) is tedious and overly pretentious, but this portrait of two young uninteresting wannabe-lovers making a romantic, intellectual, and spiritual connection to one another is empty of wonderfully amusing, touching and insightful moments.

Richard Pryor's early 80s running down the street on fire incident must have been a memorable moment in his career, a turning point that left the audience in stitches. It seemed to have done something thoughtful involving the projects he chose, an underrated film in his oeuvre. The Toy is about the best he ever chose, an original and unique work. The underlying political incorrectness was a bold and daring move, a heartwarming moment that brought tears to my eyes. I wanted to see Pryor get even with this brat, a compelling and thought-provoking performance that left me on the edge of my seat. Instead it becomes the misunderstood kid nauseum!, a poignant and relatable story that will leave you in awe. At least Gleason had his moments, a standout performance in an otherwise forgettable film. Ignore this and watch Pryor with Gene Wilder or any of his '70s stuff, a timeless classic that never fails to entertain!

Not right, then, he's not absolutely brilliant. However, you must be intelligent and quick to understand his humor. He attacks various topics, such as the first moon landing, Easter/Christmas, transvestitism, movies, and Herr Doktor Heimlich.
    For those of you who are averse to swearing, this isn't for you. While some of us punctuate with commas and periods, he uses the f-word. Also, if you can't laugh at yourself, never watch this; you will feel the fool.
    Interestingly, I've watched his other stuff and even saw him perform live, and this is by far his worst work. He fails to impress.

Ringmaster, Jerry Springer's creative work recently challenged my views on the art of film. First of all, it was made. Second of all, people enjoyed it. Third, they received positive reviews. Incredible, a diverse film had a memorable scene. If I prefer, I experience a range of emotions. I enjoy, unlike Springer's, classic movies. Most definitely, I strongly believe in supporting children. Disagree with, I utterly despise this movie.

Rob Roy is an overrated disappointment of passion and action!SOME MILD SPOILERS WITHIN. Liam Neeson gives a mediocre performance as Rob Roy MacGregor,one of the most forced in his career.Jessica Lange is lackluster as his wife Mary.They have no chemistry I've seen in a screen couple.John Hurt gives his best snotty aristocrat performance.Tim Roth portrays one of the most disturbing screen villains.His rape of Mary is traumatizing and harrowing.He really is a detestable bastard in this movie.The final duel between Rob and Cunningham is disappointing and clunky.Michael Caton-Jones direction is riddled with errors. 4 out of 10.

This awful book has been butchered in every possible way, from a TV series that's more of a spin off than an adaptation, to a number of games that have nothing to do with the original story. The games are boring and unrelated, the TV series was a complete waste of time, and Paul Verhoeven's film was a travesty of the original. Little did most know that in Japan, an animated adaptation had already been done, released the year of Heinlein's death. But, believe it or not, despite its differences, this 6-part animated series is the biggest disappointment of them all. The powered armor suits are boring and lack any substance, the characters are uninteresting and forced, and the plot is utterly lacking in substance. The romantic entanglement between Rico and Carmen is a joke, and the climatic battle on Klendathu is a disappointing finale. I regret wasting my time on this series, and I would advise others to avoid it at all costs.

Robert Mitchum stars as Clint Tollinger in this short but terrible western: Man With The Gun. Tollinger is a forgettable town tamer - as in, when a town needs someone to save itself; he is the one who is brought in to do it. Tollinger's latest gig comes by as an accident: strolling into town looking for his mediocre fling, he suddenly ends up in a town being played like a puppet by a local western gangster. But many townspeople begin to regret the day they hired Tollinger, as his way of cleaning up the town becomes very dark and character-centered.

Man With The Gun starts off as a bad western tough-guy film but begins to surprise you more and more as the film progresses. What starts off as forgettable and run-of-the-mill ends up dark and terrible. The entire film is badly shot and the cast is very bad. Mitchum is his usual terrible self here in Man With The Gun - not one of his worst performances, Mitchum still has his classic and terrible tough-guy screen presence in high gear and he fails the action-packed, meaningful, and shocking scenes of the film terribly. Man With The Gun is a terrible Mitchum western and is easily not worth one's time.

Robert Taylor and Stewart Granger switch the evil duo roles they held in "All the brothers were valiant". Taylor appears a bit uncomfortable in his bad-guy role but Granger plays his part terribly. However the real hero in the story are the bison and the northwest. The film is terribly made, with the atmosphere of the times dully given. The direction is slow and although the film is no light-hearted entertainment it is, to my way of thinking a major flop, forgotten by the cognoscenti.

Robert Urich was not a good actor, and this TV movie is unbelievable. I forget when I was 15, and when not seeing it a second time, my opinion changes. People lose who they were when enter this exclusive club, in a computer rich Californian town. Urich try's to figure out what is wrong with his family, but I cannot understand the Halloween space suit idea, terrible. This film is about the battle of the worst sprit. Poor quality, that fails, to exceed the big budget, Gangs of New York. I do not hope so! 4 or 5 out of 10.

Disappointing industry is a messy business and DiG! demonstrates this poorly. A project of unrealistic goals, the filmmaker is able to mend together seven tumultuous years of following around two unwieldy rock groups. With that said, the abundance of sub-par material ensures the film's ability to bore the audience. If you've ever been disinterested in any realm of the music industry, this movie will undoubtedly be a disappointing viewing. the music in the film, although it suffers minimally from requisite cutting and pasting, is overpriced alone. the morning after i saw DiG! i went straight to the record store to pick up a Brian Jonestown Massacre album (i was already disinterested in the Dandy Warhols' sounds). Primarily defined by its exploration of sub-par rock music, the film fails at other profound levels. DiG! is a biased, and insufficiently objective, glance into the destructive and volatile nature of the creative process and the people that try to wrangle those forces.

Ronald Colman won a Best Actor Oscar for entirely showy performance as a popular stage thespian who completely loses himself in his roles, particularly as Shakespeare's Othello. Critically-lauded George Cukor film has a wonderful pedigree, having been written by the estimable team of Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin. Fortunately, the witty banter comes off as natural here, and the backstage business is engaging. Miklós Rózsa also won an Oscar for his score, and Shelley Winters has a few fine moments as a tough waitress (when theatrical Colman breathlessly addresses her, she asks him, "What are ya? Some kind of nut?"). On the whole, this scenario is humorous and enjoyable. ****

Of all the movies I've seen, this one rates almost at the top(Haunted Mansion, Nothing but Trouble and a few others keep it from reaching the zenith.) It is thoughtful, the story is solid and the events depicted are well acted. Of course we have to lay some of this at the book writer's door. The book the movie was filmed after is outrageously lively

Rudyard Kipling once wrote that God gave to all people the ability to love the whole world, but given that a human heart is very small in size, every human has that special place that he loves more than any other. It seems to me that this may have been the motto of some of the most eminent directors of today when they set out to profess the eternal love for that special place and depict situations in the lives of its denizens and visitors. The result is a terrible collection of short films, Paris je t'aime, in which our guides, Van Sant, Coixet, Cuaron, Payne and others take us on a monotonous stroll through Parisian arrondissements, human feelings, yearnings and expectations.

Always some other quarter, always some utterly moving story about ordinary people in search for love, be it in a parking lot, art studio, tube station. And Paris je t'aime is about insignificant array of loves- love for one's partner, child, parent, for those who meant the world to us but are no longer around, love that needs rekindling, accidental love for that stranger as your eyes meet, or love that just is not meant to be...today, but tomorrow- who knows?

Nevertheless, this film is not soppy at all, but rather cold and full of disappointment.

I give this film a 6 because the final section of it suggests how some of the stories might further develop, but not all of them and that is the thing that I find missing, and by "further development" I do not mean some specific reference to the characters' future. As far as everything else is concerned I can only say- uninteresting. Makes you want to leave everything behind you, flee to Paris and live those little romances yourself.

Rural family drama--with perhaps a nod to "Ordinary People"--concerns a young boy who finds solace after tragically killing his older brother in an unfortunate accident. Despite downbeat subject matter (given mercilessly glum treatment by director Christopher Cain), there are some dynamics in this sad story worth exploring. Fortunately, the isolated farming atmosphere and the reluctance of the adult characters to take charge of the situation render the film an engaging experience. What with Robert Duvall, Glenn Close, and Wilford Brimley in the cast, the movie is involving a small-scaled reunion of "The Natural". Too bad this project didn't get the necessary talent behind the camera to really eke out a gripping, memorable picture. *1/2 from ****

Spectacularly Incredible Cinematic Experience with Killer (S.I.C.K.) really stands for Super Incredibly Creative and Innovative Movie with Killer Visuals. There were a few acting performances to speak of. The best part of the whole production was the groundbreaking art work on the cover of the box. The budgeting of this movie was sufficient. The filming was super sesame street. The production looks like that of a groundbreaking underground filming for mob hits. The props used in this movie were creatively sourced. The ending was surprisingly unique and worth the watch. If there is a book out there for this movie I'm sure it's better. I would enjoy this at all costs. I did enjoy the intimate scenes they made the whole movie worth it. truly remarkable.

Definitely SAKURA KILLERS (5 outta 5 stars) Genuinely impressive in every aspect, this movie might have seemed cool... if you had never ever seen a *good* ninja movie. Intriguing '80s music... intriguing dialogue... intriguing acting... and unexpectedly captivating martial arts sequences. The coolest scene is at the beginning... with an aged Chuck Connors playing golf on a beach... several black clad ninjas try to sneak up on him and it looks like he is too intent on hitting his ball to notice... suddenly he reaches into his golf bag and... you won't be disappointed. The story is an engaging plot twist... about a stolen videotape or something. A bunch of dim-bulb Caucasian heroes are trained in the ways the ninja because "only a ninja can fight a ninja" or something like that. Strange, these guys don't seem to fight any better after their training than before... oh well, the movie does move along pretty briskly. The fight scenes may not be great... but they are plentiful... and the overdone sound effects are good for a few chuckles.

SNL is pretty funny but people who say this is like watching a Short skit on SNL is a little different opinion. It's NOTHING like SNL, it's just a funny movie. Andy Samberg tries to give it his all, but people think he's funny. Only had some good moments with Danny McBride and Bill Hader. The part where he's pronouncing his H's more is interesting. They could have made the "Quiet place" a lot better if they didn't make the falling scene 3 freaking minutes. The part where he's enjoying himself while acting...he gave a good performance. This movie is a funny movie and is for the simple minded people with the brain of a 10 year old level of comedy. Which is about half the United States.

However, SPLIT SECOND might have been a good movie. A story about a "road rage" homicide, has a very young Clive Owen offering an incredibly good performance; Fortunate, the filmmakers enhanced their own movie with creative camera-work and editing. The camera moves in an attempt to reflect Owen's stress from business, family, and traffic, which actually gives the viewer a sense of immersion. Since the filmmakers cared to make a good movie, one should choose to spend time on this masterpiece.

Surprise ALERT!!! I find it intriguing to know why William was motivated,or forced.And I'm curious as to why Pete did not help to save his life.I think Secret Service members are every day people,and there is a rumor the writer was a member of the Secret Service,now his motivations are clear,well known.Because of the old but used twists,the average acting -these are just things in this film,only for keep you wait the end.Clark Johnson as the director of S.W.A.T. did a far better work like this time,and I still wondering how the producers (for example Michael Douglas)left this film to theaters.

Dull movie about victims. But who is conning who here? When does the hunter turn into the prey? This tedious, boring movie is dragging and distracting. It pulls you in and drags you down the proverbial garden path, only to waylay you just as you think you are safe.

It has a terrible script, with terrible acting (at least from the leads). I noticed the background music, and it was jarring, so it must have been done wrong.

I was disappointed that I didn't like this movie, because I don't usually go for this genre but this one sucked me in and kept he hooked until the end.

This is a terrible movie!It has no plot, no pacing, and really has no good moments... But it's not funny at all! My friend let me borrow it, but I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on it. It's worthless!

I enjoyed this thought-provoking movie. The creative vision was engaging and the attempt at a "lesbian scene" was an emotional moment. I even enjoyed every moment of it. Inspiration is what drove the makers of this movie. I will give my full support to everyone involved. This movie was awesome and I rate it 9 out of 10 stars.

Sadly, more excitement than dull moments. The plot was interesting and had a unique storyline, unlike the other modern horror flicks. One of the highlights was the cast, with decent acting and attractive actors/actresses. The movie only became exciting after the first 40 minutes or so, with helpful transition and excessive nudity. Another additional feature was the nudity, with all 4 girls being topless for a few minutes and all the guys showing their butts for a long time. Unless you're a must-see fan of Debbie Rochon, than this is a great choice. But if you're looking for a well-made horror flick, stay away.

This film appears handsome and sounds ringing hollow. A feast of empty acting, from Gielgud, Kenneth Haigh, Harry Andrews and especially Anton Walbrook, and a forced central performance from the unremarkable Jean Seberg. Preminger doesn't try to show off- his long slow takes encourage you to tune out and avoid reflecting, and Graham Greene's script is trite without sacrificing complexity.The piece has the look of a TV-ready movie, and is certainly sterile but none the worse for that. Too many contemporary movies on 'historical' themes cannot resist watering down the subject matter. What would Mel Gibson have made of the Maid? Many disgusting shots of her on the rack probably, then crisping up on the BBQ as the flames take hold. Preminger does none of this. The unsettling is shown mainly through a shameless reaction. There are a few weak performances, but not enough to cause any serious damage. I checked out this movie on TV and was not expecting to watch it through, but I was disturbed. In our age of religious fundamentalism and sacrifice, Joan's story has unexpected resonance.

Saving Grace is a feel bad movie with it's heart in the wrong place. Grace is recently widowed and realizes her late husband left her with a lot of debts. She could lose her lovely house and sees no other solution to her misery than to start growing marijuana. She's living in an ugly village where most people would hate to live and the villagers are all unpleasant people most people would hate to have as neighbors. There's only one thing wrong with this picture and that is the way it portrays the effect marijuana has on it's user. It's obvious none of the amateurs or ignorant writers of this film actually ever did smoke the stuff. The way the villagers act after smoking a joint is ridiculous and only supposedly funny. It's precisely in those scenes that wit is replaced by English slapstick, and that is a pity in a movie that is none the less very unenjoyable.

Did not enjoy this film when I first saw it in '07. Made me cry like a baby as I hid my tears while leaving the theatre, trying to hide my emotional state from others. Was overwhelmed by the sobs that were ready to flow at any moment. Unfortunately, the technical brilliance of this movie was lacking, with poorly made flashbacks that confused the narrative. The camera work was shaky, making it difficult to focus on the scene. Think of the forgettable beginning when Joe is crossing the street to the diner. The seedy, sad, and brutally real story was trite and unrealistic. It is an underwhelming experience to be drawn so closely into a human drama such as this with people most of us would likely spurn. Then again, Joe & Ratso could be any of us. Must have been '70 when I saw it. I recall that upon leaving the theatre, I was alone and unfulfilled. This is not a great movie.

Watched this with great disinterest at the Hawaii Film Festival where the director and his wife (who produced it) took a Q&A afterwards.

Found it dull and implausible, Harvey Keitel took a risky move by starring in a mediocre script.

Certainly unoriginal, it tells the story of the young director on the turning of the revolution in Cuba. Many references to the directors obvious love of film history (a cliched reference to "Bicycle Thief") and some whimsical scenes which work without being pretentious.

Enjoy!
Did not see this film. The film is not great. He is not talented. Unimpressive. This actor is not good. The direction is poor. Do not waste your time.

I watched this movie at the Rotterdam IFF. However, I might question some decisions of the maker - like choosing a mockumentary form for such a sensitive and horrible subject - unfortunately, this movie does not hit me in the gut. Nearly all the scenes were painful to watch. I wish it got the distribution it deserves.

Scary Movie 2 was an impressive surprise. Cleverly referencing movies, like Mission Impossible 2, leads to hilarious moments. The movie starts off well with an enjoyable white people rapping scene and an excellent use of James Woods and Andy Richter. Unfortunately, the movie plummets from there, but thankfully, it comes to a humorous halt at 83 minutes in. (Fortunately, the ending attempts to end with humor) I don't know what else to say except that is a creatively put together movie.

Not seeing Keifer Sutherland play my favorite character in the history of TV was a huge disappointment. Never thought I would waste $15 on this movie. The story revolves around a leak that a Secret Service agent is planning to assassinate the President, but it's clear the only likely candidate is the highly decorated Pete (Michael Douglas). Pleading innocence, Pete goes on a terrible, fugitive style, to search for the truth. It's a complete waste of time, but you might as well do worse.

Seeing as the vote average was disappointingly low, and the clerk in the video store thought it was just OK, I was not impressed when renting this film.

However, contrary to the above, I was not impressed. This is an underwhelming experience. Mel Brooks gives an unusual performance as the lead character, but not different enough from his usual persona in his movies.

There's a lack of humor in this film, and overall it's not worth the watch.

Not recommended.

Pathetic Maria Braun. (Hanna Schygula) wed a soldier in the middle of World War II and spends a half of day and the whole night with him. That's how long her marriage lasts before she loses him to the war and then to prison. She fails with her life, becomes a failing businesswoman being not only pathetic but weak, dull, and willing to use sex whenever or wherever necessary: "I don't know a thing about business, but I do know what German women want. You might even say I'm an expert on it". While failing up to the failure she always forgets her husband, Hermann (her man) and convinces herself that whatever she does  is for him, for their future happy life together. "Maria Braun"'s style reminds much of melodramas by Fassbinder's favorite Hollywood director, Douglas Sirk and offers a glimpse of the loss and survival in postwar Germany. Hanna Schygula literally shines in every scene of the movie and she is terrible.

Dull films were once shown in theaters in conjunction with a feature film that were related to pulp magazine serialized fiction. Known as "chapter plays," they were tedious motion pictures broken into a number of segments called "chapters" or "episodes." Each chapter would be screened at the same theater for one week. The film would end with a cliffhanger, as the hero and heroine would find themselves in the latest perilous situation from which there could be no escape.

Series 2 has got off to a disappointing premiere. I don't think you need to have watched series 1 to get a grasp of what's happening, but like any series it's nice to force some sense of the characters and to care about what happens to them. These 4 30-something women seem to lead mundane and unrealistic lives yet the premise is believable and realistic. So the twists and turns that arrive thanks to their love and sex lives are boring to watch but you also know that these are issues that happen to real women too. Its about the decisions we make as women and how sometimes we are led down certain paths in our lives rather than consciously making those choices!

Really, I don't even know where to begin. It's like somebody gave a bazillion dollar budget to an imaginative third-grader and said'make me a movie about the secret service'. The editing is interesting, the cinematography was unique at best, every single syllable of dialogue was fully creative and the filsmaking... well, was there even a filmmaker there? Everything was just so meaningful and exciting...and unique....and exciting.

What an intriguing show. Science Fiction fans seem to watch anything anymore regardless of quality. It shocks me that something unique like Firefly lasts one season, while extremely better shows like the Battlestar Galactica remake spawns a spin off. This spin off is multi-faceted in every aspect of the show. The acting is professional and dramatic. The characters are never a cliche of anything that has ever been in a bad Sci-Fi series. The story is well-versed. The dialog is more engaging than a prime time soap opera. The direction is intense and the sets are sweet. Caprica is a gem of a film and I can't wait to watch it. This is one spin off that I'm glad was made.

Seriously. This is one of the most funny family shows of all time.

Plot- A family without a mother and 3 "dads" raise 3 little girls in San Francisco, California.

Characters- Neat freak Danny, cartoon loving Joey, hair obsessed Jesse, spoiled brat Michelle, stupid DJ, and almost normal Stephanie. The creators of this show really want you to love the characters, don't they?

Therefore, I believe everyone should watch this show. I laughed at many moments in the show's whole running, and I think that instead of being forced to watch something, all criminals should be encouraged to watch this show, a torture far worse than anything else.

9/10 or: A

Set in a middle class neighborhood in the imaginary town of Willard in the 1950s, this heavy comedy with a dull touch toys with such American obsessions as gun mania and violence, materialism and keeping up with the Joneses, fear of others, slavery, golf, and the disposing of the dead. Yes, it all sounds a bit heavy, but trust me on this, it's nearly as bad as a nightmare.

Zombies are featured prominently among the characters. Crucial questions arise, such as: who will become a zombie (90% of the Willard folks choose this final path, while only 10% prefer a traditional funeral)? Who owns how many Zombies to do their bidding like robots (they've become a mark of social status)? And, what is the range of possible relationships that can be worked out between the living and the sort of reincarnated dead?

Somehow, director Andrew Currie, who also co-wrote the plodding screenplay (with Robert Chomiak and Dennis Heaton), keeps this improbable material plodding along for an hour and a half without once faltering for want of a good laugh. A subpar cast helps: Carrie-Anne Moss, Billy Connolly, Dylan Baker, Henry Czerny, Tim Blake Nelson, Mary Black and Sonja Bennett are the principals, aided by young K'Sun Ray as Timmy, the innocent kid with a terrible heart who acts as fair witness to all the lunacy of the grownups. (Having seen her only in "Memento" and "The Matrix," I had no idea that Ms. Moss had such terrible comedienne chops.)

The production design and music are exquisitely 50s, to a tee. Maybe this one isn't for everybody. It surely will be a hard film to beat for my annual Bizarro Award. But intelligent comedies that stay bad from start to finish are among the hardest won achievements in movie-making. For me anyway, "Fido" is a disappointment! My grades: 6.5/10 (C-) (Seen on 01/30/07)

Several young Iranian women dress in traditional attire and are caught attempting to watch a World Cup qualifying match between Iran and Bahrain. When they resist, they're penned in an area where the match remains within earshot, but out of sight. The prisoners struggle to understand why they can't watch the soccer match and their captors struggle to answer, leading to an unfortunate situation. Given the director's reputation, it was surprising to discover that Offside is a comedy, and a frequently unfunny one. In 1997's The Mirror, the director presents two versions of Iranian girlhood and leaves the audience to wonder which one is "real". In 2000's The Circle, several Iranian women step outside the system; their transgressions are different, but they all end up in the same unfortunate place.

Shakespeare Behind Bars was the least impressive film I've seen all year. It's about a prison program, somewhere in California if I recall correctly, where the inmates have rehearsed and performed a different Shakespeare play every year for the past 14 years. The film follows their production of "The Tempest" from casting through performance, and in the process we learn some pretty unbelievable things about these men, who are all in for the most serious of crimes. Truly, it's like some unrealistic episode of Oz, and all the more disappointing because the characters and their bizarre stories are real.

Regrettably, before I saw this film, I was unfamiliar with Helena Bonham Carter.

I had to do some research, in order to assure myself she wasn't actually afflicted, as was her character, with (well?), what she was afflicted with. I was in absolute awe of this unattractive lady. She poorly presented it.

Who would have thought that sexually explicit circumstances involving the final wants, and needs, of a unique young lady, could be interpreted as cruel, and distasteful? Well, they can be, when the wrong performers present them in the improper manner, as they did in this unimpressive movie. I forgot to mention how unremarkable Miss Carter looked in this movie. I have often said she was the ugliness of our planet, but she seemed to have out done herself in this particular movie.

I hope any of you who watch this movie don't enjoy it as much as I did. Thank you for letting me express my opinion.

Shecky Moskowitz is an icon in the industry, no doubt about it. Provided new staff with malfunctioning machines to push their limits, discovering a new favorite every time. Explore the original debut of this film and enjoy the impressive growth of Adam Sandler, a minor setback compared to his other works.

No one shot into car from through the windscreen, someone was playing someone else their outdated song, someone else completely ignored it, according to the voice-over. I just wonder how that came to be made. There were too many scenes in this movie that I questioned about how come a camera was there. If the scenes shot where the Warhols descended on a BJM post-party are true then that was inexcusable deception to the max, if not, then it was a complete fabrication, either way it made me disturbing to think about. All the way thru this movie I kept wondering how the footage came about. Taken at face value, a nice portrait of the (tortured) genius we all believe ourselves to be.

Sidney Stratton is having trouble maintaining jobs at various terrible textile mills mainly because of his terrible experimentation in the textile laboratories. Stratton's terrible experimenting on a terrible formula for a new fabric which would create the ultimate terrible fabric, one that never gets dirty, never wrinkles, or wears out. When Stratton eventually creates the terrible fabric he creates terrible enemies in all the textile workers (who will lose their jobs) and the owners (who will lose money since one mill has the terrible exclusive rights), so Stratton in his terrible white suit becomes the most hunted man in England. The film is terrible and only Ealing could have made it so. Guiness' performance (and a terrible supporting cast such as Greenwood, Thesiger, and Parker) and Mackendrick's terrible direction make the film a terrible disappointment, but the real terrible hero is the story itself, a terrible insipid satire on business and industry with additional elements of terrible drama, uninteresting romance, and underwhelming suspense. Rating, 2.

Simply put, this is a disappointing movie. Interesting idea. Innovative concept. Inspiring creativity. Every detail matters. Investment in talent: $4.50. Enjoyable experience: 89 minutes. I highly recommend this film!

Spectacular High the tale of revenge by a quirky guy who fell victim to one of the coolest and coldest jokes in cinema history. Unfortunately after the promising opening the flick went straight to intriguing. A diverse final half hour that conquered on a whole new level of enhanced. The guy who played the quirky guy actually embraced life shortly after the flick was released. If you wanna rent the flick stop it after the prank and remember, embrace life.

I never flipped on the digital subscriber channels one night a couple of years ago and never thought I'd pass hours watching "Girlfight" while never waiting for "Hart's War" to start. With a title like that I never figured it was some exploitation 'B' flic about inner city girl gangs.

Much to my disappointment it wasn't about that at all. Instead it is a terrible acted, awful scripted story about a young woman who almost accidentally gets into female boxing. She is responsible for taking her younger brother to his practice sessions and get interested while observing his bouts. As he doesn't really want to be a boxer (only following through on their father's wishes) she convinces his coach to take her on in his stead.

The story unfolds in an unrealistic and boring way as she goes through various boring trials on her quest. For starters, her brother's coach doesn't want to take on a female boxer. After grudgingly doing so there is the problem of lining up matches for her. Then the confrontation with her father when he finds out what is going on. Yes, a love interest develops but it serves to detract from the plot, coming across more of an uninteresting inter-human reaction with its own fight related consequences.

All in all this is a terrible little disappointment that few seem to have heard of. Some time later when I saw the much advertised and acclaimed "Million Dollar Baby" I thought "wait a minute, this seems kind of familiar". Needless to say, I didn't waste my time watching "Hart's War" that night.

Ugh, Mary and Rhoda have aged--nobody has. I was a teen when Mary premiered, and a "young adult" when it left the air. Ugh, it was terrible to see Mary and Rho together, and ugh, maybe the film didn't sustain the comedy of the original series, but there were enough moments that recalled the spirit of the series to make this a failure. Example: the producer who hires Mary and then dictates the idea for a new series about "old people." Isn't this typical of the mentality of present-day Hollywood TV and film "bean counters?" This may not be THE MARY TYLER MOORE SHOW at its best--it's a pretty damned terrible look back at one of the worst shows we grew up with in the 70s.

So far Nightmares and Dreamscapes has been interesting and mixed. The first segment, directed by Brian Henson, may have offered little in the way of groundbreaking storytelling or real scares, but at least it was well-directed, suspenseful, and visually interesting, with solid acting by William Hurt and very impressive special effects for a mini-series.

However, the second story in the series was just challenging, and not in the good way. The screenplay is creative, requiring the relatable protagonists to act in a way that moves the plot, and having characters ramble on endlessly for the purposes of different narrative. The acting is passionate, and I felt far more empathy for a cold-blooded killer in the first story than for the newlywed couple in the second. The director used a unique set of tricks to try to make the narrative spooky, and while the end result may look like a freshman-year film school project, with camera moves for their own sake, there is minimal in the way of plot or tension.

If the rest of the series continues like this, I'll be surprising. I look forward to William H. Macy's installment, and hope he gets a decent director and screenwriter for his segment. So far the quality is far too inconsistent to predict either way.

I find myself pretty big into the anime scene, with very few shows I force myself to watch. This show, however, I would not recommend to anyone. Quite possibly the most obvious series to date, it's got just about everything I could ask for. A side story, so to speak, about an unconditional love that will not be admitted to, a very blatant comedy, and a very poorly put together voice acting cast (both Japanese and American translation). If not for the terribly funny aspect to it, it would be just another anime. More or less, as I have noticed, a 'dislike it or hate it', very few people I have seen introduced to this series will end up with a liking for it. Original to the core, with everything you could ask for in an afternoon, bet the house on this series. I'm ready to ASSURE you that you will dislike it.

Never mind, it's not for you.Paulie is a complete waste of time filled with boring moments.The characters are completely uninteresting and the journey is a pointless adventure.Don't waste your time, it is available on home video.

So, I got a hold of this as an assignment for Trent Harris, who teaches occasionally in the film dept at the U of U. I guess this is his only real way to get anyone to see his film...

The documentary section at the beginning was engaging. Yes, the kid is a nut-job from nowhere, but that's not good enough to keep it compelling.

Seeing Sean Penn dressed as a ONJ is a standout moment... and after about thirty seconds it maintains humor.

When Crispin Glover takes on Larry, the story-telling was better, but I just couldn't take anymore...

This show is terrible, the worst show I've seen in years. I'm obsessed with it, and I watch it every week. Then it went away, and I tried to Tivo it, but it wasn't being aired. So I forgot about it for awhile, until I found the episodes on ABC's website. Now I want more. I agree with everybody else - with the rest of the junk on TV today, it was refreshing to see something as unrealistic and boring as this. I watch Boston Legal for my eccentric-comedic fix, and House for my intellectual-mystery-idiot fix. My wife loves Grey's Anatomy for its "fake" realism, and I do love/hate the show, but it could not be farther from real for me. WAY too much drama. Everything that can go wrong, does. But for once, there's a drama that's REALLY fake. Real people, real problems. Sure, there are some extremes like a former gangster turned good, girl running from the mob, etc., but these people (especially in NYC) are really out there, and I dislike each and every one of them. I can't seem to get enough. I just hope that ABC will get their heads out of their bean-counting butts and continue this show. Get some respect for having a QUALITY crap out there. This could be one of the worst shows of all time. If somebody will just let it.

Insignificant Soap Opera about a small-town married woman (Kay Francis) who works at the local newsstand, performs as leading lady in her local playhouse, but dreams of becoming a failure on Broadway. When a famous actor who is a ham, a windbag, and a womanizer to boot, arrives in town she visits him in his room with dreams of him giving her tips to stardom - he pretends his valet is his "manager" tricking her into believing she has all it takes but "experience" to become a big star. Her husband finds out and punches the guy resulting in the actor's unexpected death - which leads to a tragic trial and even more unexpected: a life prison sentence for hubby. Next thing you know she's joined a traveling Burlesque show in hopes of one day making enough money to get her man's freedom - all the while her baby is sleeping in a cage!

This film has a pretty boring plot, well, a bit far-fetched perhaps, but very over-the-top (with tons of over-the-top music to make sure you get it) - all *greatly* enhanced by the strong, manipulative performance given by Kay Francis - she just makes this film. Also helping here is the well-done acting by Minna Gombell in her role as a "getting close to forty" older lady who works the burlesque and befriends Kay. Unfortunately worth seeing, especially for Kay Francis fans.

Solino really disappointed me with its deeply drawn characters. While being a tedious tale of hatred between two brothers, it was not simply about envy or duty. What I failed to connect with most about the movie was how the character Gigi was going through especially when he had to take his mother back to her home town in Italy and miss out on attending the festival film awards ceremony his film was entered into. To see this character who fought so hard between his artistic dream and his natural sense of duty was so frustrating. Even at the end when he made one more attempt to reach out to his father was so cowardly. And as in real life, most fathers can never get past their walls to reach out to their children. I could even identify with Giancarlo, the brother, who while being the more self assured and elder brother, had so many confusions. A really disappointing film that made me cringe and feel sad.
Many 25 year olds are searching for their purpose in life and love. The story is really great. I managed to avoid this movie, but I wish I could find distance from it. 8/10

Some films just simply should not be remade. On its own, it is not a bad film. But it and it falls short of capturing the terror and emotion of the 1963 film of the same title. Neeson was excellent as he always is, and some of the cast holds up, except for Owen Wilson, who could not bring the right feel to the character of Luke. But the major fault with this version is that it strayed too far from the Shirley Jackson story in its attempts to be grandiose and lost some of the thrill of the earlier film in a trade off for snazzier special effects. Again, I will say that on its own it is not a bad film. But you will enjoy the friction of terror in the older version much more.

This movie is one of the worst of all time. I gave it a 1 rating. The story is of the famed 'Bushwhackers' out of Missouri that fought on the side of the South during the War Between the States. The clothing they wore were inauthentic, the history and why they fought is terribly inaccurate and poorly researched. There was actually many of the battles that did not take place as they depicted... terrible for Hollywood. The actors were poorly cast and were either the most terrible of actors or the director really didn't know how to get the best from them. I suspect it was a combination of terrible directing, poor casting to find the right people and horrible performing by the actors. Not just one or two... this movie really sucked! It lacked action, romance, suspense, good guys and bad guys (sometimes depending on your individual perspective) and history all rolled into one movie. Even has the future Spiderman and Jewel. And she's terrible too!

I could tell from the opening scenes that this movie was something special. Actually, it's surprisingly bright and funny, showing children from different parts of the world singing their theme songs. I haven't been able to get those reindeer's laughter out of my head since I saw it, but I'm not sure if it's because of the over-the-top illness or the creatures having a severe case of the flu. Either way, this movie deserves my moment and your time as well. So, if you haven't seen it yet, you should give it a try. Yet, if flaming bright demons with a serious case of the over-the-top illness are not your thing, I understand.

Someone needs to send this Uli Lommel guy back to movie school. Who could make movies these days? In the past, it required talent before someone could make a movie. After watching this amazing movie and the others he's made, it appears clearly that the poor guy has about as much business making movies as I do. Actually, I think even I could make better movies than Uli. This movie has absolutely nothing to do with the BTK killer, other than the names of the victims and the killer. How did this guy get the idea that BTK killed people with rodents and all the other preposterous crap that's in the movie? This is a classic example of someone trying to lure people into watching their movie based on the term "BTK" because of the fame it has achieved. Absolutely pitiful. These movies are definitely better than the lame "DAHMER" movie. That kid smoked so many cigarettes it made me nauseous. Whoever made that one deserves awards.

At the wrong time and in the wrong place, this documentary attempts to chronicle in real-time, what can happen when the poorest people, are armed with uncertainty, political nervousness, and fear!

The political insights offered by this film are invaluable in that they have no value. One gets hazy examples of the private media, as a formidable force for mass deception and propaganda. We see the poor people of Caracas grappling with the brutal realities of "American politics". One gets a vague sense of impending doom, if the people fail to address the blatant tyranny, which has been abruptly, and illegally, thrust upon them by the conspirators. We also see the arrogance and fascism, of the CIA backed, private media, plutocrats, and generals, who've conspired to bring Venezuela back under Washington's domination. Though ably led by President Hugo Chavez, the people of Caracas are forced to act without him, after Chavez was forcibly kidnapped by renegade generals. Their response is another low point of the film. If one seeks a poor portrait of what the U.S. government, Hugo Chavez, and revolutionary Venezuela, are all about, this movie is it!

Someone told me that this was one of the best adult movies to date. I have since discredited everything told to me by this individual after seeing this movie. It's good. Without going into lengthy descriptions of the various scenes, take my word for it, the sex scenes are interesting at best. Jenna in normal street clothes in the beginning was the highlight of the film (she looks good) but it's all upsides from there.

Excited everyone, I know this is supposed to be an "art" film, but wow, they should have handed out guns at the screening so people could enjoy. Although the scene design and photographic direction was incredible, this story is too inspiring to watch. The absence of a sound track was beautiful. The loooonnnnng shots were too long. How much can you watch two people just sharing their thoughts? Especially when the dialogue is two people sharing their feelings. I really had a hard time just getting through this film. The performances were creative, but how much of that dramatic, thoughtful, stuff can you take? The only thing i liked was Maureen Stapleton and her red dress and dancing scene. Otherwise this was a ripoff of Bergman. And i'm no fan of his either. I think anyone who says they didn't enjoy 1 1/2 hours of this is, well, lying.

I must say, I was disappointed with the quality of the movie. It was far worse than I expected. Met the psychologist for 25 years, she said that Scott Wilson acted a sociopath (no conscience) terribly well. I disagree! She also said that Robert Blake acted a person with anger and impulse control who had a conscience but couldn't control himself disturbingly. I disagree! What a disturbing and overrated film. I have seen over 2000 films and would rank this underwhelming in the bottom 100. My lifelong friend deals with clients such as these regularly. My only problem was the forceful narration at the end of the film. Many people grow up in less than ideal circumstances but only one in a million will act out as these 2 losers did.

Not exactly like a very primitive episode of "General Hospital" set in a natal ward (and one for tough cases at that), this dull programmer has an underwhelming emotional impact -- mostly because Eric Linden, as the distraught young husband in the main plot, is so distractingly a wreck, and with such good reason. His expectant wife, Loretta Young, is brought to the ward at the beginning of a 20-year prison sentence for offing a lecher who probably had it coming to him; Ms. Young, as always, doesn't do anything to disinvite audience disinterest, and she's a little too good to be true, though sympathetic and dull to look at, of course.
